The proceeds of such taxes shall be placed in a special fund and shall be disbursed only for the purposes specified herein; provided, however, that in lieu of such tax levies, the City Council may annually transfer to such special fund any available money of the City, but in no event shall the amount transferred to any one year exceed the amount which would result from a tax levied in such year as herein limited. As long as any bonds issued for special or local improvement districts hereafter organized remain outstanding, the tax levy or equivalent transfer of money to the special fund created for the payment of said bonds shall not be diminished in any succeeding year until all said bonds and the interest thereon shall be paid in full, unless other available funds are on hand therefor, or such bonds and interest are paid by the City as required in section 11-24 of this Charter. 
Sec. 11-28. - Bond sales; limitations. 
    Refunding bonds shall be sold at public or private sales or exchanged as may be determined by the City Council. All other bonds shall be sold to the highest and best bidder for cash at public sales after advertisement for public sales, and if all bids are rejected, they may be sold at private sales and to the best advantage of the City. Each bond issue may contain provisions for the redemption of bonds prior to their respective maturity dates on such terms as may be provided by the City Council, including, without limitation, the payment of a premium. 
(Ord. No. 647, passed at the Nov. 6, 1973 election) 
Part 4. - Receipts and Expenditures 

Sec. 11-29. - Receipts and expenditures. 
    The City Treasurer will cause the total receipts and itemized expenditures, except individual employee's salaries, to be published monthly in a newspaper of general circulation. Gross salaries of individual municipal employees shall be published semi-annually, in a newspaper of general circulation, with said individual employee's gross salary for July being thus published in August of each year, with the individual employee's gross salary for January being published in February of each year. 
(Ord. No. 880, passed at the June 5, 1990 election) 
Sec. 11-30. - Publication cost. 
    Price is to be governed by current state statute governing legal publications. 
Article XII. - Utilities and Franchises 
Part 1. - City-Owned Utilities 

Sec. 12-1. - Authority and powers. 
    The City shall have and exercise with regard to City-owned utilities, including water and water rights and acquisition thereof and bonded indebtedness in connection therewith, all the authority and powers now provided by the Constitution and statutes of the State of Colorado, including those statutes hereinafter established by act of the general assembly. In addition, the City shall have the power to exchange water rights owned by it for water rights owned by other persons, municipalities or quasi-municipal corporations. The City shall also have the right to contract with such aforementioned persons or entities for the purpose of forming consolidated water or sewer districts or for furnishing any municipal services, provided any agreements or contracts arising therefrom would clearly benefit the inhabitants of the City. 
Sec. 12-2. - Water rights in annexation. 
    The City shall have the power to purchase or obtain such existing water rights as may be used upon any land which is annexed to the City from time to time. 
Sec. 12-2.5. - Services to private correctional facilities. 
    No City-owned utility shall provide any water or wastewater services to a private correctional facility, as defined in Section 14-1 of this Charter, wherever such facility is located, unless having first obtained authorization from the eligible electors of the City of Lamar, in the manner described in Section 14-5 of this Charter. 
(Ord. No. 1078, passed at the November 1, 2005 election) 
Part 2. - Franchises and Public Utilities 

Sec. 12-3. - Definition. 
    The term "public utility" or "public utility corporation," when used in this Charter, shall mean any person, firm or corporation operating heat, power or light systems, communication systems, water, sewer or scheduled transportation systems, and serving or supplying the public. It shall not include any person, firm or corporation owning or operating sidetracks or switches for the accommodation of manufacturing plants and business houses, or private telephone lines, and shall not include municipally-owned utilities. 
Sec. 12-4. - Present franchises. 
    All franchise ordinances of the City in effect at the time that this Charter is adopted shall remain in full force and effect according to their provisions and terms until the expiration dates provided in such ordinances. 
Sec. 12-5. - Franchises granted upon vote. 
    No franchise shall be granted except upon the majority vote of the qualified tax-paying electors voting thereon at a general or special election called for that purpose. Such election shall be held within ninety days after deposit with the City Clerk of the expense (to be determined by the City Clerk) of such submission by the applicant for such franchise. 
Sec. 12-6. - Term, compensation, and restriction. 
    No franchise shall be granted for a period longer than twenty years, or without reserving to the City such fair fee arising from the use thereof as shall be fixed in the grant of such franchise. This compensation shall not exempt the grantee or his assignees from any lawful assessment upon his property or from other tax not related to the franchise privilege, or pertaining to the physical operation thereof, but shall exempt the grantee or his assignees from any occupancy tax, license, tax, permit charge, or similar tax on the privilege of doing business or in connection with the physical operation thereof, as shall be fixed in the grant of any franchise. The franchise fee established by ordinance shall be paid as provided and be subject to mutual periodic renegotiation, and failure to pay such fee shall result in forfeiture of the franchise at the option of the Council. 
Sec. 12-7. - Railroad tracks and crossings. 
    The Council may require by ordinance and by fair apportionment of the cost, subject to arbitration, any railroad or other transportation system to elevate or lower any of its right-of-way or tracks running over, under, along or across any public thoroughfare; and to construct and maintain all street crossings, bridges, viaducts or other conveniences in good condition with proper approaches and safety devices. 
Sec. 12-8. - Extension of territory. 
    With respect to any franchise, after negotiation or mutual agreement, the Council may, by ordinance, extend the area to include streets, alleys or public places and property not embraced in such franchise when public convenience and necessity requires, subject to all the terms and conditions of such original franchise, and co-extensive with the terms thereof, without a vote of the qualified tax-paying electors. 
Sec. 12-9. - Revocable licenses. 
    After public hearing, the Council, by ordinance, may grant a license, revocable for cause, to lay sidetracks and switches along or across any public thoroughfare, in accordance with standards and procedures to be adopted by the Council. 
Sec. 12-10. - Revocable permits. 
    The Council may grant permits for the temporary use or occupation of any street, alley or public place. Such permits shall be revocable by the Council at any time, whether or not the right is expressly reserved in the permit. 
Sec. 12-11. - Condemnation or purchase. 
    The right of the City to construct, purchase or condemn any public utility, work or way, as provided by the Colorado Constitution and statutes, is expressly reserved. 
Sec. 12-12. - Assignment. 
    Assignment or leasing of a franchise shall be considered a forfeiture unless application therefor be made to the City and consent given by the Council by ordinance, with such change of conditions or terms as they may deem necessary. The Council reserves the right to deny any assignment of franchise. 
Sec. 12-13. - Books and records. 
    The Council shall cause to be kept in the office of the City Clerk an indexed franchise record in which shall be transcribed copies of all public utility franchises heretofore and hereafter granted. The index shall give the name of the grantee and any assignees. The record shall be a complete history of all such franchises and shall include a comprehensive and convenient reference to all actions at law affecting the same, and copies of all annual reports, and such other matters of information and public interest as the Council may from time to time require. 
Article XIII. - Transitional Period 

Sec. 13-1. - Status of transitional provision. 
    The purpose of this article is to provide for an orderly transition from the present City government to a home rule government under the provisions of this Charter. This article shall constitute a part of this Charter during the transition period. 
Sec. 13-2. - Transition period. 
    The period from the effective date of the Charter to January 1, 1963, shall be known as the transition period. During this period, all officers and employees shall proceed with due diligence to put into effect the provisions of this Charter. During the transition period, the Council shall designate by resolution provisions of the Charter to become operative. Resolutions shall fix the dates on which, and the agency or agencies to which, each provision becomes operative. Until superseded by this Charter, or any provision thereof, the state statutes shall be in effect. 
Sec. 13-3. - Present Council and Mayor to continue in office. 
    The Council and Mayor, or their appointed successors, in office at the time of the adoption of this Charter shall continue at their present salaries to serve and carry out the functions, powers and duties of their offices until the 10th day of September, 1962. 
Sec. 13-4. - Retirement plans. 
    This Charter shall not affect any contractual relationships existing on the effective date of this Charter between the municipal government and any officer or employee by reason of any retirement plans in effect. 
Sec. 13-5. - Local improvements. 
    Local improvements not completed on the effective date of this Charter shall be governed until completed by the ordinance under which they were commenced. 
Article XIV. - Correctional Facilities[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1078 passed at the November 1, 2005 election. 

Sec. 14-1. - Private correctional facility defined. 
    The term "private correctional facility," when used in this Charter, shall mean any facility that is used or intended to be used for the incarceration of adults and that is owned or operated by a private correctional facility operator, or proposed to be owned or operated by a private correctional facility operator. 
Sec. 14-2. - Community corrections program not a private correctional facility. 
    Notwithstanding any provision of this Charter, a community corrections program, as defined in Article 27, Title 17, Colorado Revised Statutes, or corresponding sections of successor legislation, shall not be considered a private correctional facility as defined in Section 14-1 of this Charter. 
Sec. 14-3. - Private correctional facility operator defined. 
    The term "private correctional facility operator," when used in this Charter, shall mean any person, corporation, partnership, business, association, limited liability company, government enterprise (as defined in Article X, Section 20 of the Colorado Constitution), or any other entity that is not an agency or political subdivision of the State of Colorado nor an agency of the Federal government, which operates or seeks to operate a private correctional facility. 
Sec. 14-4. - Limitations on construction and operation. 
    No private correctional facility operator may construct or operate a private correctional facility within the City of Lamar except as allowed for in Section 14-5 of this Charter. Nor shall the City of Lamar expend any funds on, nor shall any city employee in his official capacity engage in, the recruitment or promotion of any private correctional facility proposed to be built within Prowers County, except as allowed for in Section 14-5 of this Charter. 
Sec. 14-5. - Authorization powers regarding construction and operation of facilities reserved to people of Lamar. 
    The powers to authorize construction or operation of a private correctional facility within the City of Lamar; to authorize the City of Lamar to expend funds or staff time on the recruitment or promotion of a private correctional facility proposed to be built within Prowers County; and, to authorize city-owned utilities to provide water or wastewater services to a private correctional facility, are reserved to the people of Lamar, and said authorization may only be granted by the eligible electors of the City of Lamar, at a municipal election, on an initiated or referred measure. Any question submitted to the people of Lamar pursuant to this section shall include, at a minimum: the name of the prospective private correctional facility operator, the maximum inmate capacity of the facility, what jurisdictions may place inmates in the facility, and not less than one nor more than five locations at which the private correctional facility might be located. 
    Adopted in Convention this 24th day of May, 1962, and signed in triplicate.

PART II - CODE OF ORDINANCES 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Title and scope. 
    This Code constitutes a compilation, revision and codification of all the ordinances of the City of Lamar, Colorado, of a general and permanent nature, and shall be known as the Lamar, Colorado Municipal Code. 
(Code 2000, § 1-1-20; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, whenever used in the ordinances of the city and/or any codification of the same, shall be construed as defined in this section, unless a different meaning is intended from the context or unless a different meaning is specifically defined and more particularly directed to the use of such words or phrases. Additionally, all definitions and construction rules set out in the Charter as applicable to terms in the Charter shall also be applicable to this Code and shall have the same meaning when used in this Code as prescribed in the Charter, unless a different meaning is specifically provided or intended from context. 
    City. The term "city" means the City of Lamar, Colorado, or the area within the territorial limits of the City of Lamar, Colorado, and such territory outside of the city over which the city has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any constitutional or statutory provision. 
    City council or council. The term "city council" or "council" means the city council of the City of Lamar. 
    Code. The term "Code" means the Lamar, Colorado Municipal Code, as published and subsequently amended, unless the context requires otherwise. 
    County. The term "county" means the County of Prowers, Colorado. 
    C.R.S. The abbreviation "C.R.S." means the Colorado Revised Statutes, including all amendments thereto. 
    Law. The term "law" denotes applicable federal law, the constitution and statutes of the state, the ordinances of the city, and, when appropriate, any and all rules and regulations which may be promulgated thereunder. 
    May. The term "may" is permissive. 
    Misdemeanor. The term "misdemeanor" means and is to be construed as meaning violation and is not intended to mean crime or criminal conduct. 
    Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
    Oath. The term "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation or declaration in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases, the terms "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the terms "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Ordinance. The term "ordinance" means a law of the city, provided that a temporary or special law, administrative action, order or directive may be in the form of a resolution. 
    Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building, land, motorized vehicle, animal or other real or personal property, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety or any other person with a possessory interest in the whole or a part of said building, land, motor vehicle, animal or other real or personal property. 
    Person. The term "person" means a natural person, joint venture, joint stock company, partnership, association, club, company, firm, corporation, business, trust or organization, or the manager, lessee, agent, servant, officer or employee of any of them. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes money, goods, chattels, things in action and evidences of debt. 
    Preceding and following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The term "property" includes real and personal property. 
    Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Shall and must. The terms "shall" and "must" are both mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means that portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    State. The term "state" means the State of Colorado. 
    Street. The term "street" includes all streets, highways, avenues, lanes, alleys, courts, places, squares, curbs or other public ways in the city which have been or may hereafter be dedicated and open to public use, or such other public property so designated in any law of this state. 
    Tenant and occupant. The terms "tenant" and "occupant," applied to a building or land, include any person who occupies all or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Written. The term "written" includes printed, typewritten, mimeographed, multigraphed or otherwise reproduced in permanent visible form. 
    Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. 
(Prior Code, § 1-2; Code 2000, § 1-2-10; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-3. - Rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the rules and definitions set out in this chapter shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the council. All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the council may be fully carried out. Further, the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than another more general provision imposed by the Code or other law, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
Sec. 1-4. - Computation of time. 
    The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day; but if the time for an act to be done shall fall on a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday, the act shall be done upon the next regular business day following such Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. 
(Prior Code, § 1-2; Code 2000, § 1-2-20; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-5. - Title of office. 
    Use of the title of any officer, employee, department, board or commission means that officer, employee, department, board or commission of the city, or his or her designated representative. 
(Code 2000, § 1-2-30; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-6. - Usage of terms. 
    All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases, and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law, shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
(Code 2000, § 1-2-40; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-7. - Grammatical interpretation. 
    The following grammatical rules shall apply to this Code and to city ordinances: 
(1)  Any gender includes the other genders. 
(2)  The singular number includes the plural, and the plural includes the singular. 
(3)  Words used in the present tense include the past and future tenses and vice versa, unless manifestly inapplicable. 
(4)  The term "may" is permissive, and the term "shall" is mandatory. 
(Prior Code, § 1-2; Code 2000, § 1-2-50; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-8. - Catchlines of sections; effect of history notes; references in Code. 
(a)  The catchlines of sections of this Code printed in boldface type, italics, or otherwise, are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section or subsection, and shall not be deemed or taken to be the titles thereof, or as any part thereof, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(b)  The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. Editor's notes and state law references which appear after sections or subsections of this Code or which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of this Code and have no legal effect. 
(c)  All references to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions or sections are to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions or sections of this Code, unless otherwise specified. 
(Prior Code, § 1-3; Code 2000, § 1-3-10; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-9. - Effect of repeal or expiration of Code section. 
(a)  The repeal of a Code section or ordinance, or its expiration by virtue of any provision contained therein, shall not affect any right accrued or any offense committed, and penalty or punishment incurred, or any proceeding commenced before the repeal took effect or the ordinance expired. 
(b)  When any ordinance repealing a former Code section, ordinance, clause, or provision shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former Code section, ordinance, clause, or provision, unless it shall be expressly so provided. 
Sec. 1-10. - Repeal of ordinances not contained in Code. 
    All existing ordinances and portions of ordinances of a general and permanent nature which are inconsistent with any ordinance included in the adoption of this Code are hereby repealed to the extent of any inconsistency therein as of the effective date of the ordinance adopting this Code, except as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 2000, § 1-1-50; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-11. - Ordinances saved from repeal. 
    The continuance in effect of temporary and/or special ordinances and parts of ordinances, although omitted from this Code, shall not be affected by such omission therefrom, and the adoption of this Code shall not repeal or amend any such ordinance or part of any such ordinance. Additionally, among the ordinances not repealed or amended by the adoption of this Code are ordinances: 
(1)  Creating, opening, dedicating, vacating or closing specific streets, alleys and other public ways. 
(2)  Naming or changing the names of specific streets and other public ways. 
(3)  Authorizing or relating to specific issuances of general obligation bonds. 
(4)  Creating specific sewer and paving districts and other local improvement districts. 
(5)  Authorizing the issuance of specific local improvement district bonds. 
(6)  Making special assessments for local improvement districts and authorizing refunds from specific local improvement district bond proceeds. 
(7)  Annexing territory to or excluding territory from the city. 
(8)  Dedicating or accepting any specific plat or subdivision. 
(9)  Calling or providing for a specific election. 
(10)  Authorizing specific contracts for purchase of beneficial use of water by the city. 
(11)  Approving or authorizing specific contracts with the state, with other governmental bodies or with others. 
(12)  Authorizing a specific lease, sale or purchase of property. 
(13)  Granting rights-of-way or other rights and privileges to specific railroad companies or other public carriers. 
(14)  Granting a specific gas company or other public utility the right or privilege of constructing lines in the streets and alleys or of otherwise using the streets and alleys. 
(15)  Granting a franchise to a specific public utility company or establishing rights for or otherwise regulating a specific public utility company. 
(16)  Appropriating money. 
(17)  Levying a temporary tax or fixing a temporary tax rate. 
(18)  Relating to salaries. 
(19)  Amending the official zoning map. 
(20)  Being temporary, although general in effect, or special, although permanent in effect. 
(21)  In force at the time the Charter became effective, except when the ordinance conflicts with provisions of the Charter, or except if the ordinance has been amended or repealed by enactments pursuant to the Charter. 
(Code 2000, § 1-1-70; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-12. - Authorized acts. 
    When this Code requires an act to be done which may as well be done by an agent or representative as by the principal, such requirement shall be construed to include all such acts performed when done by an authorized agent or representative. 
(Code 2000, § 1-3-20; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-13. - Purpose of Code. 
    The provisions of this Code, and all proceedings under them, are to be construed with a view to effect their objectives and to promote justice and promote the health, safety, morals and general welfare of the public. 
(Code 2000, § 1-3-40; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-14. - Amending Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal, or in any way affect this Code shall be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. In the case of repealed chapters, sections, and subsections or any part thereof by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time as the Code and subsequent ordinances omitted are readopted as a new code by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the section numbers of this Code may be made by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _____ of the Lamar, Colorado Municipal Code, is hereby amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions may then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "The Lamar, Colorado Municipal Code, is hereby amended by the addition of a section (or subsection or chapter) to be numbered _____, which section reads as follows:...." The new provision may then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, subdivisions, divisions, articles or chapters sought to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, chapter, or provision number, as the case may be. 
(Prior Code, § 1-4; Code 2000, § 1-3-60; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-15. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  Supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code that have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the person authorized to prepare the supplement may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances or resolutions and parts of ordinances or resolutions included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the person may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions. 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles. 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers. 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code that embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code). 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinances inserted into the Code. 
(d)  In no case shall the person make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Code 2000, § 1-3-70; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-16. - Examination of Code. 
    The mayor and city clerk shall carefully examine at least one copy of the Code adopted by this ordinance to see that it is a true and correct copy of this Code. Similarly, after each supplement has been prepared, printed and inserted in this Code, the mayor and city clerk shall carefully examine at least one copy of this Code as supplemented. The copy of this Code as originally adopted or amended shall constitute the permanent and general ordinances of the city and shall be so accepted by the courts of law, administrative tribunals and all others concerned. 
(Code 2000, § 1-3-80; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-17. - Copy of Code on file. 
    At least one copy of this Code so certified and sealed most recently shall be kept in the office of the city clerk at all times, and such Code may be inspected by any interested person at any time during regular office hours, but may not be removed from the city clerk's office except upon proper order of a court of law. 
(Code 2000, § 1-3-90; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-18. - Sale of Code books. 
    Copies of this Code book may be purchased from the city clerk upon the payment of a fee, to be set by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 2000, § 1-3-100; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-19. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever, except by ordinance or resolution or official acts of the mayor and/or the city council. 
(Code 2000, § 1-3-110; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-20. - Severability. 
    The provisions of this Code are declared to be severable, and if any section, provision or part thereof shall be held unconstitutional or invalid, the remainder of this Code shall continue in full force and effect, it being the legislative intent that this Code would have been adopted even if such unconstitutional matter had not been included therein. It is further declared that if any provision or part of this Code or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held invalid, the remainder of this Code and the application thereof to other persons shall not be affected thereby. 
(Prior Code, § 1-5; Code 2000, § 1-3-120; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-21. - General penalty. 
(a)  In this section, the term "violation of this Code" means: 
(1)  Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; 
(2)  Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; 
(3)  Failure to perform an act if the failure is declared a misdemeanor or an offense or unlawful by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; or 
(4)  Causing, allowing, permitting, aiding, abetting, suffering or concealing a violation of the Code as defined in subsections (a)(1) through (3) of this section. 
(b)  In this section, the term "violation of this Code" does not include the failure of a city officer or city employee to perform an official duty, unless it is provided that failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section or it is clear from the context that it is the intent to impose the penalty provided for in this section upon the officer or employee. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided: 
(1)  A person convicted of a violation of this Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $300.00, as set forth in section 3-8 of the Charter, plus any applicable costs or charges incurred in prosecution as may be permitted by law. 
(2)  With respect to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day the violation continues is a separate offense. 
(3)  Multiple acts constituting different violations of the Code will be treated as a separate offense. 
(d)  The imposition of a penalty does not prevent revocation or suspension of a license, permit or franchise or other administrative sanctions. 
(e)  Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time are a public nuisance and may be abated by any means as are provided by law. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent seeking and obtaining any injunctive, declaratory relief, including any and all available damages. 
(f)  Any penalty or punishment of a jail sentence prescribed in this Code or the Model Traffic Code for Colorado and the International Property Maintenance Code, as adopted by ordinances of the city is repealed and declared null and void. The sole punishment shall remain a fine of not more than $300.00 for each violation for which a conviction or deferred judgement is entered in the municipal court for the city. 
Sec. 1-22. - Jurisdiction over juveniles. 
(a)  Pursuant to the grant of jurisdiction contained within C.R.S. § 13-10-104, the definition of the term "child" contained within C.R.S. § 19-1-103(18), and Colorado case law, the municipal court is hereby authorized and empowered to hear and try all alleged violations of municipal ordinances of the city, alleged to have been committed by children. The grant of authority and jurisdiction herein contained shall be nonexclusive, and shall be concurrent with the juvenile courts of the state. 
(b)  Any child, within the meaning of C.R.S. § 19-1-103, shall be subject to prosecution in the municipal court, pursuant to the provisions of Rule 204, Colorado Municipal Court Rules of Procedure, and the provisions of C.R.S. § 13-10-111 regarding "Commencement of Actions - Process," and directing the initiation of prosecution by the issuance of a summons and complaint; provided, however, that no such child shall be subject to the arrest and detention powers contained within said Rule 204. 
(c)  No child, upon conviction of a violation of a municipal ordinance in the municipal court, shall be incarcerated or held in detention by reason of such conviction, but rather, shall be subject to the provisions of C.R.S. § 13-10-113(4) and (5). The fine to be imposed upon any child convicted of a municipal ordinance violation in the municipal court shall be limited to an amount not in excess of $300.00 for each separate offense upon which conviction shall be had. 
(d)  Any conviction of a child upon a municipal ordinance violation shall be subject to the provisions of chapter 2, article IV, division 5 of this Code. 
(Code 2000, § 1-4-50; Ord. No. 932, §§ 1-4, 1993; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-23. - Monitored home detention. 
(a)  The municipal court shall be authorized to utilize monitored home detention, either standing alone or in conjunction with other authorized penalties, as a penalty imposed upon persons, including juveniles under 18 years of age, convicted of violating the municipal ordinances of the city. The municipal court is authorized to enter into such arrangements and agreements as may be necessary to provide for such monitored home detention for convicted defendants, and shall make reports concerning such arrangements to the city council when the same become effective or as may be thereafter amended. 
(b)  All costs and expenses of such monitored home detention shall be borne by the convicted violator, with the municipal court hereby being authorized to compel payment of such costs and expenses in the manner provided for in C.R.S. § 13-10-113. 
(Code 2000, § 1-4-60; Ord. No. 967, §§ 1, 2, 1996; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-24. - Entry onto premises for inspection or investigation. 
    Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any provision of this Code or any ordinance, or whenever there is probable cause to believe that there exists an ordinance violation in any building or upon any premises within the jurisdiction of the city, any public inspector of the city may, upon presentation of proper credentials and upon obtaining permission of the occupant, or if unoccupied, the owner, enter such building or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any duty imposed upon him or her by ordinance. In the event the occupant, or if unoccupied, the owner, refuses entry to such building or premises, or the public inspector is unable to obtain permission of such occupant or owner to enter such building or premises, the public inspector is empowered to seek assistance from any court of competent jurisdiction in obtaining such entry. 
(Code 2000, § 1-5-10; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-25. - Authority to enter premises under emergency. 
    Law enforcement officers certified with the state, members of the fire department, other fire departments operating under a mutual assistance agreement or automatic aid agreement with the city, certified emergency medical technicians and paramedics, during the course of employment with a governmental agency, are hereby granted the authority to enter private residences within the city without invitation from the occupant of the residence at any time such persons have reasonable grounds to believe a medical emergency is in progress within the subject premises and the occupant of such premises is incapable of consenting to the entry because of such medical emergency. 
(Code 2000, § 1-5-20; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-26. - Announcement of purpose and authority to enter premises. 
    Unauthorized entry pursuant to section 1-25 shall be permissible only after the individuals seeking entry have announced both their purpose and authority in a loud and conspicuous voice and have waited a reasonable period of time for the occupant to respond before making entry. 
(Code 2000, § 1-5-30; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 1-27. - Corporate seal. 
    The corporate seal of the city shall consist of the words "City of Lamar, State of Colorado," arranged between two concentric circles, with the word "Seal" in the center, all of which shall be engraved upon a metallic disk, which shall be used to impress the same upon all documents requiring the seal of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 1-6; Code 2000, § 1-6-10; Ord. No. 149, § 9) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Applicability of statutory provisions regarding municipal governments, C.R.S. § 31-1-102. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Procedure for disposition of unclaimed property. 
(a)  Prior to disposition of any unclaimed property having an estimated value of $50.00 or more, the city clerk shall send a written notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last-known address, if any, of any owner of unclaimed property. The last-known address of the owner shall be the last address of the owner as shown by the records of the city department or agency holding the property. The notice shall include a description of the property, the amount or estimated value of the property and, when available, the purpose for which the property was deposited or otherwise held. The notice shall state where the owner may make inquiry of or claim the property. The notice shall also state that if the owner fails to provide the city clerk with a written claim for the return of the property within 60 days of the date of the notice, the property shall become the sole property of the city and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(b)  Prior to disposition of any unclaimed property having an estimated value of less than $50.00, or having no last-known address of the owner, the city clerk shall cause a notice to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. The notice shall include a description of the property, the owner of the property, the amount or estimated value of the property and, when available, the purpose for which the property was deposited or otherwise held. The notice shall state where the owner may make inquiry of or claim the property. The notice shall also state that if the owner fails to provide the city clerk with a written claim for the return of the property within 60 days of the date of the publication of the notice, the property shall become the sole property of the city and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(c)  If the city clerk receives no written claim within the above 60-day claim period, the property shall become the sole property of the city and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(d)  If the city clerk receives a written claim within the 60-day claim period, the city clerk shall evaluate the claim and give written notice to the claimant within 90 days thereof that the claim has been accepted or denied in whole or in part. The city clerk may investigate the validity of a claim and may request further supporting documentation from the claimant prior to disbursing or refusing to disburse the property. 
(e)  In the event that there is more than one claimant for the same property, the city clerk may, in the city clerk's sole discretion, resolve said claims, or may resolve such claims by depositing the disputed property with the registry of the district court in an interpleader action. 
(f)  In the event that all claims filed are denied, the property shall become the sole property of the city and any claim of the owner of such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(g)  Any legal action filed challenging a decision of the city clerk shall be filed pursuant to Rule 106 of the Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure within 30 days of such decision or shall be forever barred. If any legal action is timely filed, the property shall be disbursed by the city clerk pursuant to the order of the court having jurisdiction over such claim. 
(h)  The city clerk is authorized to establish and administer procedures for the administration and disposition of unclaimed property consistent with this article, including compliance requirements for other city officers and employees in the identification and disposition of such property. 
(Code 2000, § 4-4-10; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 2-2-2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ANNEXATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Colo. Const. art. 2, § 30, right to vote or petition for annexation; Colorado Municipal Annexation Act of 1965, C.R.S. § 31-12-101 et seq. 

Sec. 2-21. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish a procedure to bring land under the jurisdiction of the city in compliance with the Colorado Municipal Annexation Act of 1965, C.R.S. § 31-12-101 et seq., as amended. 
(Code 2000, § 15-1-10; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-22. - Responsibilities of applicant. 
    In addition to other duties imposed upon all applicants by this Code and the Colorado Municipal Annexation Act of 1965, as amended, all applicants shall have the following responsibilities: 
(1)  The applicant is responsible for having a representative at all meetings where the request is reviewed. Failure to have a representative present will be cause to have the item withdrawn from the agenda of that meeting. 
(2)  The applicant shall consult with the planning department to discuss any special conditions pertaining to the annexation and to obtain an annexation petition. 
(Code 2000, § 15-1-20; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-23. - Preliminary steps. 
(a)  Procedure. 
(1)  At least 15 days prior to the presentation of any annexation petition to the city council, the applicant shall submit to the city the annexation petition, the annexation fee as established by the city council, a minimum of 15 copies of the master plan and annexation map, and a minimum of five copies of all required supportive information. 
(2)  The planning department shall review all documents submitted for completeness and accuracy and compliance with C.R.S. § 31-12-107. If all documents are complete and accurate, the planning department shall submit the annexation petition to the city administrator. 
(3)  The city administrator shall present the annexation petition and a resolution initiating annexation proceedings to the city council, which shall thereafter establish a date for a public hearing. Upon the establishment of a public hearing date, the city clerk shall give appropriate notice in accordance with the Colorado Municipal Annexation Act of 1965, as amended, and shall specifically direct copies of the annexation petition and the resolution initiating the annexation procedure by certified mail to the clerk of the board of county commissioners and to the county attorney of the county wherein the territory is located. Copies of the annexation petition and the resolution initiating the annexation procedure shall also be sent by certified mail to any school district or special district having territory within the annexed area. These copies shall be sent at least 25 days prior to the public hearing. 
(4)  Upon acceptance of the annexation petition by the city council, the planning department shall furnish to the following entities copies of the annexation map and the master plan. The planning department may submit copies of the annexation map and the master plan to additional interested entities as determined by the planning department in its sole discretion. Such entities shall be advised by the planning department of the scheduled hearing date and shall further be notified that any objections to the annexation and master plan must be submitted to the city in writing no later than seven days after receipt of the annexation map and master plan. 
a.  Telephone companies. 
b.  Franchise utility companies. 
c.  City engineer. 
d.  Fire department. 
e.  Public works department. 
f.  State department of transportation. 
(5)  The planning and zoning commission shall review the annexation map, master plan and zoning request at a public hearing evaluating the proposed area's eligibility for annexation pursuant to the criteria set forth in C.R.S. § 31-12-104 and limitations set forth in C.R.S. § 31-12-105, and the planning commission shall submit a written recommendation to the city council. 
(b)  Annexation map. All annexation maps shall be made with an engineer's scale, minimum scale to be one inch represents 100 feet, and shall be on a reproducible medium with outer dimensions of 24 inches by 36 inches. The annexation map shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The date of preparation, the scale and a symbol designating true north. 
(2)  The name of the annexation. 
(3)  The names, addresses and telephone numbers of the applicant and the firm or person responsible for preparing the annexation map. 
(4)  The legal description. 
(5)  Distinction of the boundary that is contiguous to the city and the length of same. 
(6)  Lot and block numbers if the area is already platted. 
(7)  Existing and proposed easements and rights-of-way. 
(8)  Existing and requested zoning and acreage of each requested zone. 
(9)  Ownership of all parcels within and adjacent to the annexation. 
(10)  Appropriate certification blocks as directed by the planning department. 
(c)  Master plan. All master plans shall be made with an engineer's scale, minimum scale to be one inch represents 100 feet, and shall be on a reproducible medium with outer dimensions of 24 inches by 36 inches. The master plan shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The date of preparation, the scale and a symbol designating true north. 
(2)  The name of the annexation. 
(3)  The names, addresses and telephone numbers of the applicant and the firm or person responsible for preparing the master plan. 
(4)  Existing and proposed easements and rights-of-way. 
(5)  Block numbers and lot numbers with approximate dimensions. 
(6)  Proposed gross and net residential density. 
(7)  Existing watercourses with adequate easements for flood control. 
(8)  Designation of all public sites to be reserved and dedicated. 
(9)  Existing two-foot contours. 
(10)  Appropriate certification blocks as directed by the planning department. 
(d)  Supportive information. The following supportive information shall be submitted with the annexation map and master plan: 
(1)  Soil description and limitation. 
(2)  Preliminary utility plan. 
(3)  Mailing addresses of all property owners within 200 feet of the annexation. 
(4)  Affidavit concerning the amount and historical use of all water rights owned. 
(5)  Vicinity map with a radius of 11/2 miles, at a minimum scale of one inch represents 2,000 feet. 
(6)  Statement on community need for the proposed annexation and zoning. 
(7)  For all annexations in excess of ten acres, the applicant shall obtain from the school district governing the area to be annexed a statement of the effect of the annexation upon the school district, including an estimate of the number of students generated by the proposed annexation and the capital construction required to educate such students. 
(Code 2000, § 15-1-30; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-24. - Annexation impact report. 
(a)  For all annexations in excess of ten acres, the city shall prepare an impact report regarding the proposed annexation not less than 25 days before the date of the annexation hearing. Such report shall be paid for by the applicant. One copy of the impact report shall be filed with the board of county commissioners governing the area proposed to be annexed. The preparation and filing of the annexation impact report may be waived upon approval of the board of county commissioners governing the area proposed to be annexed. 
(b)  The annexation impact report shall include the following: 
(1)  A map of the city and adjacent territory showing the following information: 
a.  The present and proposed boundaries of the city in the vicinity of the proposed annexation. 
b.  The present streets, major trunk water lines, sewer interceptors and outfalls, other utility lines and ditches and the proposed extension of such streets and utility lines in the vicinity of the proposed annexation. 
c.  The existing and proposed land use pattern in the areas to be annexed. 
(2)  A copy of any draft or final pre-annexation agreement, if available. 
(3)  A statement of the city's plans for extending or providing for municipal services within the area to be annexed. 
(4)  A statement of the city's plans for the financing of municipal services to be extended into the area to be annexed. 
(5)  A statement identifying all existing districts within the area to be annexed. 
(6)  A statement of the effect of the annexation upon the school district governing the area to be annexed, as is more fully set forth in section 2-23(d)(7). 
(Code 2000, § 15-1-40; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-25. - Consideration of annexation ordinance. 
    Upon the submission of documentation in accordance with this article, and upon compliance with the notice and hearing requirements as set forth herein and in the Colorado Municipal Annexation Act of 1965, as amended, the city council may consider the approval of an ordinance annexing the subject property to the city. In the event the city council considers and disapproves such ordinance, no similar request may be heard for a period of one year from the date of denial. 
(Code 2000, § 15-1-50; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-26. - Final submission. 
    In the event the city council approves an annexation ordinance, the applicant shall submit to the planning department two Mylars of the final annexation map and two Mylars of the master plan within ten days of the effective date of the annexation ordinance. 
(Code 2000, § 15-1-60; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 2-27-2-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal Election Code of 1965, C.R.S. § 31-10-101 et seq.; Uniform Election Code of 1992, C.R.S. § 1-1-101; recall elections, C.R.S. § 1-12-101 et seq.; also article II and article IV of the Charter; municipal home rule elections, C.R.S. § 32-2-211. 

Sec. 2-56. - Election wards. 
(a)  The city shall, until amended by the city council, be divided into three election wards for the purposes of municipal elections, as follows, to wit: 
(1)  Ward 1. Ward 1 includes all of that sector of the city being located south of East Olive Street (U.S. Highway 50) and east of South Main Street (U.S. Highway 287), except that portion of the sector being located south of Parkway Drive, north of the Fort Bent Canal, west of Parkview Avenue and east of South Main Street. 
(2)  Ward 2. Ward 2 includes all of that sector within the city being located north of East Olive Street, west of Main Street and east of Eighth Street, extended south to intersect the south city limits and extended north to intersect the north city limits. Further, all that sector being located south of Parkway Drive, north of the Fort Bent Canal, west of Parkview Avenue and east of South Main Street. Further, all of that sector north of Washington Street, west of Eighth Street, south of the Lamar Canal and east of 13th Street. 
(3)  Ward 3. Ward 3 includes all of that sector within the city being located west of Eighth Street and south of Washington Street, extended south to intersect the south city limits. 
(b)  When a street divides two wards, the boundary line is the centerline of the street. 
(Prior Code, § 2-2; Code 2000, § 2-1-10; Ord. No. 149, § 2; Ord. No. 586, §§ 1-3; Ord. No. 870, 1989; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1082, §§ 1-5, 2005) 
Sec. 2-57. - Election precincts. 
    Pursuant to the authority granted by section 2-2 of the city Charter, the following election precincts are established: 
(1)  In Ward 1, one precinct is hereby established and its boundaries shall be identical to and coextensive with the boundaries of such ward. Such precinct shall be known as Precinct One, Ward 1. 
(2)  In Ward 2, one precinct is hereby established and its boundaries shall be identical to and coextensive with the boundaries of such ward. Such precinct shall be known as Precinct One, Ward 2. 
(3)  In Ward 3, one precinct is hereby established and its boundaries shall be identical to and coextensive with the boundaries of such ward. Such precinct shall be known as Precinct One, Ward 3. 
(Prior Code, § 2-3; Code 2000, § 2-1-20; Ord. No. 618, § 1; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-58. - Conduct of elections. 
(a)  The Uniform Election Code of 1992, C.R.S. § 1-1-101 et seq., and the requirements and procedures for conduct of elections therein, as set forth in state statutes, is hereby adopted for the regulation of municipal elections within the city. 
(b)  The city council may provide by resolution that municipal elections, when deemed necessary, shall be conducted pursuant to the requirements and procedures of the Colorado Municipal Election Code of 1965, C.R.S. § 31-10-101. 
(Code 2000, § 2-1-30; Ord. No. 920, §§ 1, 2, 1993; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-59. - Write-in candidate affidavit. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of C.R.S. § 31-10-306, no write-in vote for any municipal office shall be counted unless an affidavit of intent has been filed with the city clerk by the person whose name is written in prior to 64 days before the day of election indicating that such person desires the office and is qualified to assume the duties of that office if elected. 
(Code 2000, § 2-1-40; Ord. No. 922, § 1, 1993; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-60. - Cancellation of election. 
    If the only matter before the voters is the election of persons to office, and if, at the close of business on the Friday before the election, there are not more candidates than offices to be filled at such election, including candidates who have filed affidavits of intent as required by section 2-59, the city clerk shall certify such fact to the city council, which shall hold a meeting, and may cancel the election and by resolution declare the candidates elected; and, as permitted by C.R.S. § 31-10-507, said candidates shall be deemed elected. The city clerk shall publish notice of such cancellation, if possible, in order to inform the electors of the city, and notice of such cancellation shall be posted at each polling place and in not less than one other public place. 
(Code 2000, § 2-1-50; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 2-61-2-78. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CITY ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 2-79. - Compensation of elected officials. 
(a)  The city shall pay a salary in an amount to be established by the council from time to time. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this section shall apply or operate to violate the provisions of article XII, section 11 of the state constitution, wherein it is provided that the salary of any elected public officer shall not be increased or decreased during the term of office for which said public officer was elected. 
(Code 2000, § 2-2-10; Ord. No. 983, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-80. - Compensation of officers. 
    The officers of the city shall receive such compensation for their services as may be provided by resolution, charter, ordinance or statute, provided that the emoluments of no officer shall be increased or diminished during the term for which he or she shall have been elected or appointed. 
(Prior Code, § 2-1; Code 2000, § 2-2-20; Ord. No. 149, § 8) 
State Law reference- Emoluments not to be increased, C.R.S. § 31-4-405. 
Sec. 2-81. - Boards and commissions. 
    The city council shall create and appoint members to such boards and commissions as may now or hereafter exist, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Board of adjustment and appeals; 
(2)  Planning and zoning commission; 
(3)  Airport advisory board; 
(4)  Library advisory board; 
(5)  Parks and recreation advisory board; 
(6)  Tree advisory board; 
(7)  Utilities board; 
(8)  Victims and witnesses assistance and law enforcement board; 
(9)  Water advisory board; 
(10)  Youth services commission. 
(Code 2000, § 2-2-30; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-82. - Publications presented to city council. 
(a)  Reimbursement to city council. Commencing on February 25, 1976, the city clerk shall require persons requesting city council action requiring publications to pay to the city the anticipated cost of any publications of ordinances, public notices or otherwise, the estimated cost of the same to be fixed by the city clerk. 
(b)  Appeal of cost. If any person who requests action by the city council requiring publication disputes the amount required by the city clerk to be advanced, such person may appeal the decision of the city clerk to the city council at a regular city council meeting. 
(c)  Reimbursement to city attorney. If any person requests city council action requiring the services of the city attorney in drafting any such action, such person shall advance a reasonable fee, to be fixed by the city clerk and paid to the city attorney. 
(Prior Code, §§ 2-4-2-6; Code 2000, § 2-2-40; Ord. No. 686, §§ 1-3; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 2-83-2-107. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MUNICIPAL COURT 

Sec. 2-108. - Waiver of trial by jury. 
    In all trials before or in the municipal court, in cases arising under this Code or any other ordinances of the city wherein a defendant shall have the right to trial by jury, such defendant may waive trial by jury and proceed to trial by the court, in which event, the municipal judge shall record such waiver and proceed to try the case if the plea is one of not guilty. If the defendant is found guilty, the municipal judge shall fix or determine the punishment, penalty or sentence and render judgment upon such verdict for the punishment, penalty or sentence so determined, and costs. If the municipal judge shall find the defendant not guilty, the municipal judge shall record the same and discharge the defendant without costs. 
(Prior Code, § 8-4; Code 2000, § 2-3-10; Ord. No. 451, § 5; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-109. - Procedure under plea of guilty. 
    If any person accused of violating any of the provisions of this Code or any other ordinances of the city, having a right to trial by jury, shall plead guilty, the municipal judge, without a jury, shall hear the evidence and fix and determine the sentence penalty or punishment, together with costs, and the municipal judge shall enter judgment and issue execution thereon. 
(Prior Code, § 8-5; Code 2000, § 2-3-20; Ord. No. 451, § 6; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-110. - Summons of jurors. 
    In all trials before or in the municipal court in cases arising under this Code or any other ordinances of the city, or under the statutes and state constitution and the United States Constitution, wherein a defendant shall have the right to trial by jury, such defendant may demand a jury which shall consist of six jurors or a lesser number, not less than three, if the same is agreed upon by the city and the defendant, and thereupon, the municipal court or the municipal judge shall issue a venire for the jury, directed to any person authorized by ordinance or statute to serve writs or other processes issued in cases in the municipal court, which shall be substantially in the following form: 
    STATE OF COLORADO 
    CITY OF LAMAR ss. 
    COUNTY OF PROWERS 
    The People of the City of Lamar, Colorado, to ___________, greeting: 
    We command you to summon _____ persons of the City of Lamar, Colorado, to appear before me at _____, on the ___ day of ________, 20___, who are not of kin to _____, defendant, to make a jury between the City of Lamar, Colorado, and defendant _____, in a plea of not guilty to a charge of a violation of one or more ordinances of the City of Lamar; because the defendant has demanded trial by jury, and have you then and there the names of the jury, and this writ. 
    Witness my hand and seal, this ___ day of ________, 20___. 
    ___________(SEAL) 
    Municipal Judge 
(Prior Code, § 8-6; Code 2000, § 2-3-30; Ord. No. 451, § 1) 
Sec. 2-111. - Failure of prospective juror to answer summons. 
    In all cases where a person shall be summoned as a juror to try any case before the municipal court, and such person shall fail to attend at the time and place appointed in such summons, the municipal court shall have the power to issue an attachment, directed to any person authorized to serve warrants of arrest in cases in the municipal court, commanding him or her forthwith to bring before such court the body of such juror so failing to attend and to show cause why he or she should not be punished for contempt. Upon appearance of such juror on such attachment, it shall be lawful for such court or municipal judge to punish him or her for contempt or wholly discharge him or her if satisfactory excuse is made. 
(Prior Code, § 8-7; Code 2000, § 2-3-40; Ord. No. 451, § 2; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-112. - Empaneling of jury; discharge of jurors. 
    If any juror summoned to try any case before the municipal court shall be interested in the event of the case, shall be kin to a defendant, shall have expressed his or her opinion on the matter about to be tried or shall, for any cause to be judged by the municipal judge, be considered as a partial or improper juror, the municipal judge shall discharge such juror. When by such discharge or the failure of any juror to attend, the jury is not complete, the municipal judge shall direct any person authorized to serve writ or other process issued in cases in the municipal court to summon as many persons as shall be required to complete such jury, instantly, from among the bystanders or other persons in the city, which summons shall be verbal. The person so summoned shall be bound to serve on such jury, and on refusal or failure to do so, may be attached and punished for contempt in all cases arising under this Code or any other ordinances of the city wherein a jury trial is had. Each party shall be entitled to three peremptory challenges. 
(Prior Code, § 8-8; Code 2000, § 2-3-50; Ord. No. 451, § 3; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-113. - Rendering of judgment; determination of penalty. 
    Upon the return of a verdict of guilty by a jury in the municipal court, the municipal judge thereof shall record the same in the docket and shall proceed to fix or determine the punishment, penalty or sentence and render judgment upon such verdict for the punishment, penalty or sentence so determined and for costs. If the jury returns a verdict of not guilty, the municipal judge shall record the same and discharge the defendant without costs. 
(Prior Code, § 8-9; Code 2000, § 2-3-60; Ord. No. 451, § 4) 
Sec. 2-114. - Compensation of jurors; guilty defendant to be assessed jury costs. 
    Each juror or member of a jury panel who attends the municipal court shall receive compensation therefor, in an amount established by the city council. The cost of such jury and jury panel shall be assessed against the defendant in the event he or she is found guilty. 
(Prior Code, § 8-10; Code 2000, § 2-3-70; Ord. No. 451, § 7; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-115. - Costs and penalty procedures. 
(a)  The municipal judge is hereby authorized and directed to assess costs against any defendant who pleads guilty or nolo contendere, who enters into a plea agreement, or who, after trial, is found guilty of an ordinance violation. Said costs shall be as set forth in subsection (l) of this section. 
(b)  Jury trials in the municipal court are hereby authorized and are to be in conformity with the provisions of C.R.S. § 13-10-114. 
(c)  The municipal judge is empowered, in his or her discretion, to assess the actual costs and expenses of incarceration of any defendant ordered incarcerated by the municipal court against the defendant. Further, the municipal judge is empowered, in his or her discretion, to assess the actual costs and expenses incurred in the transportation of any defendant ordered incarcerated against the defendant, and in the instance of any juvenile defendant requiring transportation, against the parent or legal guardian of the juvenile defendant. 
(d)  The municipal judge is empowered, in his or her discretion, to order any defendant to perform useful public service, not to exceed 40 hours, upon conviction. The municipal court may cooperate with any public agency with respect to the oversight and supervision of the performance of such useful public service, and may assess actual costs and expenses associated therewith, against the defendant performing the same. 
(e)  The municipal court is empowered to sentence defendants to complete an approved driving school, an approved alcohol and drug abuse treatment program, or both. In the context of this authority, approved schools or programs shall be those that perform in a satisfactory manner as determined by the municipal judge. Costs and expenses with respect to any such school or program shall be borne by the defendant required to attend such programs. 
(f)  The police department is empowered to provide security for the municipal court in session upon request of the municipal judge, and when deemed necessary. 
(g)  Implementation of the provisions of this section shall be in conformity with the provisions of the Home Rule Charter, state statutes and any rules of procedure adopted by the state supreme court. 
(h)  The municipal court, in its sole discretion, may allow any convicted defendant to pay any fine, fee or cost imposed upon said conviction on a delayed basis, and the municipal court, in its discretion, may impose an additional time payment fee, as set forth in subsection (l) of this section, in any instance wherein the convicted defendant does not pay any such fines, fees or costs within 24 hours after conviction. 
(i)  In the event that any convicted defendant does not make timely payment of all fines, fees and costs ordered by the municipal court, upon conviction, the convicted defendant shall be liable for an additional fee as set forth in subsection (l) of this section, per payment not timely remitted unto the municipal court. 
(j)  In the event that any defendant does not appear before the municipal court as directed by summons, summons and complaint or order of the municipal court, the defendant shall, upon conviction, be liable for the payment of an additional fee for failure to appear imposed by the municipal court. 
(k)  The police department shall charge and collect a fee for service and return on each subpoena on each witness, plus mileage for each mile actually and necessarily traveled in service of the same, such fee to be as set forth in subsection (l) of this section; provided, however, that no such charge shall be imposed or collected for service of subpoena issued on behalf of the people of the city. 
(l)  The amount of any fees or costs referenced in this section shall be as established by the city council pursuant to recommendation by the municipal court judge, which amounts shall be maintained by the clerk. 
(Code 2000, § 2-3-80; Ord. No. 960, 1996; Ord. No. 980, §§ 1-4, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-116. - Local emergency management board (LEMB) established; composition. 
    The local emergency management board (LEMB) is hereby established, and shall consist of the following: 
(1)  The mayor, who shall be the chairperson. 
(2)  Such deputy directors and chiefs of operating disaster departments, services or divisions as are provided for by resolution, pursuant to this article. 
(3)  Such representatives of civic, business, labor, veterans', professional or other organizations having an official group or organization responsibility as may be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 7-3; Code 2000, § 2-5-30; Ord. No. 450, § 3; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-117. - Powers and duties. 
    The LEMB shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To review and recommend for adoption by the city council a local emergency operating plan (LEOP) and mutual aid plans and agreements, and such ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations as are necessary to implement such plans and agreements. 
(2)  To meet upon the call of the chairperson, or in his or her absence from the city or inability to call such meeting, upon the call of the designated emergency response authority (DERA). 
(Prior Code, § 7-4; Code 2000, § 2-5-40; Ord. No. 450, § 4; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-118. - Nonliability of certain persons. 
    No person owning, maintaining or controlling any building or premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants to the city a license or privilege or otherwise permits the city to inspect, designate and use the whole or any part of such building or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending, mock or practice attack, his or her successors in interest, or his or her agents or employees shall be subject to liability for injuries sustained by any person while in or upon such building or premises as a result of the condition of such building or premises or as a result of any act or omission in connection with the upkeep or maintenance thereof, except a willful act of misconduct, when such person has entered or gone into or upon such building or premises for the purpose of seeking refuge therein during destructive operations or attacks by enemies of the United States, or during a mock or practice attack or test ordered by lawful authority. 
(Prior Code, § 7-11; Code 2000, § 2-5-50; Ord. No. 450, § 12) 
Sec. 2-119. - Certain acts prohibited. 
    No person, during a disaster, shall: 
(1)  Willfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the LEMB in the enforcement of any lawful rule or regulation issued pursuant to this article, or in the performance of any duty imposed upon him or her by virtue of this article. 
(2)  Do any act prohibited by any lawful rules or regulations issued pursuant to this article, if such act is of such a nature as to give or be likely to give assistance to the enemy, to imperil the lives or property of inhabitants of the city, or to prevent, hinder or delay the defense or protection thereof. 
(Prior Code, § 7-12; Code 2000, § 2-5-60; Ord. No. 450, § 9; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 2-120-2-136. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-137-2-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - AIRPORT ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-156. - Creation of board. 
    There is hereby created a board to be known as the airport advisory board, hereinafter referred to in this division as the board. 
(Code 2000, § 2-6-10; Ord. No. 579, § I, 1968; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-157. - Membership qualifications; increase of membership. 
(a)  The board shall be composed of seven members, all of whom shall be at least 18 years of age, and shall be appointed by a majority of the entire city council. Members shall serve at the pleasure of the city council; provided, however, that one of said seven members shall be a duly qualified member of the city council and one of said seven members shall be a duly qualified county commissioner. No member of the board, either as an individual or an owner, employee, agent or representative of a company or organization, shall be a lessee of any part of the airport premises or of any concessionaire conducting business thereon. Notwithstanding the provisions of this subsection, a person shall not be precluded from being a member of the airport advisory board because that member has leased a portion of the airport premises to house aircraft. 
(b)  A vacancy shall exist on the board when a member's term on the board has expired or when any member dies, resigns or becomes unable to perform the functions of the office, and, in the case of the city council or board of county commissioners members, when said member shall cease to serve as a member of the city council or of the board of county commissioners. Upon such vacancy, the city council shall, within 30 days thereafter, by a majority vote of the entire city council, appoint a replacement to serve out the remainder of the term of the vacant office. All terms of members upon the board shall be for five years. 
(Code 2000, § 2-6-20; Ord. No. 579, § II, 1968; Ord. No. 889, § 1, 1991; Ord. No. 961, § 1, 1996; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1085, § 1, 2006) 
Sec. 2-158. - Powers and duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the board, within the limitations of the city Charter, this division and other applicable law, to develop, maintain, operate and supervise the Lamar Municipal Airport, and in order to carry out its duties, the board shall have the following powers, which may be further increased or limited by resolution passed by a majority of the entire city council: 
(1)  To organize and adopt such rules of procedure and bylaws as it shall deem necessary; 
(2)  During any one fiscal year, to spend, without prior city council approval, all or any lesser sum of the money budgeted to the board for such fiscal year; and 
(3)  To prescribe and enforce such rules and regulations as it deems necessary to properly carry out its duties hereunder. 
(Code 2000, § 2-6-40; Ord. No. 579, § IV, 1968) 
Sec. 2-159. - Limitations. 
    The board shall have no authority to: 
(1)  Bind the city on any oral or written contract, except for the expenditure of budgeted money as set forth in this division, unless it obtains prior city council approval; 
(2)  Violate, declare void or dishonor any binding agreement or obligation heretofore made or entered into by the city in connection with said airport; or 
(3)  Buy or sell any interest in real property, or dispose of any personal property without prior city council approval. 
(Code 2000, § 2-6-50; Ord. No. 579, § V, 1968; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-160. - Budget. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the board to present to the city council, no later than June 30 of each year, an estimate of its revenue for the ensuing year, and an estimate of its costs with respect to operation. 
(b)  Upon an adoption of a budget for the board for any given fiscal year, the city auditor and other appropriate officials are hereby authorized to honor all vouchers and expenditures by the board during said fiscal year, up to the total budget set, and without further city council action. 
(Code 2000, § 2-6-60; Ord. No. 579, § VI, 1968) 
Secs. 2-161-2-188. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PARKS AND RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-189. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a parks and recreation advisory board, hereinafter referred to in this division as the board, which board shall be composed of seven members appointed by the city council, which members shall be appointed for staggered terms of five years each, and until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(Code 2000, § 2-8-10; Ord. No. 981, § 1, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-190. - Continuation of present members. 
    Present members of the city recreation commission, at the time of the adoption of the ordinance from which this division is derived, shall continue to serve and carry out the functions, powers and duties of their offices for the remainder of their respective unexpired terms upon the commission, which commission is hereby transformed and changed into the parks and recreation advisory board. 
(Code 2000, § 2-8-20; Ord. No. 981, § 2, 1997) 
Sec. 2-191. - Reservation of seats.
