    One seat upon the board shall be reserved for a representative from the Lamar RE-2 School District, and one seat reserved for a representative from Lamar Community College. 
(Code 2000, § 2-8-30; Ord. No. 981, § 3, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-192. - Responsibilities and duties. 
    The advisory responsibilities of the board shall be as follows: 
(1)  To serve as an advisory body to the city council in the formation of parks and recreation policies designed to improve the quality of life of all users of parks and recreational facilities and programs, and to provide social, leisure and recreational activities for all persons of the community. 
(2)  To be aware of and responsive to the parks and recreation desires and needs of the community and its residents, and to work cooperatively with the city council and city staff to ensure that all such desires and needs are fulfilled, insofar as may be possible with respect to resources available. 
(3)  To be dedicated to the provision of parks and recreational facilities and opportunities to all users of parks and recreation facilities and programs. 
(4)  To exercise the express authority to waive fees at the Lamar Community Building for organized events or sponsors thereof. 
(5)  To exercise approval authority to name parks and recreational facilities and amenities. 
(Code 2000, § 2-8-40; Ord. No. 981, § 4, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-193. - General administration. 
    The board is expressly subject to the provisions of section 9-l of the Home Rule Charter. 
(Code 2000, § 2-8-50; Ord. No. 981, § 5, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 2-194-2-224. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TREE ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-225. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created and established a tree advisory board for the city, hereinafter referred to in this division as the board, which board shall consist of seven persons, being limited to residents of the county, and who shall be appointed by the city council. 
(Code 2000, § 2-9-10; Ord. No. 891, § 1, 1991; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-226. - Membership. 
(a)  Board members shall serve for three-year terms, with the initial appointments to the board being as follows: 
(1)  Three members for a one-year term each; 
(2)  Two members for a two-year term each; and 
(3)  Two members for a three-year term each. 
(b)  Members of the board shall serve staggered terms. 
(c)  If a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, a successor shall be appointed for the unexpired term. 
(d)  Members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 2000, § 2-9-20; Ord. No. 891, § 2, 1991; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-227. - Responsibilities and duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the board to study, investigate, counsel and develop plans for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting and removal of trees and shrubs upon public property, and, where consented to, private property. The board shall also serve in an advisory capacity in creating new designs for planting trees and shrubs for the city. All plans, recommendations, designs and expenditures of the board must be submitted to the city council for approval prior to the commencement of any board project. 
(Code 2000, § 2-9-30; Ord. No. 891, § 3, 1991; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-228. - General administration. 
    The board shall select its own officers, shall make its own rules, regulations and procedures and shall keep minutes of its proceedings. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. With consent of the city council, the board may consult with a forester in the performance of its duties. 
(Code 2000, § 2-9-40; Ord. No. 891, § 4, 1991; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-229. - Trees; planting and maintenance. 
    The board is hereby charged with the following additional duties: 
(1)  To develop and maintain a list of desirable trees for planting within the city in three size classes, being small, medium and large. 
(2)  To develop and maintain a list of trees not suitable for planting within southeast Colorado. 
(3)  To develop recommendatory guidelines concerning the spacing for plantings of trees, including distances by which trees should be separated from structures, other trees and plantings, and overhead and underground utilities. 
(4)  To develop and make recommendations concerning existing city ordinances pertaining to planting of trees, including the provisions of chapter 30. 
(5)  To develop guidelines concerning the care and maintenance of public trees, being those trees and other plantings now existing or hereinafter established upon public lands. 
(6)  To develop recommendatory guidelines and suggested practices concerning the pruning, removal and ordinary maintenance of trees and plantings of all kinds. 
(7)  To develop recommendatory guidelines concerning the treatment or removal of dead or diseased trees within the city in instances wherein such trees constitute a hazard to life or property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city. 
(8)  To educate and disseminate information to the public concerning all of the above. 
(Code 2000, § 2-9-50; Ord. No. 895, § 1, 1991; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 2-230-2-251. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - VICTIMS AND WITNESSES ASSISTANCE AND LAW ENFORCEMENT BOARD 

Sec. 2-252. - Creation. 
(a)  There is hereby established the victims and witnesses assistance and law enforcement board, hereinafter referred to in this division as the board. The board shall be composed of five members to be appointed by the city council. 
(b)  The terms of office of each member of the board shall be three years. All vacancies upon the board shall be filled by appointment by the city council. 
(c)  Members of the board shall receive no compensation. 
(d)  The chief of police shall serve as an advisory member of the board, but shall be a nonvoting member of the board. 
(e)  The board shall designate one of its members as chairperson, shall establish rules of procedure and order, and shall hold meetings as it might deem necessary. 
(Prior Code, § 2-7; Code 2000, § 2-10-10; Ord. No. 843, § 1; Ord. No. 956, § 1, 1995; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-253. - Assessment of surcharge. 
    A surcharge equal to 37 percent of the fine imposed for violation of all municipal ordinances, including ordinance violations under the model traffic code, is hereby levied on each municipal court action resulting in a conviction or in a deferred judgment and sentence, which violation is charged pursuant to city ordinances. All calculated surcharge amounts resulting in dollars and cents shall be rounded up to the nearest whole dollar. If a portion of the fine is suspended, a proportionate amount of this surcharge levied shall also be suspended. If the suspension of the fine is thereafter revoked, the surcharge shall be re-imposed on the total amount of the fine imposed. The surcharges shall be paid to the municipal court clerk by the defendant, and the clerk shall deposit the money so received in the fund hereinafter created. 
(Prior Code, § 2-8; Code 2000, § 2-10-20; Ord. No. 843, § 2; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-254. - Administration of surcharge. 
    The victims and witnesses assistance and law enforcement fund is hereby established in the office of the city treasurer, hereinafter referred to in this division as the fund. The fund shall consist of all monies paid as a surcharge, as provided in section 2-253. All monies deposited in the fund shall be deposited in an interest-bearing account, and all interest earned by monies in the fund shall be credited to the fund. At the conclusion of each fiscal year, all monies remaining in the fund shall remain in the fund for allocation, as hereinafter set forth. 
(Prior Code, § 2-9; Code 2000, § 2-10-30; Ord. No. 843, § 3; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-255. - Disbursement of funds. 
    The board shall disburse monies from the fund in the following manner: 
(1)  First, to the payment of all reasonable and necessary expenses and costs incurred by the board in the performance of its duties, including, but not limited to, professional fees, office supplies and meeting expenses. 
(2)  Second, not in excess of 25 percent of the net aggregate of the fund remaining after the deduction of reasonable expenses and costs shall be allocated for the purchase of victims and witnesses services and reimbursements, as hereinafter set forth. 
(3)  Third, any remaining monies may be allocated to the police department for the following purposes, including, but not limited to, purchase of equipment, training programs and additional personnel. Such funds shall not be used by the police department for defraying the costs of routine and ongoing operating expenses. 
(Prior Code, § 2-10; Code 2000, § 2-10-40; Ord. No. 843, § 4) 
Sec. 2-256. - Purpose of disbursement. 
    Disbursement of funds by the board on behalf of victims and witnesses assistance services may be used for the following purposes: 
(1)  Provision of services for early crisis intervention; 
(2)  Assistance in the prompt return of a victim's property; 
(3)  Assistance to victims and witnesses in arranging transportation to and from court; 
(4)  Provision of translator services; 
(5)  Protection from threats of harm and other forms of intimidation; 
(6)  Reasonable medical and hospital expenses and expenses incurred for dentures, eyeglasses, hearing aids or other prosthetic or medically necessary devices; and 
(7)  Losses resulting from property damage, including repair or replacement of property damaged as a result of crime or payment of the deductible amount on a residential or motor vehicle insurance policy in an amount not to exceed $250.00. Victims' recovery due to property damage shall not exceed $250.00 for any crime, but in no case shall a loss be compensable if the aggregate property damages are less than $25.00. 
(Prior Code, § 2-11; Code 2000, § 2-10-50; Ord. No. 843, § 5; Ord. No. 941, § 1, 1994) 
Sec. 2-257. - Applications for disbursement. 
    The board is authorized to accept and evaluate all applications for disbursement of funds, whether emanating from victims, witnesses or the police department. Applications for disbursement shall be made upon forms prescribed by the board, and made available by the police department. The board shall establish its own criteria for evaluating applications for disbursement, and nothing herein contained shall obligate the board to make disbursement of any funds available to it. Upon a finding by the board that a disbursement shall be made from the fund, the board shall submit a written request for payment to the city clerk, who shall then remit payment in accordance with the request. 
(Prior Code, § 2-12; Code 2000, § 2-10-60; Ord. No. 843, § 6) 
Secs. 2-258-2-277. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - WATER ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-278. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a water advisory board for the city, hereinafter referred to in this division as the board. The present members of the de facto water advisory board heretofore in existence are hereby reappointed and affirmed in like manner as the original appointment to said board was performed. 
(Code 2000, § 2-11-10; Ord. No. 865, § 1, 1989; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-279. - Membership; appointment. 
(a)  The board shall consist of five citizen-at-large members, to be appointed for a five-year term, and all provisions of said appointments shall be subject to section 9-1 of the Home Rule Charter. 
(b)  A member of the city council shall also be appointed by the mayor to serve as an ex officio member of the board without voting privileges. The city administrator, public works director, water and sewer supervisor and city attorney shall attend meetings of the board as required. 
(Code 2000, § 2-11-20; Ord. No. 865, § 2, 1989; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-280. - Purpose. 
    The board shall be advisory and recommendatory to the city council, and shall concern itself with the following matters: 
(1)  To develop, adopt, revise and continually update policy directed toward long-range planning for the development and conservation of adequate raw water supply for the city, including annexations, subdivisions and replats. 
(2)  To develop procedures for the transfer of water rights appurtenant to lands being annexed, subdivided or replatted, if the same should be in the best interest of the city. 
(3)  Upon request by the city council, to review annexations, subdivisions and replats, and recommend to the city council as to the adequacy of water rights, if any, to be transferred, and adequacy of water supply with respect to said annexations, subdivisions and replats. 
(4)  Upon request by the city council, to review all requests for city water supply to service areas outside the city, including extra-territorial water and/or sewer taps, and to make appropriate recommendations upon said subjects to the city council. 
(5)  Upon request by the city council, to review all matters, including pollution, concerning the raw water supply of the city. 
(6)  To recommend to the city council as to the uses, purchase or sale of any water rights affecting the water supply of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 2-11-30; Ord. No. 865, § 3, 1989; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-281. - Selection of officers; procedures. 
(a)  The board shall choose its own chairperson and other necessary officers from its citizens-at-large members, and shall adopt its own rules of procedure for the proper conduct of its business. 
(b)  Minutes of all board meetings shall be prepared and distributed on a timely basis to all board members and city councilmembers. 
(c)  Board meeting dates shall be established by the board. 
(Code 2000, § 2-11-40; Ord. No. 865, § 4, 1989; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 2-282-2-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - YOUTH SERVICES COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-311. - Establishment. 
    There is hereby established a youth services commission, hereinafter referred to in this division as the commission. 
(Code 2000, § 2-12-10; Ord. No. 985, § 1, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-312. - Duties. 
    The purpose of the commission is to be an advisory body to the city council, dealing with, considering and making recommendations with respect to all manner of issues which affect the youth of the city, including, but not limited to, recreational issues and programs, youth crime, library services, teen counseling and activities, teen employment opportunities and the like. While it is intended that the commission shall be a city council advisory body and operated as such, it is also contemplated, and the commission is encouraged, to be alert to opportunities to cooperate with other governmental entities, including the RE-2 School District and the county, by way of example, for the purpose of consideration of youth-related issues. 
(Code 2000, § 2-12-20; Ord. No. 985, § 2, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-313. - Composition of commission. 
    The commission shall be composed of seven youth members, one sitting member of city council and one city staff member, all of whom shall be appointed by the city council. Youth members shall be the voting members of the commission, with the city councilmember and city staff member being liaison members only and having no vote on the commission. Youth members shall be between the ages of 14 and 18 years, and shall serve for two-year terms; however, when an appointed youth attains the age of 18 years during his or her term, the member's tenure shall terminate, whereupon the city council shall appoint a replacement member for the remaining term of the terminated member. Initial appointments of youth members shall be on a staggered basis so as to provide for overlapping terms, in the interest of continuity of members, i.e., five initial members of the commission now appointed shall continue serving for the term of appointment, two members to be newly appointed shall serve for one-year terms, and two members also to be newly appointed shall be appointed for two-year terms. 
(Code 2000, § 2-12-30; Ord. No. 985, § 3, 1997; Ord. No. 996, § 3, 1998; Ord. No. 1014, § 1, 1999; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 2-314. - Conduct of commission. 
    No member of the commission shall receive compensation for service, but members of the commission may be reimbursed necessary expenses actually incurred in the discharge of duties. All members shall be subject to removal by the city council at its pleasure and at any time without cause. The commission shall choose its own chairperson and vice-chairperson, and shall adopt rules of procedure. 
(Code 2000, § 2-12-40; Ord. No. 985, § 4, 1997) 
Secs. 2-315-2-331. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - LAMAR COMMUNITY RESOURCE AND SENIOR CENTER ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-332. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a city community resource and senior center advisory board, hereinafter referred to in this division as the board, which board shall be composed of six members appointed by the city council, and which members shall be appointed for staggered terms of five years each and until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
(Code 2000, § 2-14-10; Ord. No. 1039, 2001) 
Sec. 2-333. - Term and vacancy provisions. 
    The original board shall be appointed for terms as follows: two for a five-year term, one for a four-year term, one for a three-year term, one for a two-year term and one for a one-year term. Subsequent to the original appointments, each board member shall be appointed to a term of five years. Vacancies on the board shall exist when any member dies, resigns or becomes physically unable to perform the functions of his or her office. Upon such vacancy, the city council shall, within 30 days thereafter, by majority vote of the council, appoint a replacement to serve out the remainder of the term of the vacated office. 
(Code 2000, § 2-14-20; Ord. No. 1039, 2001) 
Sec. 2-334. - Reservation of seats. 
    One seat upon the board shall be reserved for a representative chosen by the city. One seat upon the board shall be reserved for a representative chosen by the Prowers County Commission. One seat shall be reserved for a representative chosen by Southeastern Colorado Economic Development. Three seats on the board shall be reserved for representatives chosen by the Lamar Senior Citizens, Inc. 
(Code 2000, § 2-14-30; Ord. No. 1039, 2001) 
Sec. 2-335. - Responsibilities and duties. 
    The advisory responsibilities of the board shall be as follows: 
(1)  To serve as an advisory board to the city council in the use, regulation and care of the Lamar Community Resource and Senior Center. 
(2)  To serve as an advisory board to the city council for the development or revision of policies and procedures designed to improve the quality of life of all users of the facility and participants in the programs and activities occurring within or at the facility. 
(3)  To be aware of and responsive to the desires and needs of the public and community as related to the use of the Lamar Community Resource and Senior Center, and to work cooperatively with the city council and city staff to ensure that all such desires and needs are fulfilled, insofar as may be possible with respect to the available resources. 
(4)  To be dedicated to the provision of a community resource and senior facility and related opportunities for use by the public. 
(5)  To exercise the express authority to waive fees at the Lamar Community Resource and Senior Center as established by resolution adopted by the city council. 
(6)  To exercise decisions approving or denying use of the Lamar Community Resource and Senior Center as established by resolution adopted by the city council. 
(7)  To conduct an annual review of any operation plan and/or fee schedule adopted for use of the Lamar Community Resource and Senior Center and make recommendations to the city council as to changes to said plans or fees. 
(Code 2000, § 2-14-40; Ord. No. 1039, 2001) 
Secs. 2-336-2-358. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - LAMAR HISTORIC PRESERVATION ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-359. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to promote the public health, safety and welfare through: 
(1)  The protection and preservation of the historic and cultural heritage of the city by providing for the designation of historic buildings, landmarks, sites and districts (collectively referred to hereinafter as historic sites) in accordance with this article; 
(2)  The enhancement of property values and the stabilization of historic neighborhoods, sites of historical events and the like; 
(3)  The increase of economic and financial benefits as a result of the attraction of tourists and visitors to the city; and 
(4)  The provisions of educational opportunities to increase public appreciation of the city's unique heritage. 
(Code 2000, § 2-15-10; Ord. No. 1042, 2002) 
Sec. 2-360. - Board established. 
(a)  Creation. An historic preservation advisory board is hereby created, to be known as the city's historic preservation advisory board (the board), which shall have principal responsibility for matters of historic preservation as set forth in subsection (i) of this section. 
(b)  Membership. The board shall consist of five members from the city and may include the surrounding area. 
(c)  Appointments and terms of office. Members of the board shall be appointed by the city council and shall serve three-year terms. The city council shall give reasonable opportunity to interested parties to nominate individuals to serve as members of the board. The initial terms for members shall be one member for a one-year term, two members for a two-year term, and two members for a three-year term. 
(d)  Vacancies. The foregoing provisions notwithstanding, any duly appointed member of the board shall continue to serve until the member's successor has been appointed. Members may be appointed to serve successive terms without limitation. Appointments to fill vacancies on the board shall be made by the city council; provided, however, that prior to the appointment of board members to fill vacancies for board members whose terms are ending, the city council shall give reasonable opportunity to interested parties along with the board to nominate individuals to serve as members of the board. 
(e)  Compensation removal. All members of the board shall serve without compensation except for such amounts determined appropriate by the city council to offset expenses incurred by board members in the performance of their duties as board members. All members of the board shall serve at the pleasure of the city council and may be removed by the city council at any time with or without cause. 
(f)  Quorum and voting. A quorum for the board shall consist of a majority of the members of the board, excluding vacant seats. A quorum is necessary for the board to hold a meeting or to take official action. A roll call vote shall be taken upon the request of any member. A tie vote shall be deemed denial of the motion or recommended action. 
(g)  Officers. The board shall, by majority vote, elect one of its members to serve as chairperson to preside over the board's meetings and one member to serve as secretary. The members so designated shall serve in these capacities for terms of one year and may serve successive terms. 
(h)  Meetings. The board shall hold at least one regularly scheduled meeting per calendar quarter, or as necessary to take action on pending matters. Minutes shall be kept of all board meetings. The board shall comply with all requirements of the Open Public Meetings Act (C.R.S. §§ 24-6-401 and 24-6-402 et seq.) applicable to local public bodies as defined in that Act. 
(i)  Powers and duties. 
(1)  The board shall: 
a.  Review applications for designation of sites as being historic pursuant to this division and make recommendations to the city council as to whether the city council should, by resolution, designate the site described in the application for such designation based upon the criteria established in section 2-361 and any subsequent amendments thereto. 
b.  As needed, review the criteria for designation of historic sites set forth in section 2-361 and make recommendations to the city council for amendments thereto which the board believes appropriate or necessary. 
(2)  In addition to the above duties, the board may, at its discretion: 
a.  Advise and assist owners of historic properties on the physical and financial aspects of preservation, renovation, rehabilitation and reuse, including nomination to the Colorado Register of Historic Properties and National Register of Historic Places. 
b.  Develop and assist in public education programs including, but not limited to, walking tours, brochures, a marker program of historic properties, lectures and conferences. 
c.  Conduct surveys of historic sites for the purpose of defining those of historic significance and prioritizing the importance of identified historic sites. 
d.  Advise the city council on matters related to preserving the historic character of the city. 
e.  Pursue financial assistance for preservation-related programs. 
f.  Perform duties or functions as assigned by the city council. 
(j)  Rules and procedures for board. The board may establish additional rules of operation that are consistent with its duties as enumerated herein. 
(Code 2000, § 2-15-20; Ord. No. 1042, 2002; Ord. No. 1215, 12-27-2016) 
Sec. 2-361. - Criteria for designation of historic sites. 
(a)  In order to qualify for designation as an historic site pursuant to this division, the site must be determined to have historic significance due to one or more of the following factors: 
(1)  Its character, interest or value as part of the development, heritage or cultural characteristics of the City of Lamar, County of Prowers, State of Colorado or the United States of America. 
(2)  Its location as a site of a significant historic event. 
(3)  Its identification with a person who significantly contributed to the culture and development of the City of Lamar, County of Prowers, State of Colorado or the United States of America. 
(4)  Its exemplification of the cultural, economic, social or historic heritage of the City of Lamar, County of Prowers, State of Colorado or the United States of America. 
(5)  Its portrayal of the environment of a group of people in an era of history characterized by a distinctive architectural style. 
(6)  Its embodiment of distinguishing characteristics of an architectural type or specimen. 
(7)  Its identification as the work of an architect or master builder whose individual work has influenced the development of the City of Lamar, County of Prowers, State of Colorado or the United States of America. 
(8)  Its embodiment of elements of architectural design, detail, materials or craftsmanship that represent a significant architectural innovation. 
(9)  Its relation to other distinctive areas that are eligible for preservation according to a plan based on an historic, cultural or architectural motif. 
(10)  Its unique location or singular physical characteristic representing an established and familiar visual feature of a neighborhood, community or the city. 
(11)  Its potential to make important contributions to the understanding and knowledge of the area's history or pre-history. 
(b)  And in addition, if the site seeking designation comprises a district, it must be geographically definable. 
(Code 2000, § 2-15-30; Ord. No. 1042, 2002; Ord. No. 1215, 12-27-2016) 
Sec. 2-362. - Designation of historic sites. 
(a)  Recommendation for designation of historic sites. Pursuant to the procedures hereinafter set forth in this section, the board may, by written recommendation to the city council, propose the designation as an historic site of any building, landmark, site or district meeting the criteria set forth in section 2-361, as amended from time to time. Each such designation recommendation shall include a description of the characteristics of the site which justify its designation and shall include a legal description of the location and boundaries of the historic site. The designation recommendation may also indicate alterations which would have a significant impact upon, or be potentially detrimental to, the historic features of the site. Any such designation shall be in furtherance of and in conformance with the purposes and standards of this section. 
(b)  Notification requirements. The site included in any such designation shall be subject to the notification requirements set forth in section 2-365. 
(c)  Procedures for designating historic sites for preservation. Applications for designation must be made to the board. The board may require that such application be made in such form as specified by the board. Application shall be made only by the owners of 100 percent of the historic site for which an application is submitted. If the site to be considered is a district, written consent must be demonstrated from at least 70 percent of all property owners within the proposed district. 
(1)  Board review. The board shall review the application for conformance with the criteria for designation established in section 2-361, as it may be amended, and with the purposes of this section. The board shall consider the application at a regularly scheduled or special meeting. The board shall approve, modify and approve, or disapprove the application. The board shall notify the city administrator within seven days of any decision approving or disapproving an application. 
(2)  City council action. Unless an application is withdrawn by the applicant within 60 days of the date on which the city council is advised of any decision of the board recommending approval or disapproval of an application, the city council shall approve, modify and approve, or disapprove the proposed designation. The city council shall advise the board of its decision regarding the designation. 
(3)  Recordation. Within 30 days of designation approval by the city council, such designation will be recorded with the county register of deeds. 
(Code 2000, § 2-15-40; Ord. No. 1042, 2002; Ord. No. 1215, 12-27-2016) 
Sec. 2-363. - Limitation on resubmission and reconsideration of proposed designations. 
    Whenever the board or city council disapproves an application for designation of an historic site, no person shall submit an application that is the same or substantially the same for at least six months from the effective date of the final city action on the original application. 
(Code 2000, § 2-15-50; Ord. No. 1042, 2002) 
Sec. 2-364. - Amendment of designation. 
    Designation of an historic site may be amended to add features or property to the site under the procedures prescribed in section 2-362 for initial designations. 
(Code 2000, § 2-15-60; Ord. No. 1042, 2002) 
Sec. 2-365. - Notification. 
    Any owner filing an application for designation of property under this article shall, as a part of the application, agree to notify the board of the owner's intentions to alter, demolish, move or remove the site subject to the application at least 30 days prior to undertaking any such work. Any such owner shall be responsible for notifying any subsequent purchaser of the property of this notification requirement and the board may revoke the designation of the site hereunder unless the subsequent purchaser agrees in writing to the provisions of this section. The board shall review work associated with such notification for adherence to the Secretary of the Interior's standards for the treatment of historic properties and provide comments to the owner to encourage work in keeping with the intent and spirit of these standards. 
(Code 2000, § 2-15-70; Ord. No. 1042, 2002; Ord. No. 1215, 12-27-2016) 
Sec. 2-366. - Revocation of designation. 
    If a building or special feature on a designated site has changed or been altered in such a way as to negate the features necessary to retain designation, the owner may apply to the board for a revocation of the designation, or the board shall recommend revocation of the designation to the city council in the absence of the owner's application to do so. 
(Code 2000, § 2-15-80; Ord. No. 1042, 2002; Ord. No. 1215, 12-27-2016) 
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means any live vertebrate creature, domestic or wild, except human beings. 
    Animal control officer means any person who is employed by the city and authorized by the chief of police to administer and enforce this chapter. 
    Animal shelter means a facility operated by the city, or with which the city may contract, for the purpose of impounding and caring for animals. 
    At large. An animal shall be deemed to be running at large when off or away from the premises of the owner, possessor, keeper or lessee, and not under control thereof. An animal shall also be deemed to be running at large when not under control on the common grounds of condominiums, townhomes, apartment complexes and mobile home parks. 
    Circus means a commercial variety show featuring animal acts for public entertainment. 
    Control. An animal shall be construed to be under control of a person as follows: 
(1)  Confinement within a vehicle, fencing or other adequate enclosure where the animal has no access to passersby; 
(2)  Attachment to a leash not over six feet in length and held by a person of sufficient size and strength to restrain the animal; or 
(3)  Tethered on the premises of its owner, possessor, keeper or lessee such that it does not have access to passersby on a public street, sidewalk or right-of-way. 
Nothing herein shall restrict the ordinary uses of Seeing Eye and hearing-aid animals. 
    Humane manner means care of an animal, including, but not limited to, adequate heat, ventilation, sanitary shelter and wholesome food and water, consistent with the normal requirements and feeding habits of the animal's size, species and breed. 
    Kennel means any establishment or dwelling unit kept or being used for the purpose of keeping, boarding, breeding, buying, selling, grooming, letting for hire or engaging in the training of animals. 
    Leash or lead means a thong, cord, rope, chain or similar device which holds an animal in restraint and which is not more than six feet in length. 
    Neighborhood means the area within 500 feet of the exterior boundaries of the property where the animal is kept. 
    Owner means any person, partnership, corporation or association owning any animal, or having the same in his or her care, custody or control, or who causes, encourages or suffers the same to remain upon his or her premises for a period of more than three days. 
    Performing animal exhibition means any spectacle, display, act or event other than a circus in which performing animals are used. 
    Pet means any animal customarily kept for pleasure, rather than for utility. 
    Pit bull means any pit bull that is an American pit bull terrier, American Staffordshire terrier, Staffordshire bull terrier, or any pit bull displaying the physical traits of any one or more of the above breeds, or any pit bull exhibiting those distinguishing characteristics that conform to the standards established by the American Kennel Club (AKC) or United Kennel Club (UKC) for any of the above breeds. 
    Premises means real property owned, rented, leased, used, kept or occupied by a person. 
    Rabies vaccination means the inoculation of an animal with a rabies vaccine approved by the state department of health. 
    Restraint means physical control by use of a lead or leash. 
    Trap means any device used to contain or capture an animal. 
    Veterinary hospital means any premises upon which a licensed veterinarian performs surgery, makes diagnoses and treats diseases of, and injuries to, animals. 
    Vicious animal means an animal that bites or attacks human beings or other animals or in a vicious or terrorizing manner attacks or approaches in an attitude of attack upon a person upon any street, sidewalk, alley or other place or ground, except when in reasonable defense of persons. A dog kept or possessed for protection or security purposes which, by its nature or training, would otherwise come under the foregoing provision shall not be deemed vicious so long as it is securely confined in an enclosure or securely attached to a chain, rope or cord of sufficient size and strength to reasonably secure the animal and keep it physically segregated from persons other than its owner, custodian or possessor. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-10; Ord. No. 859, § 4-1, 1988; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1196, §§ 1, 2, 2015) 
Sec. 4-2. - Fees. 
(a)  Generally. All fees established herein are subject to revision by the chief of police or city administrator, and approval by the city council. 
(b)  Adoption. Any person adopting a dog from the animal shelter shall pay a fee as established by the city council. 
(c)  Euthanasia. Any owner of any animal for which a request for euthanasia has been made may pay a fee as established by the city council. Such owner shall submit written verification of ownership of the animal to be euthanized. 
(d)  Impoundment. Any person claiming an animal from the animal shelter or other location of impoundment shall pay a fee as established by the city council, and any other costs of examination, testing and treatment which may reasonably be incurred for the care of the animal. The fees and costs shall be paid when and how more specifically provided herein, or as otherwise required by law. 
(e)  Duration of license. The license provided for by this chapter shall remain in effect for the duration of the registered owner's ownership of the dog. 
(f)  Replacement tag. Any person requesting a replacement tag shall pay a fee as established by the city council for each tag requested. 
(g)  Quarantine. The owner of any animal quarantined pursuant to this chapter shall pay a fee as established by the city council for each day the animal is held in the animal shelter. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-20; Ord. No. 859, § 4-7, 1988; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1150, § 1, 2010) 
Secs. 4-3-4-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSING AND VACCINATIONS 

Sec. 4-23. - License required. 
(a)  No person shall, without obtaining a city license therefor, own, keep or harbor any dog over six months of age. 
(b)  This article shall not apply to kennels, veterinary hospitals, pet shops, educational facilities, laboratories, properly licensed commercial establishments and animals kept in connection with farming operations. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-200; Ord. No. 859, § 4-3, 1988; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 4-24. - Deadline for application. 
    An applicant for a dog license shall apply for said license within five days of becoming the owner of any such dog, or immediately after such dog is brought into the city. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-210; Ord. No. 859, § 4-3, 1988) 
Sec. 4-25. - Application; where to file; contents. 
(a)  An applicant for a dog license shall apply to the police department or such other locations as designated by the city council. 
(b)  Such application shall be upon forms provided by the city and shall contain at least the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the owner; 
(2)  The call name, breed, age, color and sex of the dog, and information to properly identify the dog, including microchipping and tattooing information; 
(3)  The signature of the owner attesting to the ownership of the dog. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-220; Ord. No. 859, § 4-3, 1988) 
Sec. 4-26. - Proof of vaccination. 
    Any owner applying for a dog license shall obtain a certificate of rabies vaccination from a licensed veterinarian. Said certificate shall accompany the application for license, unless otherwise provided by this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-240; Ord. No. 859, § 4-3, 1988) 
Sec. 4-27. - Certificate of vaccination. 
    The certificate of vaccination required by this article shall contain: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the owner of the vaccinated dog; 
(2)  The date of vaccination and the type of rabies vaccine used; 
(3)  The date of expiration of the vaccination; and 
(4)  The breed, age, color and sex and any identifying information of the vaccinated dog. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-250; Ord. No. 859, § 4-3, 1988) 
Sec. 4-28. - Dog tag requirements. 
(a)  Upon acceptance of the completed license application, the police department shall issue a durable tag stamped with an identifying number and year of issuance. 
(b)  The owner or custodian shall attach the tag to the collar or harness of the dog so licensed. Said collar or harness shall be worn by such dog at all times that it is outside the owner's premises. 
(c)  A duplicate tag may be obtained upon payment of the required replacement tag fee, as described in section 4-2(f). 
(d)  The police department shall maintain a record of all tags issued according to this article, and such record may be inspected by the public at reasonable hours, but in such a manner as not to interfere unduly with the regular business of the office. 
(Code 2000, §§ 7-6-260-7-6-280; Ord. No. 859, § 4-3, 1988; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 4-29. - License revocation or suspension; exceptions. 
    Upon conviction of violation of this chapter, or a plea of guilty or nolo contendere to a violation of this chapter, the city may revoke the license and require the violator to dispose or sell all animals owned, kept or harbored by the violator. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-290; Ord. No. 859, § 4-3, 1988; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 4-30-4-46. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - VIOLATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Cruelty to animals, C.R.S. § 18-9-201 et seq. 

Sec. 4-47. - Abandonment. 
    It is unlawful to leave any animal unattended for more than 48 consecutive hours without providing for humane care of said animal. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-600; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988) 
Sec. 4-48. - Cruelty. 
    It is unlawful to engage or permit any activity that constitutes cruelty to animals as provided in C.R.S. § 18-9-202; no person shall torment, overload, overwork or otherwise abuse an animal; or cause, instigate or permit any dogfight, cockfight, bullfight or other combat between animals, or between animals and human beings. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-610; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988) 
State Law reference- Cruelty to animals, C.R.S. § 18-9-201; animal fighting, penalty, C.R.S. § 18-9-204. 
Sec. 4-49. - Confining in vehicle. 
(a)  It is unlawful to confine any animal within a parked, closed vehicle without allowing cross-ventilation to prevent the animal from suffering heat exhaustion, heat stroke or death. 
(b)  Under no circumstances shall any person confine any animal in a parked, closed vehicle on any public street, alley or parking lot for a period exceeding 30 minutes. 
(c)  Any animal control officer or police officer observing any animal kept in violation of this article may enter the vehicle and impound such animal to protect its well-being. Any officer making entry into a vehicle for the purposes of this article shall leave written notice in the vehicle informing the animal owner of the impoundment of said animal. 
(d)  Any officer making entry into a vehicle for purposes of this article shall be immune from suit or liability, criminal or civil, for, caused by, or arising out of such entry. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-620; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988) 
Sec. 4-50. - Disturbing peace and quiet. 
(a)  No owner of an animal in the city shall permit such animal to disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood by barking, whining, howling or making any other noise in a continuous or excessive manner. 
(b)  No owner of any animal in the city shall permit such animal to interfere with the sleep of any person of ordinary sensibilities between sunset and sunrise by barking, whining, howling or making any other noise in an excessive or continuous manner. 
(c)  The animal control officer or police officer has authority, without liability, to use all reasonable means to abate such violation, including the authority to impound such animal upon receipt of a signed complaint when the owner is absent from the premises; provided, however, that this authority does not extend to entering the owner's dwelling or other buildings upon the owner's premises. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-630; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988) 
Sec. 4-51. - Animals. 
    It is unlawful for any person to use, keep, have in his or her possession or harbor any domesticated animals which, by frequent or habitual howling, barking, meowing, squawking or otherwise, shall cause annoyance or disturbance to persons in the neighborhood; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to hospitals licensed for the treatment of small animals or to premises occupied or used by the city animal shelter. 
(Code 2000, § 10-9-40; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 4-52. - Enclosures; prohibited to open. 
    It is unlawful to, in any manner, open directly or indirectly or aid or assist in opening any pen, fence or other enclosure with intent of releasing any animal confined therein, or to create an opening, which opening will permit the release of the animal so confined without the authorization of the owner or custodian of such animal. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-640; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988) 
Sec. 4-53. - Misrepresentation of license application. 
    It is unlawful for any person applying for a city dog license to knowingly make any material misrepresentation in the license application. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-660; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988) 
Sec. 4-54. - Tags; prohibited use. 
    It is unlawful for any person to use or permit the use of a license tag for an animal other than the animal for which such tag was duly issued. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-670; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988) 
Sec. 4-55. - Poison exposure. 
(a)  It is unlawful to expose any known poisonous substance, whether mixed with food or not, so that a reasonable person would know or should know that such substance would probably cause animals to be attracted thereto, eat thereof and be poisoned thereby. 
(b)  This article does not prohibit the poisoning of rats or mice with commercial rat poison mixed with vegetable substances, or poisoning conducted by or under the direction of state or federal wildlife officials. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-680; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988) 
Sec. 4-56. - Releasing from restraint. 
    It is unlawful to, without the consent of the owner, release any animal from restraint or confinement, except when necessary to preserve the life of such animal, provided that when an animal is released under such necessity, the person making such release shall immediately inform an animal control officer or the police department that he or she has done so, and if possible, immediately return the animal to the owner. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-700; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988) 
State Law reference- Unauthorized release of certain animals, C.R.S. § 18-9-206. 
Sec. 4-57. - Running at large. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any owner, possessory keeper or lessee of any animal to fail to prevent the same from running at large. Any animal found running at large may be impounded by an animal control officer or police officer, as provided herein. 
(b)  It is lawful for any officer to go upon any property, using such force as may be reasonably necessary, for the purpose of pursuing and capturing any animal running at large for the purpose of securing and/or impounding the animal pursuant to this chapter. 
(c)  If any animal is found at any place within the city other than upon the premises of the owner, and not under control, the owner is presumed to have violated this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-720; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988) 
Sec. 4-58. - Taking without permission. 
    It is unlawful for any person to take and deliver to the animal shelter or elsewhere any animal not his or her own unless first receiving written permission from the lawful owner of such animal, unless authorized by this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-730; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988) 
Sec. 4-59. - Inhumane trap setting; exceptions. 
(a)  It is unlawful to set any type of steel-jawed trap or any other inhumane trap which, by its nature, may kill or maim any animal or human being. 
(b)  This section does not prohibit the use of common rat or mouse traps or traps set by, or under the direction of, state or federal wildlife officials. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-740; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988) 
Sec. 4-60. - Vicious animals prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall own, keep, harbor or possess any vicious animal in the city, except as provided by this article. 
(b)  An animal is not a vicious animal because it has bitten or attacked any or all of the following persons: 
(1)  Any person engaged in the unlawful entry into or upon the animal owner's premises where the animal is kept; 
(2)  Any person engaged in the unlawful entry into the animal owner's vehicle wherein such animal is confined; 
(3)  Any person engaged in attempting to stop a fight between such animal and another animal; 
(4)  Any person engaged in attempting to aid such animal when it is injured. 
(c)  For the purpose of this section, a person is lawfully upon the private property of such owner when he or she is on the property in the performance of any duty imposed upon him or her by the laws of the state or the city, or the law or postal regulations of the United States, or when he or she is on such property at the invitation, expressed or implied, of the owner thereof. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-760; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988) 
State Law reference- City may adopt non-breed-specific dangerous dog controls, C.R.S. § 18-9-204.5. 
Sec. 4-61. - Vicious animals; warnings and criminal charges. 
(a)  When an animal control officer or police officer of the city deems an animal to be vicious, he or she shall issue a written warning to the owner of said animal, stating his or her determination that such animal is vicious, or he or she may cause charges to be filed as provided by C.R.S. § 18-9-204.5. 
(b)  In the event the municipal court finds that the evidence supports a charge made that an animal is vicious, the municipal judge may order, in addition to the penalties provided in C.R.S. § 18-9-204.5, that the owner be prohibited from keeping such animal within the city limits. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-770; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
State Law reference- Unlawful ownership of dangerous dogs, C.R.S. § 18-9-204.5. 
Sec. 4-62. - Kennels unlawful; limitation on number of dogs kept. 
(a)  Limit. It is unlawful for any person to keep or maintain more than three dogs within the city. It is also unlawful for any person to operate a kennel within the city. 
(b)  Keeping defined. As used herein, the keeping of dogs includes the ownership, possession, care, custody, control or maintenance of a dog. 
(c)  Exemptions. Veterinary clinics, pet stores, dog groomers and circuses are exempt from the provisions of this section. Members of a dog rescue organization who are assisting the rescue organization by temporarily keeping one or more dogs until a proper, permanent home can be found for the animals may temporarily keep these dogs (which are available for adoption), in addition to as many as three dogs which are owned or otherwise kept by the members; provided, however, that the rescue organization is recognized and approved by the chief of police. 
(d)  Grandfather provision. Any person keeping or maintaining more than three dogs at the time of the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived may register his or her nonconforming status with the police department and may continue to keep and maintain those particular dogs during the dogs' lifetime; provided, however, that each of these dogs must be legally licensed at the time of registration and must remain licensed during its entire grandfather period. Any owner who fails to register within 90 days of the adoption of said ordinance from which this article is derived loses the right to keep and maintain more than three dogs. In the event that a grandfathered dog dies or otherwise is no longer kept or maintained within the city, its owner may not replace the dog. It is the intention of this provision that eventually all grandfathered dogs will, at the conclusion of their natural lifetimes, result in all owners being in compliance with the limitations imposed by this section. If an owner fails to maintain proper licensing, that owner will also lose grandfather status in regard to the unlicensed dog and this section may be enforced by requiring the owner to remove the unlicensed dog from his or her ownership, possession, care, custody, control or maintenance. If a grandfathered owner should move outside of the city and then attempt to return, the owner must comply with the provisions of this section. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-790; Ord. No. 1150, § 3, 2010) 
Sec. 4-63. - Keeping of certain animals prohibited. 
    Except as provided for in section 30-170 et seq., no person shall keep any horse, ass, mule, sheep, swine, goat, goose, turkey, chicken or fowl within the city, and the keeping of the same within the city is a nuisance. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-810; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 4-64. - Pit bulls required to be spayed or neutered. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to own, keep, or harbor any dog within the city that the person in possession knew, or should have known, was a pit bull that has not been spayed or neutered. 
(b)  Exceptions to the requirement that a pit bull be spayed or neutered include the following: 
(1)  The pit bull is under eight weeks of age. 
(2)  The pit bull cannot be spayed or neutered without a high likelihood of suffering serious bodily harm or death due to a physical abnormality. A veterinarian must certify such a condition exists in the animal and the period of time after which the pit bull can be spayed or neutered. 
(3)  The pit bull has been present in the city for less than 30 days. 
(4)  The owner, keeper or harborer has obtained a license to keep an intact pit bull. 
(c)  License for keeping an intact pit bull: 
(1)  An owner, keeper or harborer of a pit bull which is either a show dog or a breeding dog may obtain a non-transferable intact pit bull license valid for a period of one year. The license may be obtained from the police department if all of the following conditions are met: 
a.  The applicant has provided a copy of the American Kennel Club (AKC) or United Kennel Club (UKC) registration, registration number, and pedigree documents for the dog. 
b.  If the intact pit bull will be used for breeding, the applicant must possess a city business license. If more than one owner, keeper or harborer is involved in the breeding process, each party must apply for and be granted a business license and an intact pit bull license. Sections 4-1 and 4-62 shall apply. 
c.  If the intact pit bull is a show dog, the owner, keeper or harborer must provide documentation that the animal has participated in at least one sanctioned dog show within the previous 365 days. 
d.  The application shall be accompanied by a license fee for the dog. The license fee shall be in accordance with section 4-2. 
e.  Upon approval of the application and the payment of the applicable fee, an intact pit bull tag shall be issued for the dog. 
(2)  The intact pit bull license must be renewed annually for so long as the owner, keeper or harborer continues to maintain the intact animal. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-820; Ord. No. 1196, § 3, 2015) 
Sec. 4-65. - Exotic, dangerous and unusual animals. 
    It is unlawful for any person to own, possess, harbor, sell or in any other manner traffic in any of the following animals, except as specifically provided for herein, such animals being: 
(1)  Poisonous reptiles; 
(2)  Gorillas, chimpanzees, baboons, orangutans and any other primate that normally grows to more than 30 pounds in weight; 
(3)  Any species of felines not falling within the category of ordinary domesticated house cats; 
(4)  Bears of any species; and 
(5)  Foxes, wolves, coyotes or other species of canines other than dogs. 
(Prior Code, § 4-26; Code 2000, § 7-6-800; Ord. No. 644, § 1; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 4-66. - Exceptions to restriction. 
(a)  Section 4-65 shall not apply to any of such animals as may be a part of any circus, carnival or similar show duly licensed to perform within the city. 
(b)  Notwithstanding anything heretofore in this article, any person engaged in the capture of any animal named in section 4-65, not for profit, but for the purpose of supplying the same to persons or entities outside of the city for medical or other such research, may keep any of the same within the city for a period not to exceed 30 days and then only in such pens, cages or other places of confinement as may be approved in advance by the police department. 
(Prior Code, § 4-27; Code 2000, § 7-6-830; Ord. No. 644, §§ 2, 3; Ord. No. 859, § 4-5, 1988; Ord. No. 1196, § 4, 2015) 
Secs. 4-67-4-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RABIES CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Rabies control, vaccination and reporting requirements, C.R.S. § 25-4-3601 et seq. 

Sec. 4-91. - Rabies control; requirements. 
(a)  Inoculation required. The owner of every dog over the age of six months shall keep said animal vaccinated against rabies. No such rabies vaccine shall be administered until after a ten-day observation period has expired after any dog has inflicted a bite on any person or other animal. 
(b)  Attachment of tags. Concurrently with the issuance and delivery of the certificate of vaccination referred to herein, the owner of the vaccinated animal shall cause to be attached to the collar or harness a metal tag, serially numbered to correspond with the vaccination certificate number and bearing the year of issuance. Said collar or harness shall be worn by such animal at all times it is outside the owner's premises. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-500; Ord. No. 859, § 4-4, 1988; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 4-92. - Bites; reporting and quarantine. 
(a)  The owner of any animal that bites a human being shall report the occurrence to the animal control section of the police department when such bite incident is known to said owner, or is reported to him or her. Said owner shall provide any further information requested of him or her. 
(b)  Any animal that bites a human being shall be quarantined for a period of not less than ten days from the date of the bite. The animal shall be quarantined at the animal shelter or a veterinary hospital at the owner's expense. If the owner cannot be immediately notified, the animal shall be quarantined at the animal shelter or veterinary hospital until such time as the owner is located. The expenses of such quarantine shall be the responsibility of the owner. 
(c)  Failure to quarantine is a violation of this article. 
(d)  Reporting of rabies cases and bites by rabid or suspected animals per C.R.S. § 25-4-601 et seq. Every person having knowledge thereof shall report to the animal control section of the police department any suspected or positively diagnosed occurrence of rabies and any biting by any suspected or confirmed rabid animal. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-510; Ord. No. 859, § 4-4, 1988; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 4-93-4-112. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - IMPOUNDMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Impounded animals, costs of impoundment, care, provision, and disposition, C.R.S. § 18-9-202.5. 

Sec. 4-113. - Animals subject to impoundment. 
(a)  Any animal may be impounded if the animal is the subject matter of a violation, or an investigation of a violation, of any provision of federal, state and local law, including the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  The owner or custodian of an animal that has been impounded because of alleged violation of this chapter may prevent disposition of the animal by filing a payment for impoundment, care, and provision costs with the court in an amount determined by the city council to be sufficient to provide for the animal's care and provision at the impound agency for at least 30 days, including the day on which the animal was taken into custody. Animals impounded shall be kept, cared for and disposed of as provided by this Code. 
(c)  Animals impounded for rabies or suspected rabies shall be treated as provided by C.R.S. § 25-4-601 et seq., or any other rules as may be established by the appropriate local or state agency responsible for rabies control. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-400; Ord. No. 859, § 4-2, 1988) 
Sec. 4-114. - Notice procedure. 
(a)  Upon the impoundment of an animal, it shall be the duty of the police department to make a reasonable investigation to determine the owner or custodian of the animal and to notify the owner or custodian, if known, of the animal's impoundment and the requirements for its release, and the time and place the animal will be offered for sale, if applicable; and if the animal is not claimed within six business days from the date of notification, it will be considered to be abandoned and be disposed of in accordance with this article. 
(b)  A written notice shall be posted in the police department daily, listing all animals impounded within that time period. Said notice shall be posted in a conspicuous location for a period of five business days, shall contain a description of the animals impounded and the date of impoundment, and shall state that if the animal is not claimed within six business days from the date of said notice, it shall be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-410; Ord. No. 859, § 4-2, 1988; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
State Law reference- Procedure for disposal of impounded animals, C.R.S. § 18-9-202.5. 
Sec. 4-115. - General procedure. 
(a)  All animals impounded shall be kept for the period provided by law to ensure the protection of the general welfare of the public and for the safety of the animal. No female animal in estrus shall be released unless the owner or custodian has facilities for the caring and confining of the animal in a building or secure enclosure in such a manner that the female cannot come into contact with a male animal, except for planned breeding. 
(b)  No animal shall be released until the production of satisfactory proof of ownership thereof, payment of all applicable fees and incurred expenses, and submission of proof of all applicable licensing and inoculation. 
(c)  Upon the expiration of six business days from the date of impoundment, all unclaimed animals shall be considered abandoned, and may be adopted by any person upon payment of all applicable fees and submission of evidence of applicable licensing and inoculation. Said evidence shall be submitted to the police department no later than 72 hours after the date of adoption. All animals not claimed or adopted shall be disposed of in accordance with the directions of the chief of police. 
(d)  Nothing in this chapter is intended to restrict or limit the rights and procedures set out in C.R.S. § 18-9-202.5, including the owner's right to require examination by a veterinarian within 72 hours, have a hearing or any other procedure outlined in statute. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-420; Ord. No. 859, § 4-2, 1988; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 4-116. - Disposal or adoption authorization. 
(a)  Any animal not reclaimed by its owner within the time period established in section 4-115 may be humanely euthanized or adopted. 
(b)  Any animal may be euthanized or adopted prior to the expiration of said time period if specifically requested by the lawful owner. Said request shall be made in writing, on forms furnished by the police department. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-440; Ord. No. 859, § 4-2, 1988; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 4-117. - Injured or sick animals. 
(a)  If, in the judgment of an animal control officer or police officer, an impounded animal is in need of immediate treatment for illness or injury, the officer may take the animal directly to a licensed veterinarian. The costs of treatment shall remain the responsibility of the owner and may be recovered by the city. 
(b)  If, in the opinion of a licensed veterinarian, an impounded animal is experiencing extreme pain or suffering or is severely injured past recovery, severely disabled past recovery, or severely diseased past recovery, the animal may be euthanized without a court order, pursuant to C.R.S. § 18-9-202.5. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-450; Ord. No. 859, § 4-2, 1988) 
Sec. 4-118. - Release of animals. 
    An animal control officer shall not release, except to a veterinarian, any animal which is reasonably thought to be vicious and a threat to public safety, or shows signs of rabies infection. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-460; Ord. No. 859, § 4-2, 1988; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 4-119. - Costs, fees and charges. 
    An owner reclaiming an impounded animal shall be assessed a fee as set forth in section 4-2, which shall be paid prior to the animal being released to the owner or at the owner's direction. In addition, the owner shall pay all costs incurred in veterinary fees for the animal, if any. 
(Code 2000, § 7-6-470; Ord. No. 859, § 4-2, 1988) 
Chapter 6 - BUILDING REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Administration and enforcement. 
(a)  An administrative official designated by the city council shall administer and enforce this chapter. He or she may be provided with the assistance of such other persons as the city council may direct. 
(b)  If the administrative official shall find that any of the provisions of this chapter are being violated, he or she shall notify, in writing, the person responsible for such violations, indicating the nature of the violation and ordering the action necessary to correct it. He or she shall order discontinuance of illegal use of land, buildings or structures; removal of illegal buildings or structures of illegal additions, alterations or structural changes; discontinuance of any illegal work being done; or shall take any other action authorized by this chapter to ensure compliance with or to prevent violation of its provisions. 
(Code 2000, § 16-19-10; Ord. No. 839, § 900.01, 1986) 
Sec. 6-2. - Building permits. 
    No building or other structure shall be erected, moved, added to or structurally altered without a permit therefor, issued by the administrative official. No building permit shall be issued by the administrative official except in conformity with the provisions of this article, unless the administrative official has received a written order from the board of adjustment and appeals in the form of an administrative review, special exception or variance, as provided by this chapter. 
(Code 2000, § 16-19-20; Ord. No. 839, § 900.02, 1986) 
Sec. 6-3. - Application for building permit. 
(a)  All applications for building permits shall be accompanied by plans in triplicate, drawn to scale, showing the actual dimensions and shape of the lot to be built upon; the exact sizes and locations on the lot of any buildings already existing; and the location and dimensions of the proposed building or alteration. The application shall include such other information as lawfully may be required by the administrative official, including any existing or proposed buildings or alterations; existing or proposed uses of the buildings and land; the number of families, housekeeping units or rental units the building is designed to accommodate; conditions existing on the lot; and such other matters as may be necessary to determine conformance with, and provide for the enforcement of, this chapter. 
(b)  One copy of the plans shall be returned to the applicant by the administrative official, after he or she shall have marked such copy either as approved or disapproved, and attested to the same by his or her signature on such copy. The original and one copy of the plans, similarly marked, shall be retained by the administrative official. 
(Code 2000, § 16-19-30; Ord. No. 839, § 900.03, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 6-4. - Certificates of zoning compliance. 
(a)  It is unlawful to use, occupy or permit the use or occupancy of any building or premises, or both, or part thereof, hereafter created, erected, changed, converted or wholly or partly altered or enlarged in its use of a structure, until a certificate of zoning compliance shall have been issued therefor by the administrative official, stating that the proposed use of the building or land conforms to the requirements of this chapter. 
(b)  A temporary certificate of zoning compliance may be issued by the administrative official for a period not exceeding six months during alterations or partial occupancy of a building, pending its completion, provided that such temporary certificate may include such conditions and safeguards as will protect the safety of the occupants and the public. 
(c)  The administrative official shall maintain a record of all certificates of zoning compliance and a copy shall be furnished, upon request, to any person. 
(Code 2000, § 16-19-40; Ord. No. 839, § 900.04, 1986) 
Sec. 6-5. - Expiration of building permit. 
(a)  If the work described in any building permit has not begun within 90 days from the date of issuance thereof, said permit shall expire and shall be cancelled by the administrative official, and written notice thereof shall be given to the persons affected. 
(b)  If the work described in any building permit has not been substantially completed within two years of the date of issuance thereof, said permit shall expire and be cancelled by the administrative official, and written notice thereof shall be given to the persons affected, together with notice that further work as described in the cancelled permit shall not proceed unless and until a new building permit has been obtained. 
(Code 2000, § 16-19-50; Ord. No. 839, § 900.05, 1986) 
Sec. 6-6. - Construction and use to be as authorized. 
    Building permits or certificates of zoning compliance issued on the basis of plans and applications approved by the administrative official authorize only the use, arrangement and construction set forth in such approved plans and applications. Use, arrangement or construction at variance with that authorized shall be deemed a violation of this article, and punishable as provided by section 30-738. 
(Code 2000, § 16-19-60; Ord. No. 839, § 900.06, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 6-7-6-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MINIMUM STANDARDS CODES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 6-31-6-48. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 6-49. - Adoption. 
    Pursuant to C.R.S. § 31-16-201 et seq., there is adopted as the building code of the city, by reference thereto, the International Building Code, 2006 edition, together with all appendices and tables thereto, published by the International Code Council, Inc., 5203 Leesburg Pike, Suite 708, Falls Church, Virginia 22041, to have the same force and effect as if set forth herein in every particular. The subject matter of the adopted code includes comprehensive provisions and standards regulating the erection, construction, enlargement, alteration, repair, moving, removal, conversion, demolition, occupancy, equipment, use, height, area and maintenance of buildings and structures for the purpose of protecting the public health. 
(Code 2000, § 18-1-10; Ord. No. 975, § 1, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1052, § 1, 2002; Ord. No. 1099, § 1, 2007) 
Sec. 6-50. - Copy on file. 
    At least one copy of the International Building Code, certified to be a true copy, has been and is now on file in the office of the city clerk and may be inspected by any interested person between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, holidays excepted. The code, as finally adopted, shall be available for sale to the public through the office of the city clerk at a moderate price. 
(Code 2000, § 18-1-20; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1099, § 1, 2007) 
Sec. 6-51. - Amendments. 
(a)  The code adopted herein is hereby modified by the following amendments: 
(1)  Section 101.1, Title, is amended by inserting "The City of Lamar." 
(2)  Section 101.4.1, Electrical, is amended by replacing "ICC Electrical Code" with "current electrical code adopted by the State of Colorado." 
(3)  Section 101.4.4, Plumbing, is amended by deleting the final sentence reading: "The provision of the International Private Sewage Disposal Code shall apply to private sewage disposal systems." 
(4)  Section 101.4.7, Energy, is deleted and replaced with the following: 
"All new and remodeled structures will have a minimum of R-13 insulation in the walls and R-30 in the ceilings. Windows will be the thermal type, and exterior doors will have storm doors or will be of the insulated type, which includes solid core wood." 
(5)  Section 105.2, Work exempt from permit, is amended by changing "24" to "48" and "5,000 gallons" to "10,000 gallons" in paragraph 9, and by deletion of "accessory to one- and two-family dwellings." 
(6)  Section 107.3, Temporary power, is amended by replacing "ICC Electrical Code " with "current electrical code adopted by the State of Colorado." 
(7)  Section 108.3, Building permit valuations, is amended by adding the phrase "by means of the Building Valuation Data Sheet as printed in the latest edition of the Building Safety Journal or other accepted means" to the last sentence. 
(8)  Section 109.3.5, Lath and gypsum board inspection, is amended by deleting the exception. 
(9)  Section 110.1, Use and occupancy, is amended by the addition of "Exception: Group U occupancies." 
(10)  Section 110.2, Certificate issued, is amended by the deletion of paragraphs 1, 7 and 11. 
(11)  Section 201.3, Terms defined in other codes, is amended by the addition of "the electrical code adopted by the State of Colorado" after "International Mechanical Code." 
(12)  Section 406.1.4, Separation, is amended by changing "1/2-inch (12.7 mm)" to " 5/8 -inch Type X." 
(13)  Table 1004.1.1, Maximum floor area allowance per occupant, is amended by inserting "Dancing, 5 gross." 
(14)  Section 1301.1.1, Energy efficiency, is amended as follows: 
a.  "International Energy Conservation Code" is deleted and replaced with the following: 
"All new and remodeled structures will have a minimum of R-13 insulation in the walls and R-30 in the ceilings. Windows will be the thermal type, and exterior doors will have storm doors or will be of the insulated type, which includes solid core wood." 
b.  The following exception is added: 
"Commercial or industrial applications that will not be heated to more than 52 degrees Fahrenheit. In which case, the walls will have R-11 insulation and ceilings will have R-11 insulation." 
(15)  Table 1607.1, Minimum uniformly distributed live loads and minimum concentrated live loads, is amended by changing habitable attics and sleeping areas from "30" to "40." 
(16)  Section 1805.2.1, Frost protection, is amended by replacing "below the frost line of the locality" with "32 inches deep." 
(17)  Section 1805.4.5, Timber footings, is deleted in its entirety. 
(18)  Section 1805.5.6, Wood foundations, is deleted in its entirety. 
(19)  Section 1808.1, Definitions, is amended by deleting "Timber piles" and its definition. 
(20)  Section 1809.1, Timber piles, is deleted in its entirety. 
(21)  Section 1907, Details of enforcement, is amended by the addition of a new section 1907.5.1 as follows: 
"Minimum lap of deformed reinforcement bars. Reinforcement bars will be lapped a minimum of 36 bar diameters and will be tied a minimum of twice." 
(22)  Section 2303.4.2, Metal-plate-connected trusses, is deleted in its entirety. 
(23)  Section 2701.1, Scope, is amended by replacing "ICC Electrical Code" with "current electrical code adopted by the State of Colorado." 
(24)  Section 2901.1, Scope, is amended by deleting "Private sewage disposal system shall conform to the International Private Sewage Disposal Code." 
(25)  Section 3103, Temporary structures, is deleted in its entirety.
