All adult businesses and adult entertainment businesses shall have conspicuously displayed in the common area at the principal entrance to the premises a sign, of which uppercase letters shall be at least two inches high, and lowercase letters at least one inch high, which shall read as follows: 
THIS ADULT ENTERTAINMENT BUSINESS IS REGULATED AND LICENSED BY THE CITY OF LAMAR, COLORADO 
ENTERTAINERS AND CUSTOMERS ARE: 
Not permitted to engage in any type of illegal conduct or prostitution on the premises or to fondle, caress or touch the breasts, pubic region, buttocks or genitals of any employee, patron or other entertainer or to permit any employee, patron or other entertainer to fondle, cress or touch the breasts, pubic region, buttocks or genitals of said entertainer, employee or patron. 
Not permitted to be nude, unclothed or in less than opaque attire, costume or clothing so as to expose to view any portion of the breasts below the top of the areola, or any portion of the pubic region, buttocks or genitals. The entertainers are to be upon a stage at least two (2) feet above the customer floor and a sufficient distance from the customers to prevent the customers from touching the entertainers. 
Not permitted to demand or collect any payment or gratuity from any customer for entertainment, except as follows: 
While such entertainer is on the stage, by placing such payment or gratuity into a box affixed to the stage, or 
While such entertainer is not on the stage, by either placing such payment or gratuity into the entertainer's hand or under the entertainer's leg garter. 
CUSTOMERS ARE: 
Not permitted to be on the stage at any time. 
Not permitted to touch, caress or fondle the breasts, pubic region, buttocks or genitals of any employee, server, manager or entertainer or engage in solicitation for prostitution. 
(7)  Lighting required. 
a.  The interior premises of all adult businesses and adult entertainment businesses shall be equipped with overhead lighting of sufficient intensity to illuminate every place to which customers are permitted access at an illumination of not less than one foot-candle, as measured at the floor level, and such illumination must be maintained at all times that any customer or patron is present in or on the premises. 
b.  The exterior premises of all adult businesses or adult entertainment businesses shall be equipped with overhead lighting of sufficient intensity to illuminate every place to which customers are permitted access at an illumination equivalent to not less than one foot-candle in all parking areas and on the general grounds of the premises, as measured at the ground level. There shall be illumination to the equivalent of not less than five foot-candles as measured at the ground level at each entrance and doorway area, and such illumination must be maintained at all times that any customer or patron is present on the premises. 
(8)  Closed booth or room prohibited. 
a.  The premises of all adult businesses and adult entertainment businesses shall be physically arranged in such a manner that the entire interior portion of any booths, cubicles, rooms or stalls is visible from a common area of the premises. The use of video cameras to meet this requirement is not allowed. Visibility shall not be blocked or obscured by doors, curtains, drapes or any other obstruction whatsoever. The manager shall be required to position himself or herself so as to be able to view the entire interior portion of the premises while on duty. 
b.  Only one person shall be allowed in any booth, cubicle, room or stall at a time. Such booths, cubicles, rooms or stalls shall be constructed out of metal or such other material as is incapable of perforation by any customer or employee on the premises. Other than the entryways, there shall be no openings, holes, access doors or any other manner of accessibility between any booth, cubicle, room or stall and any other booth, cubicle, room or stall. 
(9)  Ventilation and sanitation requirements. The premises of all adult businesses and adult entertainment businesses shall be kept in a sanitary condition. Separate dressing rooms and restrooms for men and women shall at all times be maintained and kept in a sanitary condition. 
(10)  Hours of operation. No adult business or adult entertainment business may be open or in use between the hours of 1:30 a.m. and 12:00 noon of the following day. 
(Code 2000, § 6-10-310; Ord. No. 1046, 2002; Ord. No. 1056, §§ 2, 3, 2002) 
Sec. 8-63. - Manager on premises. 
(a)  A manager shall be on duty at any adult business or adult entertainment business at all times the premises is open for business. The name of the manager on duty shall be prominently posted during business hours. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the manager to verify that any person who provides adult entertainment or works as an employee within the premises possesses a current and valid license as required by this article and that such licenses are prominently displayed and posted. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the manager to ensure that persons under the age of 21 years, other than those individuals licensed as employees of the adult business or adult entertainment business pursuant to section 8-301(b), do not enter upon the premises. 
(Code 2000, § 6-10-320; Ord. No. 1046, 2002; Ord. No. 1056, § 4, 2002) 
Sec. 8-64. - Inspector and inspections. 
    All adult businesses and adult entertainment businesses shall permit representatives of the police department or any other city official acting in their official capacity to inspect the premises as necessary to ensure that the business is complying with all applicable regulations, ordinances and laws. 
(Code 2000, § 6-10-330; Ord. No. 1046, 2002) 
Secs. 8-65-8-78. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - LICENSE SUSPENSION, REVOCATION, NONRENEWAL OR RENEWAL 

Sec. 8-79. - Suspension, revocation or nonrenewal. 
(a)  Whenever the city clerk has information that: 
(1)  The owner or operator of any adult business or adult entertainment business or a holder of an adult business or adult entertainment business employee license has violated, or knowingly allowed or permitted the violation of, any of the provisions of this article; 
(2)  There have been recurrent violations of provisions of this article that have occurred under such circumstances that the owner or operator of an adult business or adult entertainment business knew or should have known that such violations were committed; 
(3)  The adult business or adult entertainment business license or the employee license was obtained through false statements in the application for such license, or renewal thereof; 
(4)  The adult business or adult entertainment business licensee or employee licensee failed to make a complete disclosure of all information in the application for the license, or renewal thereof; 
(5)  The owner or operator, any partner or any corporate officer or director holding an adult business or adult entertainment business license has become disqualified from having a license by a conviction as provided in this article; or 
(6)  The holder of an employee license issued pursuant to this article has become disqualified from having a license by a conviction as provided in this article; 
then the city council shall conduct a hearing to determine whether the license should be suspended or revoked. 
(b)  Based upon the evidence produced at the hearing, the city council may take any of the following actions: 
(1)  Suspend the license for up to 90 days. 
(2)  Revoke the license for the remainder of the license year. 
(3)  Place the license holder on administrative probation for a period of up to one year, on the condition that no further violations of the article occur; and if after a hearing, a subsequent violation is determined to have actually occurred, the license will be revoked for the remainder of the license year. 
(Code 2000, § 6-10-410; Ord. No. 1046, 2002) 
Sec. 8-80. - Renewal. 
(a)  A license may be renewed by making application to the city clerk on application forms provided for that purpose. Licenses shall expire on December 31 of each calendar year, and renewal applications for such licenses shall be submitted between December 15 and December 31. 
(b)  Upon timely application and review as provided for a new license, a license issued under the provisions of this article shall be renewed by issuance of a new license in the manner provided for in this article. 
(c)  If the application for the renewal of a license is not made during the time period in subsection (a) of this section, the expiration of such license shall not be affected, and a new application shall be required. 
(Code 2000, § 6-10-420; Ord. No. 1046, 2002) 
Sec. 8-81. - Judicial review; stay of enforcement of orders. 
    Following the entry of an order by the city council suspending or revoking a license issued pursuant to this article, or disapproving the renewal application for a license, such licensee or applicant may seek judicial review in a manner provided by law. The city council may stay enforcement of such order for a period of time not to exceed 30 days, pending the filing and/or final disposition of proceedings for judicial review. 
(Code 2000, § 6-10-430; Ord. No. 1046, 2002) 
Secs. 8-82-8-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 

Sec. 8-96. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Retail license means a grant to a licensee to sell fermented malt beverages or a grant to a licensee to sell malt, vinous or spirituous liquors pursuant to state law. 
    Retail licensee or licensee means the holder of a license to sell fermented malt beverages or the holder of a license to sell malt, vinous or spirituous liquors pursuant to state law. 
(b)  All other terms shall be defined as set forth in the provisions of the Colorado Beer Code, the Colorado Liquor Code and special event permits, as the definitions presently exist or may hereafter be amended. 
(Code 2000, § 6-2-10; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-97. - Application of state statutes; exemption of Lamar Community College. 
(a)  Except as provided in this section, pursuant to a declaration of the General Assembly, the Colorado Beer Code, C.R.S. § 12-46-101 et seq., the Colorado Liquor Code, C.R.S. § 12-47-101 et seq., and Special Event Permits, C.R.S. § 12-48-101 et seq., as they presently exist or may hereafter be amended, shall apply to the sale of fermented malt beverages, alcoholic beverages, special malt liquors, spirituous liquors and vinous liquors in the city. 
(b)  The distance restriction set forth in C.R.S. § 12-47-313(1)(d)(I) is eliminated as to Lamar Community College. 
(Code 2000, § 6-2-20; Ord. No. 1017, 2000; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-98. - Power and purpose. 
    The city is authorized and will issue, renew, transfer, suspend and revoke various licenses for sale of alcoholic beverages pursuant to the application and fee requirements, standards, investigation and hearing procedures established by state law. 
(Code 2000, § 6-2-30; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
State Law reference- Local licensing authority, C.R.S. § 12-47-309 et seq.; standards for consideration at hearing on application, C.R.S. § 12-47-312; notice requirements for hearing, C.R.S. § 12-47-311. 
Sec. 8-99. - Application form. 
    All applications for new city liquor licenses and fermented malt beverage licenses shall be made on forms provided by the state liquor enforcement division, and all applicants shall fully furnish all information requested thereon. 
(Prior Code, § 14-7; Code 2000, § 6-2-40; Ord. No. 581, §§ 1-3; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-100. - Fingerprinting of applicants. 
    All applicants for new licenses or renewals shall be fingerprinted by the police department. If the applicant is other than an individual, then the person who will actively manage the business shall be the one so required to be fingerprinted. 
(Prior Code, § 14-7; Code 2000, § 6-2-50; Ord. No. 581, §§ 1-3; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-101. - Renewals. 
    Applicants who seek to renew a license and who have heretofore complied with section 8-38 shall not be required to again submit to such fingerprinting unless there has been a change in personnel of such a nature as to place the active management of the business under one or more persons who have not previously been fingerprinted under this article. 
(Prior Code, § 14-7; Code 2000, § 6-2-60; Ord. No. 581, §§ 1-3; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-102. - Licensing fees. 
    Licensing fees shall be paid to the city clerk by the applicant at the time of the filing of the application or request as established by state statute. 
(Prior Code, § 14-7.1; Code 2000, § 6-2-70; Ord. No. 700, § 1; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
State Law reference- Local license fees for liquor licenses, C.R.S. § 12-47-505; local license fees for fermented malt beverages, C.R.S. § 12-46-107. 
Sec. 8-103. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  Whenever a decision of the city council, acting as the local licensing authority (hereinafter authority), suspending a retail license for 14 days or less becomes final, whether by failure of the retail licensee to appeal the decision or by exhaustion of all appeals and judicial review, the retail licensee may, before the operative date of the suspension, petition the authority for permission to pay a fine in lieu of having his or her retail license suspended for all or part of the suspension period. Upon the receipt of the petition, the authority may, in its sole discretion, stay the proposed suspension and cause any investigation to be made which it deems desirable and may, in its sole discretion, grant the petition if it is satisfied: 
(1)  That the public welfare and morals would not be impaired by permitting the retail licensee to operate during the period set for suspension and that the payment of the fine will achieve the desired disciplinary purposes; 
(2)  That the books and records of the retail licensee are kept in such a manner that the loss of sales of alcoholic beverages which the retail licensee would have suffered had the suspension gone into effect can be determined with reasonable accuracy therefrom; and 
(3)  That the retail licensee has not had his or her license suspended or revoked, nor had any suspension stayed by payment of a fine, during the two years immediately preceding the date of the motion or complaint which has resulted in a final decision to suspend the retail license. 
(b)  The fine accepted shall be equivalent to 20 percent of the retail licensee's estimated gross revenues from sales of alcoholic beverages during the period of the proposed suspension, except that the fine shall be not less than $200.00 nor more than $5,000.00. 
(c)  Payment of any fine pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be in the form of cash, certified check or cashier's check made payable to the city clerk and shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(d)  Upon payment of the fine pursuant to this section, the authority shall enter its further order permanently staying the imposition of the suspension. 
(e)  In connection with any petition pursuant to this section, the authority is limited to granting stays only when necessary for it to complete its investigation and make its findings. 
(f)  If the authority does not make the findings required in subsection (a) of this section and does not order the suspension permanently stayed, the suspension shall go into effect on the operative date finally set by the authority. 
(Code 2000, § 6-2-80; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
State Law reference- Additional penalties, suspension, revocation and fines for violations, C.R.S. § 12-47-601. 
Sec. 8-104. - Optional premises. 
(a)  Optional premises licenses and optional premises for hotel and restaurant licenses may be issued by the authority. 
(b)  The following standards shall be applicable to the issuance of a license under this section, in addition to all other applicable standards set forth in the Colorado Liquor Code for optional premises licenses and optional premises for a hotel and restaurant licenses. 
(1)  Eligible facilities. Outdoor sports and recreational facilities, as used in C.R.S. § 12-47-310, are eligible for licensing as an optional premises or an optional premises for a hotel and restaurant. 
(2)  Number of optional premises. There are no restrictions on the number of optional premises which any one licensee may have on an outdoor sports or recreational facility. 
(3)  Minimum size of facility. There is no restriction on the minimum size of an outdoor sports or recreational facility which would be eligible for issuance of an optional premises license or optional premises for a hotel and restaurant license. 
(c)  The application for an optional premises license or optional premises for a hotel or restaurant license shall be accompanied by the following: 
(1)  A map or other drawing illustrating the outdoor sports or recreational facility boundaries and the approximate location of each optional premises requested; 
(2)  A description of the method which shall be used to identify the boundaries of the optional premises when it is in use; and 
(3)  A description of the provisions which have been made for storing malt, vinous and spirituous liquors in a secured area on or off the optional premises for the future use on the optional premises. 
(Code 2000, § 6-2-90; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-105. - Regulations for non-alcohol events for underage persons on licensed premises. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alcoholic beverage means any fermented malt beverage or malt, vinous or spirituous liquors. 
    Licensed premises means any premises for which a license to sell fermented malt beverages or malt, vinous or spirituous liquors is granted pursuant to the Colorado Liquor Code, C.R.S. § 12-47-101 et seq., with the exception that licensed premises, as used in this section, shall not include: 
(1)  A restaurant, as defined in C.R.S. § 12-47-103(30), serving a meal as defined by C.R.S. § 12-47-103(20). 
(2)  A bowling alley or other facility where the sport of bowling occurs. 
(3)  A club as defined in C.R.S. § 12-47-103(6). 
(4)  Any licensed premises, as defined in this subsection, during which a private party is occurring. 
    Non-alcohol event means any activity for which an underage person is admitted to a licensed premises. 
    Private party means an event which meets the following criteria: 
(1)  The licensed premises is reserved by an identifiable person or organization that pays a fee to have exclusive use of the licensed premises for an event where attendance is by invitation only. 
(2)  The licensed premises is closed to the public for a specific period of time during which the person or organization has exclusive use of, and the host of the event and owner or manager of the licensed premises jointly control access to, the premises and preclude those persons under the age of 21 years from obtaining and consuming alcoholic beverages on the premises. 
(3)  No fee or remuneration, inclusive of ticket sales or purchases, is assessed against those attending the event. 
(4)  The owner or manager of the licensed premises has submitted an application to the police department which complies with the following requirements: 
a.  The application is submitted to the police department during the police department's business hours of Monday through Friday (excluding holidays) between 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 
b.  The application is submitted at least 48 hours before the event is scheduled to occur; and 
c.  The application is made on a form approved by the police department setting forth information which includes, but is not limited to: 
1.  The name, address and telephone number of the person or organization that has reserved the licensed premises for private party use; 
2.  The duration during which the licensed premises will be used for the private party; and 
3.  The purpose for which the licensed premises are being reserved for private party use. 
    Underage person means any person younger than 21 years old. 
(b)  Underage persons are prohibited from being on licensed premises for any purpose other than the participation in a non-alcohol event within the meaning of this section. 
(c)  The licensee, owner, operator or manager of a licensed premises shall notify the police department at least 48 hours in advance of any date on which underage persons will be present on the licensed premises. 
(d)  Each such non-alcohol events notice shall specify the date on which the event is to occur and the time of commencement. All notices shall be filed with the police department during normal working hours, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., and shall be given on forms prescribed by the police department. 
(e)  After a non-alcohol event notice has been given, the licensee, owner, operator or manager of a licensed premises may cancel an event only by giving like notice to the police department in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(f)  Regardless of the date given, all notices shall expire and be deemed cancelled no later than the date of expiration or revocation of the license to sell alcoholic beverages applicable to the licensed premises. 
(g)  During the period of any non-alcohol event, a notice card approved by the police department shall be posted at all public entrances to the licensed premises notifying the general public that no alcoholic beverages may be consumed, sold or given away on or carried into the licensed premises during the event. 
(h)  Once a non-alcohol event has commenced, no alcoholic beverages may be consumed, sold or given away on or carried into the licensed premises until the next day following the closing hours of the licensed premises. 
(i)  During the period of any non-alcohol event, all alcoholic beverages shall be stored in a locked portion of the licensed premises in a secure place out of the sight and physical reach of any patron present, and shall be under the direct and immediate control and supervision of the licensee, owner, operator or manager of the licensed premises. All beer taps and automatic dispensers of alcoholic beverages shall be either disconnected, disabled or made inoperable during the time allocated for the non-alcohol event and continuing into the next day following the closing hours of the licensed premises. 
(Code 2000, § 6-2-100; Ord. No. 1044, 2002; Ord. No. 1077, §§ 1, 2, 2004) 
Secs. 8-106-8-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AMUSEMENTS AND AMUSEMENT DEVICES 

Sec. 8-120. - Generally. 
    Every person operating any place of amusement, theater, picture show or other such place not specifically provided for in this article, at any time during the year, shall pay an annual license fee as established by the city council, and the license under this article shall not apply to schools, churches or charitable benefits, as distinguished from any place operated as a commercial enterprise. 
(Prior Code, § 14-8; Code 2000, § 6-3-10; Ord. No. 294, § 1; Ord. No. 416, § 1; Ord. No. 808, § 4; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-121. - Circus or menagerie. 
    Every person operating a circus, menagerie, or circus and menagerie combined shall pay a license fee as established by the city council, which shall cover two entertainments during 24 hours, and which shall cover all side shows showing under one management. For the purposes of this section, two entertainments means showings that occur consecutively, whether it is the same or different shows. 
(Prior Code, § 14-10; Code 2000, § 6-3-20; Ord. No. 260, § 14; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-122. - Carnivals. 
    Every person operating a carnival or street carnival shall apply for a license as required by this chapter and pay a license fee as established by the city council, which shall cover all shows and concessions that are showing under one management. Carnivals shall be required to show proper licensing and approval for all rides as required under 7 C.C.R. 1101-12, as may be amended. A license issued by the city shall in no way be intended as an exemption from state licensing requirements, including the requirements of 7 C.C.R. 1101-12. 
(Prior Code, § 14-11; Code 2000, § 6-3-30; Ord. No. 260, § 15; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-123. - Amusement rides. 
    Any person operating any amusement rides, including, but not limited to, merry-go-rounds or Ferris wheels, shall pay a license fee as established by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 14-12; Code 2000, § 6-3-40; Ord. No. 260, § 12; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-124. - Exhibitions generally. 
    Every person conducting exhibitions for pay not otherwise provided for in this article shall pay a license fee as established by the city council; provided, however, that those exhibitions sponsored by nonprofit organizations and entities shall be exempt from payment of license fees. 
(Prior Code, § 14-14; Code 2000, § 6-3-50; Ord. No. 260, § 19; Ord. No. 808, § 5; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-125. - Smoking. 
    No person shall smoke cigarettes, cigars, e-cigarettes or pipes in any theater or place where moving pictures are being shown, or any theatrical or other public performance is being given, in the city, while an audience is gathered therein for any such show or public performance, unless permission for such smoking shall have first been given by resolution duly adopted by the city council and approved by the fire chief, provided that any such permission may be revoked at any time by the city council, in its discretion. 
(Prior Code, § 3-5; Code 2000, § 6-3-70; Ord. No. 340, § 1; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-126. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Coin-operated amusement devices, games, arcade machines or any similar device used for testing one's skill or otherwise means any amusement device placed in operation by a coin, provided that the term "coin-operated amusement devices, games, arcade machines or any similar device used for testing one's skill or otherwise" shall not include any machine used for gambling. 
    Merchant means any person using, renting or otherwise displaying for hire one or more amusement devices for the use of the public in a place of business under his or her control. 
    Operator means any person owning or controlling one or more amusement devices which are rented, displayed or otherwise used in a place of business. 
(Prior Code, § 3-6; Code 2000, § 6-4-10; Ord. No. 354, § 1; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-127. - Licenses required. 
(a)  Every operator, as defined by this article, shall be required to have a license as provided for in this article. 
(b)  No merchant or person shall display, let or otherwise permit to be used, within the city, a coin-operated amusement device belonging to an operator, unless such operator has an operator's license, as provided by this article. 
(Prior Code, § 3-7; Code 2000, § 6-4-20; Ord. No. 354, §§ 2, 3; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-128. - Operator's license. 
    Upon application to the city clerk, and upon payment of the annual license fee as established by the city council, an operator's license under this article will be issued to any person, provided that such person shall be in compliance with all local, state and federal laws regulating the business, including zoning and building regulations. 
(Prior Code, § 3-8; Code 2000, § 6-4-30; Ord. No. 354, § 4; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-129. - Annual license period. 
    The annual period for which licenses under this article shall be issued shall commence on January 1 and end on December 31. 
(Prior Code, § 3-13; Code 2000, § 6-4-40; Ord. No. 354, § 13; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-130. - Revocation; confiscation of devices. 
    Any license issued pursuant to this article to any person who is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be revoked, and any game or device operated in violation of the terms of this article may be confiscated and destroyed or disposed of as provided by law. 
(Prior Code, § 3-14; Code 2000, § 6-4-50; Ord. No. 354, § 12; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-131. - Use of devices for gambling prohibited; liability of merchant. 
(a)  No person shall permit gambling upon any coin-operated amusement device or issue checks or slugs payable in such games. 
(b)  The owner or operator of the place of business in which any amusement device is used is hereby specifically charged with knowledge and made liable for the use of such games or devices, and if any such game or device is used for gambling, the owner or operator of such place of business shall be liable the same as if he or she had authorized such use. 
(Prior Code, § 3-15; Code 2000, § 6-4-60; Ord. No. 354, §§ 9, 10; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-132. - Dealing with unlicensed merchants and operators prohibited. 
    No merchant shall use amusement devices belonging to an operator whose license to operate has been suspended, during the time of such suspension. It shall be the duty of a merchant or operator to know whether any person with whom he or she is dealing is duly authorized under this article, and, that his or her license has not been suspended. 
(Prior Code, § 3-16; Code 2000, § 6-4-70; Ord. No. 354, § 11; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 8-133-8-146. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CONTRACTORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-147. - License fees. 
    General building contractors, minor subcontractors and major subcontractors shall be required to obtain a license and shall pay such license fee as established by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 5-4; Code 2000, § 6-5-10; Ord. No. 748, § 13; Ord. No. 974, § 1, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-148. - Liability insurance and workers' compensation insurance. 
(a)  All licensed general building contractors and subcontractors within the city must procure, and exhibit to the building official as a condition of licensing, general public liability insurance coverage in a minimum amount of $100,000.00 and conditioned upon satisfactory and adequate performance of all contracting and building activities undertaken by the holder of such license. 
(b)  Additionally, all licensed building contractors and subcontractors within the city must procure, and exhibit to the building official as a condition of licensing, either: 
(1)  Proof of workers' compensation insurance on any and all employees of the contractor or subcontractor, with such coverage being in compliance with the requirements of the Workers' Compensation Act of Colorado, as amended from time to time; or 
(2)  Proof of the contractor's or subcontractor's rejection or exemption from the coverage required by the Workers' Compensation Act of Colorado, as amended from time to time. 
(Prior Code, § 5-4.1; Code 2000, § 6-5-20; Ord. No. 748, § 14; Ord. No. 974, § 2, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1067, § 1, 2003) 
Secs. 8-149-8-163. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIRE SUPPRESSION CONTRACTORS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- State registration required, local registration authorized, C.R.S. § 24-33.5-1206.1. 

Sec. 8-164. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fire suppression contractor means any individual, firm, corporation, association, or organized group of persons, that, individually or through others, offers to undertake, represents itself as being able to undertake, or does undertake to sell, layout, fabricate, install, modify, alter, repair, maintain, or perform maintenance inspections of any fire suppression system. For the purposes of this article, the term "fire suppression contractor" shall include the following: 
(1)  Any person who installs, retrofits, adds to, services, repairs or inspects automatic fire sprinkler and stand pipe systems of all types, including, but not limited to, backflow preventers; 
(2)  Any person who installs, retrofits, adds to, services, repairs or inspects special hazard fire suppression systems, including necessary control, alarm and detection components; 
(3)  Any person who installs, retrofits, adds to, services, repairs or inspects portable fire extinguishers, including necessary control, alarm and detection components; and 
(4)  Any person who performs hydrostatic testing of portable fire extinguishers. 
(Code 2000, § 6-6-10; Ord. No. 1008, § 2, 1999) 
Sec. 8-165. - License regulations and requirements. 
    Every fire suppression contractor shall be subject to the following regulations and license requirements by applicable category: 
(1)  Fire Suppression Contractor A. 
a.  Authorized activities. Recipients of a Fire Suppression Contractor A license are hereby authorized to install, add to, alter, service, repair and inspect automatic fire sprinkler and stand pipe systems of all types as well as retrofit existing systems with backflow preventers. 
b.  Mandatory compliance. Recipients of a Fire Suppression Contractor A license are required to obtain permits from the fire department for installation or alteration of such systems pursuant to the Uniform Building Code, as amended, and the Uniform Fire Code, as amended. 
c.  Requirements. A Fire Suppression Contractor A license shall only be issued upon: 
1.  Receipt of proof of a current certificate of registration to the fire suppression program from the state division of fire safety; and 
2.  Receipt of proof of current liability insurance coverage in the amount of $600,000.00 or greater. 
(2)  Fire Suppression Contractor/Dealer B. 
a.  Authorized activities. Recipients of a Fire Suppression Contractor/Dealer B license are hereby authorized to install, add to, alter, service, repair and inspect portable fire extinguishers and special hazard fire suppression systems inclusive of their necessary control, alarm and detection components, and to perform hydrostatic testing of portable fire extinguishers. 
b.  Mandatory compliance. Recipients of a Fire Suppression Contractor/Dealer B license are required to obtain permits from the fire department for installation or alteration of such systems pursuant to the Uniform Building Code, as amended, and the Uniform Fire Code, as amended. 
c.  Requirements. A Fire Suppression Contractor/Dealer B license shall only be issued upon: 
1.  Receipt of proof of a current certification from at least one manufacturer of special hazard systems, which certification qualifies the recipient to install and service such system; 
2.  Receipt of proof of a currently maintained DOT registration as an approved cylinder requalification facility or a contract with an outside cylinder requalification facility for which proof is provided of that facility's registration with the DOT, liability insurance coverage of at least $600,000.00 and identification on the cylinders of the company actually performing the hydrostatic test; 
3.  Receipt of proof of current liability insurance coverage in the amount of $600,000.00 or greater; 
4.  Satisfaction of the minimum equipment list as set forth at the fire department; and 
5.  Provision of names and qualifications of employees of the contractor/dealer who will be performing the installations, additions, alterations, services, repairs and inspections. 
(3)  Fire Suppression Contractor/Dealer C. 
a.  Authorized activities. Recipients of a Fire Suppression Contractor/Dealer C license are hereby authorized to install, service, recharge, repair, inspect and hydrostatically test portable fire extinguishers. 
b.  Requirements. A Fire Suppression Contractor/Dealer C license shall only be issued upon: 
1.  Receipt of proof of a currently maintained DOT registration as an approved cylinder requalification facility or a contract with an outside cylinder requalification facility for which proof is provided of that facility's registration with the DOT; 
2.  Receipt of proof of current liability insurance coverage in the amount of $600,000.00 or greater; 
3.  Satisfaction of the minimum equipment list as set forth at the fire department; and 
4.  Provision of names and qualifications of employees of the contractor/dealer who will be performing the installations, recharges, services, repairs and inspections. 
(4)  Commercial, Industrial or Institutional Non-Contractor/Dealer D. 
a.  Authorized activities. Recipients of a Commercial, Industrial or Institutional Non-Contractor/Dealer D license are hereby authorized to install, recharge, service, repair and inspect portable fire extinguishers which are the property or under the care and control of the license applicant. 
b.  Requirements. A Commercial, Industrial or Institutional Non-Contractor/Dealer D license shall only be issued upon: 
1.  Receipt of proof of current liability insurance coverage in the amount of $600,000.00 or greater; 
2.  Receipt of a detailed explanation of his or her qualifications to service portable fire extinguishers; 
3.  Satisfaction of the minimum equipment list as set forth at the fire department; and 
4.  Provision of names and qualifications of employees of the licensee who will be performing the installations, recharges, services, repairs and inspections. 
(Code 2000, § 6-6-20; Ord. No. 1008, § 3, 1999) 
Sec. 8-166. - License and registration fees. 
    The annual license and registration fees for those individuals installing, repairing and servicing fire extinguishers and fire suppression systems shall be as established by the city council. 
(Code 2000, § 6-6-30; Ord. No. 1008, § 4, 1999; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 8-167-8-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MARIJUANA BUSINESSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 8-181-194. - Reserved 
DIVISION 2. - MEDICAL MARIJUANA[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- City may prohibit and/or provide reasonable regulations of medical marijuana centers, optional premises cultivation and infused products manufacturing, C.R.S. § 12-43.3-310. 

Sec. 8-195. - Medical marijuana. 
    Under the authority granted in C.R.S. § 12-43.3-101 et seq., and the Charter of the city, the ordinance from which this article was derived is adopted by the city council and prohibits certain businesses and land uses related to medical marijuana in the city, and in furtherance of its stated intent, the city council makes the following findings: 
(1)  The Colorado Medical Marijuana Code, C.R.S. § 12-43.3-101 et seq., authorizes a regulatory structure for the retail, sale, distribution, cultivation and dispensing of medical marijuana, marijuana-infused products and optional premises cultivation. Through that regulatory structure, the scope and authority of amendment 20 to the state constitution is further defined. 
(2)  The Colorado Medical Marijuana Code also specifically authorizes the governing body of a municipality to vote to prohibit the licensure and/or operation of medical marijuana centers, optional premises cultivation operations and medical marijuana-infused products manufacturing within the municipality. 
(3)  The Colorado Medical Marijuana Code also specifically authorizes a municipality to prohibit the operation of medical marijuana centers, optional premises cultivation operations and medical marijuana-infused products manufacturers' licenses based on local government zoning, health, safety and public welfare laws for the distribution of medical marijuana. 
(4)  After due and careful consideration of the Colorado Medical Marijuana Code, article XVIII of the state constitution, the Controlled Substance Act (21 USC 811), the Colorado Uniform Controlled Substance Act (C.R.S. § 18-18-10 et seq.) and the real and possible effects of cultivation and dispensing of marijuana and/or the manufacturing and sale of marijuana-infused products, those businesses, operations and land uses have been found to adversely affect the health, safety and welfare of the city and its inhabitants. 
(5)  Therefore, it is and shall be unlawful for any person to operate, cause to be operated or permit to be operated a medical marijuana center, an optional premises cultivation operation or a medical marijuana-infused products manufacturing or sale facility, business or operation related thereto in the city, and no city licenses shall be issued for the same. 
(Code 2000, § 6-11-10; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 2010) 
Sec. 8-196. - Definitions. 
    All definitions provided in C.R.S. § 12-43.3-101 et seq. are adopted herein unless specifically amended hereby. 
    Marijuana shall have the same meaning as the term "usable form of marijuana," as set forth in article XVIII, section 14(1)(I) of the state constitution or as may be more fully defined in any applicable state law or regulation. The term "marijuana" may alternatively be spelled "marihuana." 
    Medical marijuana means marijuana that is grown and sold pursuant to the provisions of C.R.S. § 12-43.3-101 et seq., and for a purpose authorized by article XVIII, section 14 of the state constitution. 
    Medical marijuana center means any person licensed pursuant to the provisions of C.R.S. § 12-43.3-101 et seq., who sells marijuana in any form to registered patients or to primary caregivers as defined in article XVIII, section 14 of the state constitution; except, however, a primary caregiver as defined herein shall not be considered a medical marijuana center. 
    Medical marijuana-infused product means any product infused with or containing marijuana that is intended for use or consumption other than by smoking, including edible products, ointments and tinctures. 
    Medical marijuana-infused product manufacturer means a person licensed pursuant to C.R.S. § 12-43.3-101 et seq., to operate a business as described in C.R.S. § 12-43.3-404. 
    Medical use shall have the same meaning as is set forth in article XVIII, section 14(1)(B) of the state constitution or as may be more fully defined in any applicable state law or regulation. 
    Optional premises cultivation operation means a person licensed pursuant to C.R.S. § 12-43.3-101 et seq., to grow and cultivate marijuana for a purpose authorized by article XVIII, section 14 of the state constitution. 
    Patient has the same meaning as set forth in article XVIII, section 14(1)(C) of the state constitution. 
    Possess or possession means having physical control of an object or control of the premises in which an object is located, or having the power and intent to control an object, without regard to whether the one in possession has ownership of the object. The term "possession" may be held by more than one person at a time. Use of the object is not required for possession. 
    Primary caregiver has the meaning set forth in article XVIII, section 14(1)(F) of the state constitution, and as the same may be clarified or construed by C.R.S. § 12-43.3-101 et seq. 
    Produce or production means: 
(1)  All phases of growth of marijuana, from seed to harvest; 
(2)  Combining marijuana with any other substance for distribution, including storage and packaging for resale; or 
(3)  Preparing, compounding, processing, encapsulating, packing or repackaging, labeling or relabeling of marijuana or its derivatives, whether alone or mixed with any amount of any other substance. 
(Code 2000, § 6-11-20; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 2010) 
Sec. 8-197. - Applicability and effective date. 
(a)  This article shall apply to all property and persons within the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a violation under this article for a person to establish, operate, cause or permit to be operated or continue to operate within the city and within any area annexed to the city after December 31, 2010, a medical marijuana center, a medical marijuana-infused product manufacturing facility, an optional premises cultivation operation or any business, facility or any other operation requiring a license under C.R.S. § 12-43.3-101 et seq. 
(Code 2000, § 6-11-30; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 2010) 
Sec. 8-198. - Patients and primary caregivers. 
    Nothing in this article shall prohibit, regulate or otherwise impair or be construed to prohibit, regulate or impair the cultivation, use or possession of medical marijuana by a patient and/or by a primary caregiver for his or her patients, provided that such patient or primary caregiver is acting in accordance with all applicable provisions of article XVIII, section 14(1)(C) of the state constitution, C.R.S. § 12-43.3-101 et seq., C.R.S. § 25-1.5-106, the regulations promulgated by the state department of public health and environment, the department of revenue or any other agency with regulatory authority, and the laws of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 6-11-40; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 2010) 
Secs. 8-199-8-212. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERSONAL USE AND REGULATION OF MARIJUANA[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- City may prohibit marijuana operations through the enactment of an ordinance, Colo. Const. art. XVIII, § 16. 

Sec. 8-213. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Colorado Medical Marijuana Code means C.R.S. § 12-43.3-101 et seq. 
    Consumer means a person 21 years of age or older who purchases marijuana or marijuana products for personal use by persons 21 years of age or older, but not for resale to others. 
    Department means the state department of revenue or its successor agency. 
    Industrial hemp means the plant of the genus Cannabis and any part of such plant, whether growing or not, with a delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol concentration that does not exceed three-tenths percent on a dry weight basis. 
    Locality means a county, municipality or city and county. 
    Marijuana or marihuana means all parts of the plant of the genus Cannabis, whether growing or not, the seeds thereof and the resin, including marijuana concentrate. The term "marijuana" or "marihuana" does not include industrial hemp, nor does it include fiber produced from the stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of the plant, sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of germination or the weight of any other ingredient combined with marijuana to prepare topical or oral administrations, food, drinks or other products. The term "marijuana" or "marihuana" also includes any artificially concocted substance containing delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol. 
    Marijuana accessories means any equipment, products or materials of any kind which are used, intended for use or designed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, composting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, vaporizing or containing marijuana or for ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing marijuana into the human body. 
    Marijuana cultivation facility means an entity licensed to cultivate, prepare and package marijuana and sell marijuana to retail marijuana stores, to marijuana product manufacturing facilities and to other marijuana cultivation facilities, but not to consumers. 
    Marijuana establishment means a marijuana cultivation facility, a marijuana testing facility, a marijuana product manufacturing facility or a retail or wholesale marijuana store. 
    Marijuana product manufacturing facility means an entity licensed to purchase marijuana, manufacture, prepare and package marijuana products, and sell marijuana and marijuana products to other marijuana product manufacturing facilities and to retail marijuana stores, but not to consumers. 
    Marijuana products means concentrated marijuana products and marijuana products that are comprised of marijuana and other ingredients and are intended for use or consumption, such as, but not limited to, edible products, ointments and tinctures. 
    Marijuana testing facility means an entity licensed to analyze and certify the safety and potency of marijuana. 
    Medical marijuana center means an entity licensed by a state agency to sell marijuana and marijuana products pursuant to article XVIII, section 14 of the state constitution and the Colorado Medical Marijuana Code. 
    Retail marijuana store and wholesale marijuana store means an entity licensed to purchase marijuana from marijuana cultivation facilities and marijuana and marijuana products from marijuana product manufacturing facilities and to sell marijuana and marijuana products to consumers or other marijuana stores. 
    To publicly use, consume, ingest, display, possess, transfer, distribute or sell marijuana means doing any of those acts in a public place without a license to allow the same. A public place is any place on or in any street, alley, road, parking lot, sidewalk, park, stadium, ball park, gymnasium, business establishment, school facility or building, licensed liquor or alcoholic beverage store, licensed 3.2 percent alcohol beer store or 3.2 percent alcohol bar, licensed alcoholic beverage bar or specially licensed liquor and alcohol event, dormitory, arena, fairgrounds, public swimming pool, playground, cemetery, parking lot, building, jail or detention facility, hospital or nursing home, or part thereof, open to the public for business or governmental purposes. None of the prohibited acts may be done in a motor vehicle, motor home, camper or trailer or any other vehicle parked in or on the above public places. 
    Unreasonable or impracticable means that the measures necessary to comply with the regulations require such a high investment of risk, money, time or any other resource or asset that the operation of a marijuana establishment is not worthy of being carried out in practice by a reasonably prudent businessperson. 
(Code 2000, § 6-12-10; Ord. No. 1182, § 1, 2013) 
Sec. 8-214. - Prohibited acts. 
    No business license shall be issued by the city for the operation of any marijuana establishment, marijuana cultivation facility, marijuana product manufacturing facility, marijuana testing facility or retail or wholesale marijuana store within the city, and it shall be a violation of this article to operate such business in the city. 
(Code 2000, § 6-12-20; Ord. No. 1182, § 1, 2013) 
Secs. 8-215-8-228. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS 

Sec. 8-229. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Peddler means any person who travels within the city, conveying or transporting goods, wares or merchandise or offering or exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers. 
    Solicitor means any person who travels within the city soliciting, taking or attempting to take orders for sale or purchase of goods, wares or merchandise, including magazines, books, periodicals, real or personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, for services to be performed or for the donation of money or financial assistance, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such order, or whether or not such individual is collecting advance payment on such orders. The term "solicitor" includes any person who, for himself or herself, or for another person, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, motor vehicle, trailer, structure, tent, railroad boxcar, hotel room, lodginghouse, apartment, shop or other place within the city for the primary purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. 
    Transient merchant means any person, firm or corporation, whether as owner, agent or consignee, who engages in a temporary business of selling and delivering goods, wares, property, services and merchandise within the city, and who, in furtherance of said purpose, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, motor vehicle, trailer, tent, railroad car, hotel, motel, lodginghouse room, apartment, shop, street, alley or other place within the city, for the exhibition or sale of such goods, wares, services and merchandise, either privately or at public auction. The person so engaged is not relieved from complying with the provisions of this article by reason of associating temporarily with any local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer; provided, however, that if all sales made by such person of goods, wares, merchandise or services shall be reported for sales tax collection purposes to the city as made by such local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, and all monies derived from such sales shall be collected by such local dealer, trader, merchant or auctioneer, then such transient merchant shall be exempt from the provisions of this article. 
(Prior Code, § 14-29; Code 2000, § 6-7-10; Ord. No. 798, § 1; Ord. No. 814, § 1; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-230. - License requirement. 
    It is unlawful for any peddler, solicitor or transient merchant to engage in any such businesses within the city without first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Prior Code, § 14-29.1; Code 2000, § 6-7-20; Ord. No. 798, § 2) 
Sec. 8-231. - Exceptions to provisions. 
    The terms of this article do not include the acts of persons selling personal property at wholesale to dealers in such property, nor do such terms include the following professions or businesses: news sellers, state-licensed real estate and insurance salespersons and brokers, any public utility and its employees franchised to do business within the city, auto salespersons and any dissemination of information without solicitation of money or other consideration. This article shall not apply to any peddler, solicitor or transient merchant who is a bona fide resident of the counties of Kiowa, Prowers, Baca or Bent of the State of Colorado. Nothing contained in this article prohibits any sale required by statute or by order of any court or to prevent any person conducting a bona fide auction sale pursuant to law. 
(Prior Code, § 14-29.2; Code 2000, § 6-7-30; Ord. No. 814, § 3; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-232. - Contents of license application. 
(a)  Applicants for a license under this article shall file with the city clerk a sworn application, in writing, on a form to be furnished by the city clerk, which shall give the following information: 
(1)  Name, date of birth, Social Security number and physical description of the applicant; 
(2)  Complete permanent home and local address of the applicant, and in the case of a transient merchant, the local address from which proposed sales will be made; 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold by such applicant; 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials therefrom, establishing the exact relationship; 
(5)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(6)  The source of supply of the goods or property proposed to be sold, or orders taken for the sale thereof, where such goods or products are located at the time said application is filed, and the proposed method of delivery; 
(7)  A recent photograph of the applicant, which picture shall be approximately two inches by two inches, showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(8)  The name of at least two references who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or in lieu of the names of references, such other available evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant as will enable an investigator to properly evaluate such character and business responsibility; 
(9)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinances, other than traffic violations, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor; 
(10)  The last cities or towns, not to exceed three, where the applicant carried on business immediately preceding the date of application and the addresses from which such business was conducted in those municipalities; and 
(11)  A $500.00 surety bond. 
(b)  At the time of filing the application, a fee, as established by the city council, shall be paid to the city clerk, to cover the cost of investigation of the facts stated therein. There shall be no application fee for renewals in the immediately succeeding license period. 
(c)  Upon receipt of such application, it shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall immediately institute such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character as he or she deems necessary for the protection of the public good and shall endorse the application in the manner prescribed in this article within 72 hours, excluding weekends and holidays, after it has been filed with the city clerk by the applicant. 
(d)  If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on such application his or her disapproval and his or her reasons for the same, and return the application to the city clerk, who shall notify the applicant that his or her application is disapproved and that no license shall be issued. 
(e)  If, as a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his or her approval and return the application to the city clerk, who shall, upon payment of the prescribed license fees, deliver to the applicant his or her license. Such license shall contain the signature of the issuing officer, show the name and address of the licensee, the kinds of goods to be sold thereunder, and contain the following wording: "The City of Lamar, Colorado, does not endorse the products of licensee," the amount of fee paid, the date of issuance and the length of time the same shall be operative, as well as the license number and identifying description of any vehicle used in such licensed business. Each peddler, solicitor or transient merchant must secure a personal license. The city clerk shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued hereunder. 
(Prior Code, § 14-29.3; Code 2000, § 6-7-40; Ord. No. 798, §§ 4, 5; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-233. - License fee. 
    Every applicant for a license under the provisions of this article shall pay a fee as established by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 14-29.4; Code 2000, § 6-7-50; Ord. No. 798, § 6; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 8-234-8-247. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - VEHICLES FOR HIRE 

Sec. 8-248. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of this article, the term "for hire" means for money or other things of value, gratuities, tips and free will offerings, whether paid directly or indirectly, as compensation or consideration for services rendered. The applicability of these provisions includes the term "motor carrier of passengers" as defined by C.R.S. § 40-101(4)(a), as may be amended. 
(Prior Code, § 23-1; Code 2000, § 6-8-10; Ord. No. 346, § 1; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-249. - License required. 
    No person shall carry on the business of operating a vehicle for hire in the carrying of passengers on the streets of the city without first obtaining a license therefor. As a condition of maintaining a city license, the person shall be licensed as provided by the state. 
(Prior Code, § 23-2; Code 2000, § 6-8-20; Ord. No. 328, § 1) 
Sec. 8-250. - License issuance, fee and transferability. 
    The city council, within its discretion, may issue a license for the carrying on of the business of operating vehicles for hire for the transportation of passengers within the city to any person deemed by the city council to be properly qualified for such, upon the payment of an annual fee as established by the city council. Such license shall be issued to the proprietor of such business and shall not be transferable. 
(Prior Code, § 23-3; Code 2000, § 6-8-30; Ord. No. 328, § 2; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-251. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
    The city council shall have the right to suspend or cancel any license granted under this article for the violation of any rules or regulations promulgated pursuant to this article, and to suspend or cancel any license for the infraction of any provision of this Code or any other ordinance of the city or state law with reference to the operation of motor vehicles on the streets of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 23-4; Code 2000, § 6-8-40; Ord. No. 328, § 4; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-252. - Requirements for state vehicle permit. 
    No person shall operate under a license issued pursuant to this article unless such person holds a permit granted by the state public utilities commission for the use and operation of the vehicle to be used in the city. 
(Prior Code, § 23-5; Code 2000, § 6-8-50; Ord. No. 328, § 3; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-253. - Promulgation of regulations and rate schedules. 
    The city council shall have the right to make rules and regulations governing the operation of taxicabs and vehicles for hire within the city and the rates charged therefor to passengers. 
(Prior Code, § 23-6; Code 2000, § 6-8-60; Ord. No. 328, § 4) 
Secs. 8-254-8-267. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - MISCELLANEOUS LICENSES 

Sec. 8-268. - Auctioneers. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Auctioneer means any person who engages in the business of auctioning off real or personal property, whether on a full-time or part-time basis. 
    Resident auctioneer means any person who has resided in the city for six months immediately preceding his or her application, and who has, during such six-month period, been engaged in business or otherwise gainfully employed in the city. 
    Transient or itinerant auctioneer means any auctioneer who has resided in the city for less than six months immediately preceding his or her application for a license. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any auctioneer to engage in the business of making sales at auction within the city to which the public is invited, without first securing a license therefor and paying the required license fee. 
(c)  The license fee for an itinerant or transient auctioneer shall be as established by the city council. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to auctioneers when engaged in making sales under and by virtue of legal proceedings, or when making sales for any bona fide residents of the city who are selling out or when selling livestock at any regularly established sales yard. 
(e)  Any license issued hereunder is personal and cannot be transferred. 
(Prior Code, § 14-15; Code 2000, § 6-9-10; Ord. No. 260, § 3; Ord. No. 426, § 1; Ord. No. 561, §§ 1-5; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-269. - Bankruptcy sales. 
    Exclusive dealers in bankrupt goods shall pay a license fee as established by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 14-17; Code 2000, § 6-9-20; Ord. No. 260, § 11; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-270. - Billiard parlors. 
    Any operator of any billiard or pool parlor for gain or profit shall pay an annual license fee as established by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 14-18; Code 2000, § 6-9-30; Ord. No. 260, § 11; Ord. No. 270, § 2; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-271. - Bowling alleys. 
    Every person operating any bowling alley shall pay an annual license fee as established by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 14-19; Code 2000, § 6-9-40; Ord. No. 260, § 39; Ord. No. 808, § 7; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-272. - Employment agents. 
    Every employment agent or person operating an employment agency shall pay a license fee as established by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 14-21; Code 2000, § 6-9-50; Ord. No. 260, § 18; Ord. No. 808, § 8; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-273. - Fortune-telling and like practices. 
    Every clairvoyant or fortune-teller engaging in such practice within the city shall pay a license fee as established by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 14-22; Code 2000, § 6-9-60; Ord. No. 260, § 17; Ord. No. 751, § 1; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-274. - Hotels, motels, roominghouses. 
(a)  The license fee for conducting a hotel, roominghouse, lodginghouse or cottage camp shall be as established by the city council. 
(b)  The city council shall have full power to grant, deny, renew, transfer, suspend during investigation and revoke after notice and hearing the license provided for in this section. Before any license shall be granted or transferred, an application for such license shall be filed with the city council by the applicant for such license, or other person who desires a transfer, stating the location, giving the street number in the city and the number of rooms contained in the hotel, motel, lodginghouse or cottage camp. 
(c)  If the city council concludes after investigation that the applicant is not a person of suitable character to conduct a hotel, roominghouse, lodginghouse or cottage camp, it may deny a license to the applicant, or if the city council finds, after such license has been granted, that the person to whom it has been assigned is conducting said premises, or any activity or conduct therein, in a manner which is in violation of this Code or the state statutes, the city council shall have the power to suspend during investigation, and revoke after notice and hearing, any license which has been granted. 
(d)  Any person, either as principal, agent, clerk or servant, who carries on the business of conducting any hotel, roominghouse, motel, lodginghouse or tourist or cottage camp, shall keep a register of all guests, and every guest shall be required to register before obtaining room or sleeping accommodations. Said register of guests required to be kept by this section shall be made available at all times for inspection by any law enforcement officer of the city, at the request of such officer. 
(Prior Code, § 14-23; Code 2000, § 6-9-70; Ord. No. 260, §§ 32-36; Ord. No. 432, § 1; Ord. No. 808, § 9; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-275. - Manufacturer's agents. 
    Any manufacturer's agent who stores or distributes goods at retail within the city, without a definitely established location, shall pay a license fee as established by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 14-26; Code 2000, § 6-9-80; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-276. - Miniature golf courses. 
    Every person operating any miniature or baby golf course shall pay an annual license fee as established by the city council. Such license fee shall be paid quarterly in advance. 
(Prior Code, § 14-27; Code 2000, § 6-9-90; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-277. - Mobile concessions. 
    Every person operating a mobile concession shall pay a license fee as established by the city council. Mobile concessions are not permitted to sell at the ballparks, community building or swimming pool. 
(Code 2000, § 6-9-100; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 8-278. - Pawnbrokers. 
    Every pawnbroker or person operating a pawn shop shall pay a license fee as established by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 14-28; Code 2000, § 6-9-110; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Chapter 10 - EMERGENCY SERVICES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Ambulance service; rates and charges generally. 
    Rates and charges for all ambulance services furnished by the city shall be established by city council, which rates and charges shall become effective concurrently with changes in levels of repayment and reimbursement by third parties, including governmental agencies, in order to best maintain the financial integrity of the ambulance service and to avoid subsidization of said service by other funds of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 2-13-10; Ord. No. 959, § 1, 1996; Ord. No. 965, § 1, 1996; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 10-2. - Annual reports. 
    The fire chief and city treasurer shall, no later than October 1 of each year, make reports to the city council as to rates and charges for ambulance services then in effect, and further report upon the financial condition of the ambulance service provided by the city. 
(Code 2000, § 2-13-20; Ord. No. 959, § 2, 1996; Ord. No. 965, § 2, 1996) 
Secs. 10-3-10-16. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 10-17. - Creation; composition. 
    There is hereby created a police department for the city, which shall consist of one chief of police and as many police officers as may from time to time be deemed necessary for the safety and good order of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 2-4-10; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 10-18. - Departmental regulations. 
    The police department shall be operated and managed in accordance with such departmental rules and regulations as may from time to time be proposed by the chief of police, and approved by the city administrator. 
(Code 2000, § 2-4-20; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 10-19. - Chief of police; appointment and duties. 
(a)  The city council, upon the recommendation of the city administrator, shall appoint a chief of police who shall be the head of the police department. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to: 
(1)  See that the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state are duly enforced and the rules and regulations of the police department obeyed, and perform such duties as may be required by the city council. 
(2)  Direct the operations of the police department, subject to the rules and regulations thereof. 
(3)  Arrest any person violating any of the city ordinances and take such violator before the municipal court for trial. 
(4)  Render such accounts of the police department, his or her duties and receipts as may be required by the city council, and keep the records of his or her office open to inspection by the city council at any time, subject to any applicable privilege. 
(b)  Before entering upon the duties of such office, the chief of police shall take and subscribe to an oath that he or she will support the Constitution of the United States, the constitution and laws of the state and ordinances of the city, and that he or she will faithfully perform the duties of the office upon which he or she is about to enter. 
(Code 2000, § 2-4-30; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 10-20. - Duties of police officers. 
    All members of the police department shall have powers and duties as follows: 
(1)  They shall perform all duties required by the chief of police. 
(2)  They shall be the enforcement officers of the city and shall see that the provisions of the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state are complied with. They shall arrest without process all persons engaged in the violation in their presence of any provision of the ordinances of the city or the laws of the state. 
(3)  They shall execute and return all writs and processes to them directed by the municipal judge in any case arising under a city ordinance, and they may serve the same in any part of the county. 
(Code 2000, § 2-4-40; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 10-21. - Lost, abandoned and recovered stolen property. 
(a)  Custody of property. 
(1)  The chief of police and/or his or her designee has custody of all lost, abandoned and recovered stolen personal property coming into the possession of the city. The chief of police shall keep a record of all property taken into custody, and shall, pending disposal of the property, cause the property to be stored on property owned or leased by the city or with a private person engaged in the business of storing personal property. 
(2)  If the finder of lost, abandoned or stolen property is an officer or employee of the city and takes possession of such property, the city shall be deemed the finder and the property shall be placed in the custody of the chief of police. 
(3)  Whenever a private person brings property that the person has found to any city employee, the property shall be placed in the custody of the chief of police. Upon the finder's making a report concerning the location and circumstances of the finding, the chief of police shall issue a receipt for the property, which shall declare the finder's contingent right to reclaim the possession thereof. 
(4)  Upon coming into possession of such personal property, the chief shall make reasonable efforts to ascertain the ownership of the property. 
(5)  If the chief of police ascertains the owner of lost, abandoned or stolen personal property, except a motor vehicle, the chief of police shall give notice in writing to the owner that the property is in the possession of the police department, that it may now be reclaimed, and that it will be sold or otherwise disposed of by the city unless the owner reclaims the property in the manner prescribed by law within 60 days after the date the notice is deposited in the mail, postage prepaid, to the owner at the owner's last-known address. 
(6)  If the owner of the lost, abandoned, or stolen personal property cannot be ascertained by the chief of police, the chief of police shall periodically, and not less than once each year, cause notice containing the following information to be published for three consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the city: 
a.  A description of the lost, abandoned or stolen personal property then in possession of the chief of police; and 
b.  A statement that the property will be disposed of by the city unless the owner thereof reclaims the property in the manner provided for by law within ten days after the last publication of the notice. 
(b)  Immediate disposal permitted. The chief of police may immediately dispose of any property that reasonably appears to pose a sanitary or health hazard if stored and shall keep a log describing all property disposed of for these reasons. 
(c)  Disposition of property other than motor vehicles. 
(1)  If, at any time prior to the city's disposition of any found personal property, except a motor vehicle, in the manner provided by this section, a person claims to be the property owner, the chief of police shall return the property to such claimant if the claimant submits written evidence of ownership that is sufficient to satisfy the chief of police that the claim is rightful and if the claimant pays the city for all reasonable costs incurred by the city in obtaining possession of the property, storing the property and publishing or mailing notice related to the property. 
(2)  If an apparent owner has not made claim to the property by the expiration of the time period set forth in the mailed or published notice, the finder of record shall be notified by mail that the finder has ten days to claim the property. If, within the ten-day period, the finder makes a demand for the property and tenders payment to the city for all reasonable costs incurred by the city in connection with the possession, storage and publication and mailing of notices regarding the property, the property shall be returned to the finder. 
(3)  If the found personal property remains unclaimed after the time following the notice as required in subsection (c)(2) of this section, the city administrator shall cause the property to be disposed of by sale, unless the city administrator decides that the property can be used by the city. 
(4)  If property is to be disposed of by sale, the city administrator shall: 
a.  Cause a notice of such sale to be published for three consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the city setting forth the date, time and place of the sale; a description of the property to be sold; and a statement that the property will be sold at public auction to the highest bidder for cash. 
b.  At the date and place designated for the sale of the lost, abandoned or recovered stolen personal property described in the notice of sale, cause the property to be sold at public auction to the highest bidder for cash. If a bid is not made for the article of personal property offered at such sale, the article shall become the property of the city. 
c.  Upon consummation of the sale, the individual exhibiting a receipt of sale to the chief of police shall be entitled to possession of the article purchased. 
d.  The proceeds of the sale shall first be applied to the costs of keeping, providing notice, storage and sale, and the balance shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(5)  There is no right of redemption from a sale and conveyance of the lost, abandoned or recovered property. 
(d)  Disposition of motor vehicles. Motor vehicles shall be disposed of according to the provisions and procedures set out in C.R.S. § 42-4-1801 et seq., for abandoned vehicles on public property; and C.R.S. § 42-4-2101 et seq., for vehicles abandoned on private property. 
(e)  Holding property as evidence. If the city attorney, district attorney or other person charged with the duty of prosecuting violations of the city, state, or federal laws requests that any of the lost, abandoned or recovered stolen personal property be held by the chief of police because it is required in a criminal prosecution, the chief of police shall retain custody and shall not sell the property until written notice is received that the property is no longer needed for prosecution purposes. 
(Code 2000, § 2-4-50; Ord. No. 1139, § 1, 2009) 
Secs. 10-22-10-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SERVICE 

Sec. 10-36. - Creation. 
    The mayor and the city clerk are hereby authorized and directed to execute and enter into an intergovernmental agreement creating an emergency telephone authority, which agreement shall include the city, the county, and all other cities, towns, special districts and other emergency response authorities located within the county. 
(Code 2000, § 5-3-10; Ord. No. 916, § 1, 1993; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 10-37. - Charges. 
    Pursuant to C.R.S. § 29-11-102(2) and (3), there is hereby imposed a charge in an amount not to exceed $0.70 per month per exchange access facility, as defined within said statute, upon all telephone exchange access facilities located within the corporate limits of the city. No such charge shall be imposed upon more than 100 exchange access facilities or their equivalent, per customer billing; and, further, such charge shall not be imposed upon any state or local governmental entity. 
(Code 2000, § 5-3-20; Ord. No. 916, § 2, 1993) 
Sec. 10-38. - Administration.
