(c)  The possession or consumption of ethyl alcohol shall not constitute a violation of this section if such possession or consumption takes place for religious purposes protected by the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. 
(d)  Prima facie evidence of a violation of subsection (a) of this section shall consist of: 
(1)  Evidence that the defendant was under the age of 21 years and possessed or consumed ethyl alcohol anywhere in the city; or 
(2)  Evidence that the defendant was under the age of 21 years and manifested any of the characteristics commonly associated with ethyl alcohol intoxication or impairment while present anywhere in the city. 
(e)  During any trial for a violation of subsection (a) of this section, any bottle, can or other container with labeling indicating the contents of such bottle, can or container shall be admissible into evidence, and the information contained on any label on such bottle, can or other container shall not constitute hearsay. A jury or a judge, whichever is appropriate, may consider the information upon such label in determining whether the contents of the bottle, can or other container were composed in whole or in part of ethyl alcohol. A label which identifies the contents of any bottle, can or other container as "beer," "ale," "malt beverage," "fermented malt beverage," "malt liquor," "wine," "champagne," "whiskey" or "whisky," "gin," "vodka," "tequila," "schnapps," "brandy," "cognac," "liqueur," "cordial," "alcohol" or "liquor" shall constitute prima facie evidence that the contents of the bottle, can or other container were composed in whole or in part of ethyl alcohol. 
(f)  A parent or legal guardian of a person under 21 years of age, or any natural person who has the permission of such parent or legal guardian, may give, or permit the possession and consumption of, ethyl alcohol to or by a person under the age of 21 years under the conditions described in subsection (b)(1) of this section. This subsection shall not be construed to permit any establishment which is or is required to be licensed pursuant to C.R.S. title 12, art. 46, 47 or 48, or any members, employees or occupants of any such establishment to give, provide, make available or sell ethyl alcohol to a person under 21 years of age. 
(Prior Code, § 17-20; Code 2000, § 10-6-40; Ord. No. 434, § 1; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-51. - Sales near schools. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell, offer or expose for sale or gift any fermented malt beverage or any vinous, spirituous or malt liquors within a distance of 500 feet from any private, public or parochial school, said distance to be computed by direct measurement from the nearest property lines. However, this prohibition shall not affect the rights of any person holding a lawful permit or license to conduct such business within the restricted area hereby established; nor shall this prohibition prevent the renewal, upon the expiration thereof, of any license in effect at such time authorizing such business within the restricted area hereby established. 
(Code 2000, § 10-6-50; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-52. - Alcoholic beverages in certain places. 
(a)  No person shall carry or have any open containers of alcoholic beverages on any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place, in any automobile or on the grounds or in the facilities of any public or private school, college or university, except where authorized by the governing authority of such institution. 
(b)  No person shall drink any alcoholic beverages in or on any of the places enumerated in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  The foregoing prohibitions shall not apply to any place duly licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(Code 2000, § 10-6-60; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-53. - Open container. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to possess or consume by open container any alcoholic beverage, whether such possession is actual or constructive, in any public place as defined in section 14-156, upon property owned, operated, leased or maintained by the state or any political subdivision or agency thereof, or upon property owned, operated, leased or maintained by the city; provided, however, that it shall not be a violation of this provision to store or consume any alcoholic beverage in conformance with, and pursuant to the terms of, any validly issued permit or license. 
(b)  In the event that any violation of this section is alleged to have occurred in a motor vehicle under circumstances such that the complaining party to such incident is unable to identify the person alleged to have possessed or consumed malt, vinous or spirituous liquor or fermented malt beverages, it shall be presumed that the operator of said motor vehicle is in violation of the provisions of this section. 
(c)  It shall be an exception to this section if the owner or person in possession or control of such property has given express or implied consent to the possession and consumption of malt, vinous and spirituous liquor or fermented malts beverage upon said premises. 
(Code 2000, § 10-6-70; Ord. No. 925, § 2, 1993; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-54. - Special permit. 
    The city administrator may grant permission to persons to consume any malt, vinous or spirituous liquor or fermented malt beverage on publicly-owned property for special functions, including, but not limited to, athletic events, artistic events, cultural events, receptions, street closure events or civic events. 
(Code 2000, § 10-6-80; Ord. No. 925, § 4, 1993; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-55. - Abusing toxic vapors. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "toxic vapors" means the following substances or products containing such substances: alcohols, including methyl, isopropyl, propyl or butyl; aliphatic acetates, including ethyl, methyl, propyl or methyl cellosolve acetate; acetone; benzene; carbon tetrachloride; cyclohexane; freon, including freon 11 and freon 12; hexane; methyl ethyl ketone; methyl isobutyl ketone; naphtha; perchlorethylene; toluene; trichloroethane or xylene. 
(b)  No person shall knowingly smell or inhale the fumes of toxic vapors for the purpose of causing a condition of euphoria, excitement, exhilaration, stupefaction or dulled senses of the nervous system. No person shall knowingly possess, buy or use any such substance for the purposes described in this section. This subsection shall not apply to the inhalation of anesthesia for medical or dental purposes. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person knowingly to sell, offer for sale, deliver or give away to any other person any substance or product releasing toxic vapors, where the seller, offeror or deliverer knows or has reason to believe that such substance will be used for the purpose of inducing a condition of euphoria, excitement, exhilaration, stupefaction or dulled senses of the nervous system. 
(d)  In a prosecution for a violation of this section, evidence that a container lists one or more of the substances described in subsection (a) of this section as one of its ingredients shall be prima facie evidence that the substance in such container contains toxic vapors and emits the fumes thereof. 
(Code 2000, § 10-6-110; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, C.R.S. § 18-18-412. 
Sec. 14-56. - Definition of drug paraphernalia. 
    The term "drug paraphernalia" means all equipment, products and materials of any kind which are used, intended for use or designated for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing into the human body a controlled substance in violation of the laws of the state or city. The term "drug paraphernalia" includes, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Testing equipment used, intended for use or designed for use in identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness or purity of controlled substances under circumstances in violation of the laws of the state or city; 
(2)  Scales and balances used, intended for use or designated for use in weighing or measuring controlled substances; 
(3)  Separation gins and sifters used, intended for use or designed for use in removing twigs and seeds from or otherwise cleaning or refining marijuana; 
(4)  Blenders, bowls, containers, spoons and mixing devices used, intended for use or designed for use in packaging small quantities of controlled substances; 
(5)  Capsules, balloons, envelopes and other containers used, intended for use or designed for use in packaging small quantities of controlled substances; 
(6)  Containers and other objects used, intended for use or designed for use in storing or concealing controlled substances; or 
(7)  Objects used, intended for use or designed for use in ingesting, inhaling or otherwise introducing a controlled substance into the human body, such as: 
a.  Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic or ceramic pipes with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads or punctured metal bowls; 
b.  Water pipes; 
c.  Carburetion tubes and devices; 
d.  Smoking and carburetion masks; 
e.  Roach clips, meaning objects used to hold burning material, such as a marijuana cigarette that has become too small or too short to be held in the hand; 
f.  Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials; 
g.  Chamber pipes; 
h.  Carburetor pipes; 
i.  Electric pipes; 
j.  Air-driven pipes; 
k.  Chillums; 
l.  Bongs; or 
m.  Ice pipes or chillers. 
(Code 2000, § 10-12-10; Ord. No. 1155, § 1, 2010; Ord. No. 1166, § 1, 2010) 
State Law reference- Definition of drug paraphernalia, C.R.S. § 18-18-426. 
Sec. 14-57. - Definition of marijuana. 
    The term "marijuana" shall have the meaning as set forth in C.R.S. § 18-18-102(18). 
(Code 2000, § 10-12-20; Ord. No. 1155, § 1, 2010; Ord. No. 1166, § 1, 2010) 
Sec. 14-58. - Drug paraphernalia; determination considerations. 
    In determining whether an object is drug paraphernalia, a court, in its discretion, may consider, in addition to all other relevant factors, the following: 
(1)  Statements by an owner or by anyone in control of the object concerning its use; 
(2)  The proximity of the object to controlled substances; 
(3)  The existence of any residue of controlled substances on the object. 
(Code 2000, § 10-12-30; Ord. No. 1155, § 1, 2010; Ord. No. 1166, § 1, 2010) 
Sec. 14-59. - Illegal possession of drug paraphernalia by an underage person. 
(a)  No person who is under the age of 21 years shall be in possession of drug paraphernalia or marijuana accessories. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any person who possesses drug paraphernalia or marijuana accessories in compliance with section 14 of article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution, Medical marijuana, and the implementing state statutes and state regulations concerning medical marijuana. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any person 21 years of age or older who possesses drug paraphernalia or marijuana accessories and in compliance with the state constitution, article XVIII, section 16, and the implementing state statutes and state regulations concerning personal use of marijuana. 
(Code 2000, § 10-12-40; Ord. No. 1155, § 1, 2010; Ord. No. 1166, § 1, 2010; Ord. No. 1195, pt. 1, 2015) 
Sec. 14-60. - Manufacture, sale or delivery of drug paraphernalia; penalty. 
    No person shall sell or deliver, possess with intent to sell or deliver or manufacture with intent to sell or deliver equipment, products or materials, knowing, or under circumstances where one reasonably should know, that such equipment, products or materials could be used as drug paraphernalia. 
(Code 2000, § 10-12-50; Ord. No. 1155, § 1, 2010; Ord. No. 1166, § 1, 2010) 
Sec. 14-61. - Advertisement of drug paraphernalia; penalty. 
    No person shall place an advertisement in any newspaper, magazine, handbill or other publication and who intends thereby to promote the sale of equipment, products or materials designed and intended for use as drug paraphernalia. 
(Code 2000, § 10-12-60; Ord. No. 1155, § 1, 2010; Ord. No. 1166, § 1, 2010) 
Sec. 14-62. - Unlawful possession of marijuana. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person who is 21 years of age or older to possess, transport, transfer, or use more than one ounce of marijuana for personal use. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to possess, use, transfer, or transport any amount of marijuana for personal use except as described in subsection (f) of this section. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person within one residence or dwelling who is 21 years of age or older to possess, grow, transport, or process more than six marijuana plants, only three of which shall be maturing flowering plants, for personal use. The growing of said marijuana plants shall take place in an enclosed locked facility and shall not be grown openly or publicly. 
(d)  It is unlawful for any person under the age of 21 to grow marijuana plants except as described in subsection (f) of this section. 
(e)  It is unlawful for any person who is 21 years of age or older to transfer more than one ounce of marijuana to another person or to transfer any marijuana for remuneration or to transfer any marijuana to any person under 21 years of age. 
(f)  The provisions of subsections (a) through (e) of this section shall not apply to any person who possesses, grows, transports, or transfers marijuana in compliance with the state constitution, Medical marijuana, section 14 of article XVIII, provided that the possession, growing, use, transfer, or transport of the medical marijuana is not in plain view or done in a public place. 
(g)  The municipal court may utilize treatment, probation, or deferred sentencing for any person who violates any provision of this section. 
(Code 2000, § 10-12-70; Ord. No. 1155, § 1, 2010; Ord. No. 1166, § 1, 2010; Ord. No. 1195, pt. 2, 2015) 
Sec. 14-63. - Open marijuana container prohibited in a vehicle or in a public place. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to have or carry any open container of marijuana on any street, road, highway, sidewalk, alley or in any other place open to the public, or in any motor vehicle or other means of conveyance, or in any building or grounds open to the public, except where authorized by law. 
(b)  The term "open container of marijuana" means any receptacle, container or marijuana accessory that contains any amount of marijuana and that has no personal marijuana dispensary seal, or said seal is broken. If the violation takes place in a motor vehicle under circumstances where the complaining party is unable to identify the person possessing the marijuana or container, the operator of the vehicle shall be presumed to have violated the provisions of this section. 
(Code 2000, § 10-12-80; Ord. No. 1155, § 1, 2010; Ord. No. 1166, § 1, 2010; Ord. No. 1195, pt. 3, 2015) 
Sec. 14-64. - Unlawful manufacture of hash oil. 
    It shall be unlawful to manufacture hash oil anywhere within the city by use of solvents containing compressed flammable gases, including, but not limited to, butane. 
(Code 2000, § 10-12-90; Ord. No. 1195, pt. 4, 2015) 
Sec. 14-65. - Public consumption. 
    It is unlawful for any person to consume marijuana or marijuana products in a public place. 
Sec. 14-66. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, corporation, partnership, limited liability company, company, association of persons, for profit or not for profit, to operate any marijuana establishment, marijuana cultivation facility, marijuana product manufacturing facility, marijuana testing facility or retail or wholesale marijuana store within the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, corporation, partnership, limited liability company, company or association of persons, for profit or not for profit, knowingly to possess, use, display, purchase, transport, transfer, store, warehouse, cultivate, sell or distribute to another or to a consumer or any other person or entity, more than one ounce of marijuana for personal use. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, corporation, partnership, limited liability company, company or association of persons, for profit or not for profit, knowingly and openly, in a public place, to publicly use for any purpose, consume, ingest, display, possess, transfer, distribute or sell marijuana to a consumer or to any other person or entity. 
(Code 2000, § 6-12-20; Ord. No. 1182, § 1, 2013) 
Secs. 14-67-14-78. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GOVERNMENT AND PUBLIC OFFICERS 

Sec. 14-79. - Obstructing government operations. 
(a)  It is unlawful to obstruct government operations. 
(b)  A person commits obstructing government operations if he or she intentionally obstructs, impairs or hinders the performance of a governmental function by a public official, employee or servant, by using or threatening to use violence, force or physical interference or obstacles. 
(Code 2000, § 10-1-20; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, C.R.S. § 18-8-102. 
Sec. 14-80. - Impersonating a peace officer. 
    No person shall impersonate a police officer or any other officer of the city by wearing any star, badge or other emblem of office or in any other manner. 
(Prior Code, § 17-9; Code 2000, § 10-1-30; Ord. No. 87, § 12; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, C.R.S. § 18-8-113. 
Sec. 14-81. - Obstructing a peace officer or firefighter. 
(a)  No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order, signal or direction of a police officer made or given in the discharge of the police officer's duties. 
(b)  No person shall, in any way, interfere with or hinder any police officer who is discharging or apparently discharging the duties of the position. 
(c)  It is unlawful to obstruct a peace officer or firefighter. 
(d)  A person commits obstructing a peace officer or firefighter when, by using or threatening to use violence, force or physical interference or obstacles, such person knowingly obstructs, impairs or hinders the enforcement of the law or the preservation of the peace by a peace officer acting under color of his or her official authority, or knowingly obstructs, impairs or hinders the prevention, control or abatement of fire by a firefighter acting under color of his or her official authority. 
(e)  It is no defense to a prosecution under this section that the peace officer was acting in an illegal manner, if the peace officer was acting under color of his or her official authority as defined in section 14-5(c). 
(f)  This section does not apply to obstruction, impairment or hindrance of the making of an arrest. 
(Prior Code, § 17-18; Code 2000, § 10-1-40; Ord. No. 87, § 12; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, C.R.S. § 18-8-104. 
Sec. 14-82. - Resisting arrest. 
(a)  It is unlawful to resist arrest. 
(b)  A person commits resisting arrest if he or she knowingly prevents or attempts to prevent a peace officer acting under color of his or her official authority from effecting an arrest of the actor or another by: 
(1)  Using or threatening to use physical force or violence against the peace officer or another; or 
(2)  Using any other means which creates a substantial risk of causing physical injury to the peace officer or another. 
(c)  A peace officer acts under color of his or her official authority when, in the regular course of assigned duties, the peace officer is called upon to make, and does make, a judgment in good faith based upon surrounding facts and circumstances that an arrest should be made by the peace officer. 
(Code 2000, § 10-1-50; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, C.R.S. § 18-8-103. 
Sec. 14-83. - Assisting in escape of prisoners. 
    No person shall effect the escape or in any manner assist in effecting the escape or make any attempt to effect the escape of any person from the jail or any other place where any such person shall have been incarcerated by virtue of this Code or any other ordinance of the city or any judgment rendered thereunder without having the permission of the appropriate custodian of the jail or incarceration facility. No person shall hold communication with any person so incarcerated by conversation or otherwise without the permission of the appropriate custodian of the jail or incarceration facility, or furnish or deliver or cause to be delivered or furnished to any such person so incarcerated any food, drink or any other thing. 
(Prior Code, § 17-26; Code 2000, § 10-1-60; Ord. No. 87, § 13; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, C.R.S. § 18-8-201 et seq. 
Sec. 14-84. - False reporting to authorities. 
    It is unlawful for a person to falsely report to authorities. A person commits false reporting to authorities if he or she: 
(1)  Knowingly causes a false alarm of fire or other emergency to be transmitted to or within an official or volunteer fire department, ambulance service or any other government agency which deals with emergencies involving danger to life or property; 
(2)  Makes a report or knowingly causes the transmission of a report to law enforcement authorities of a crime or other incident within their official concern when he or she knows that it did not occur; or 
(3)  Makes a report or knowingly causes the transmission of a report to law enforcement authorities pretending to furnish information relating to an offense or other incident within their official concern when he or she knows that he or she has no such information or knows that the information is false. 
(Code 2000, § 10-1-70; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
State Law reference- Similar provision, C.R.S. § 18-8-111. 
Sec. 14-85. - Duty of citizens to aid police officers. 
    A person, 18 years of age or older, shall, upon command by a person known to him or her to be a peace officer, take reasonable steps to provide aid to the peace officer in effecting or securing an arrest or preventing the commission by another of any offense. 
(Code 2000, § 10-1-80; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 14-86-14-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIREWORKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation by local governments, C.R.S. § 24-33.5-2007. 

Sec. 14-100. - Definitions. 
(a)  For purposes of this article, the term "fireworks" means any article, device or substance prepared for the primary purpose of producing a visual or auditory sensation by combustion, explosion, deflagration or detonation, and shall specifically include, without limitation, any such article, device or substance which produces an explosive report and/or is or causes a projectile into the air or along the earth. 
(b)  The term "fireworks" does not include the following: 
(1)  Toy caps which do not contain more than 0.25 of a grain of explosive compound per cap; 
(2)  Highway flares, railroad fuses, ship distress signals, smoke candles and other emergency signal devices; 
(3)  Educational rockets and toy propellant device type engines used in such rockets when such rockets are of nonmetallic construction and utilize replaceable engines or model cartridges containing less than two ounces of propellant, and when such engines or model cartridges are designed to be ignited by electrical means; 
(4)  Fireworks which are used in testing or research by a licensed explosives laboratory; or 
(5)  Any device defined in C.R.S. § 24-33.5-2001(11) as permissible fireworks. 
(Code 2000, § 10-7-10; Ord. No. 971, § 2, 1996; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-101. - Sale prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any fireworks within the corporate limits of the city. Persons desiring to sell exempted items as described in section 14-100(b) shall first obtain a permit for the sale of said items. Application for a permit to sell such fireworks from any temporary location shall be made by June 15 of each year, and shall be made to the fire chief. A permit fee, as established by the city council, shall be charged for each sales location proposed and shall be paid to the city clerk. Fifty percent of the permit fee shall be refunded to the applicant if the site of sale of such items is cleaned of all stands, refuse and debris constructed or caused by said sale to the satisfaction of the fire chief by July 10 of each year. No permit granted hereunder shall be transferable. City sales tax shall be collected and remitted to the city in respect of all sales at such locations. 
(Code 2000, § 10-7-20; Ord. No. 971, § 3, 1996; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-102. - Possession or discharge of fireworks. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to light, set off, detonate or discharge any fireworks within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to possess fireworks with the intention to light, set off, detonate or discharge the same within the corporate limits of the city. 
(c)  A person acts with intent when his or her conscious objective is to cause the specific result proscribed by this article, being the lighting, setting off, detonation, or discharge of any fireworks within the city. It is immaterial to the issue of specific intent whether or not the result actually occurred. 
(Code 2000, § 10-7-30; Ord. No. 971, § 4, 1996) 
Sec. 14-103. - Displays. 
    The fire chief is hereby authorized to grant supervised public displays of fireworks at any time by fair associations, civic groups and other organizations or groups of individuals. Every display shall be handled by a qualified operator who shall be approved by the fire chief. Every display shall be of such a character and located in a manner which, in the opinion of the fire chief, does not present a hazard to or endanger any person or property. 
(Code 2000, § 10-7-40; Ord. No. 971, § 5, 1996; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-104. - Seizure or confiscation. 
    The chief of police may seize, take, confiscate, and remove all items, articles and stocks of fireworks possessed or utilized by any person in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 2000, § 10-7-50; Ord. No. 971, § 6, 1996; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 14-105-14-118. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MINORS 

Sec. 14-119. - Curfew. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any child under the age of 18 years to be in or on any public street, highway, road, alley, park, playground, public grounds, public building, vacant lot or other public place within the city between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 5:00 a.m. of the following day, except in pursuit of lawful employment, or unless there exists a reasonable necessity therefor, or unless such child is accompanied by a parent, guardian or other person of the age of 21 years or more having specific permission of a parent or guardian to have the custody of the child at the time, provided that on Friday and Saturday nights, the curfew hours for children 15 through 17 years old shall be extended to 1:00 a.m. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any child under the age of 15 years to be in or on any public street, highway, road, alley, park, playground, public grounds, public building, vacant lot or other public place within the city between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. of the following day, except in pursuit of lawful employment, or unless there exists a reasonable necessity therefor, or unless such child is accompanied by a parent, guardian or other person of the age of 21 years or more having specific permission of a parent or guardian to have the custody of the child at the time. 
(Prior Code, § 17-5.1; Code 2000, § 10-5-10; Ord. No. 608, § 1; Ord. No. 757, § 1; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-120. - Arrested child to be taken home. 
    In addition to any other powers he or she may have, any law enforcement officer of the city arresting a child for the violation of any provision hereof is empowered to take such child home and to demand that a parent, guardian or other person having the right to custody of such child take such child home. It is unlawful for any such parent, guardian or other person to fail or refuse to take such child home after demand has so been made upon him or her. 
(Prior Code, § 17-5.3; Code 2000, § 10-5-20; Ord. No. 608, § 3; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-121. - Aiding, abetting of minor. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to knowingly aid, abet, approve, encourage, allow, permit, tolerate or consent to the violation by any minor child of any provision of this article or any ordinances of the city. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any parent, guardian or other person having the care and custody of any child under the age of 18 years to allow or permit any such child to be in or on any public street, highway, alley, park, playground, public grounds, public building, vacant lot or other public place within the city between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 5:00 a.m. of the following day, except in pursuit of lawful employment, or unless there exists a reasonable necessity therefor, or unless accompanied by a parent, guardian or other person of the age of 21 years or more having specific permission of a parent or guardian to have the custody of the child at the time, provided that on Friday and Saturday nights, the curfew hours for children 15 through 17 years old shall be extended to 1:00 a.m. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any parent, guardian or other person having the care and custody of any child under the age of 15 years to allow or permit any such child to be in or on any public street, highway, alley, park, playground, public grounds, public building, vacant lot or other public place within the city between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. of the following day, except in pursuit of lawful employment, or unless there exists a reasonable necessity therefor, or unless accompanied by a parent, guardian or other person of the age of 21 years or more having specific permission of a parent or guardian to have the custody of the child at the time. 
(Prior Code, § 17-5.2; Code 2000, § 10-5-30; Ord. No. 608, § 2; Ord. No. 757, § 2; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-122. - Encouraging delinquency. 
    It is unlawful for any person, by any act or neglect, to encourage, aid or cause a child to come within the purview of the juvenile authorities, and it shall likewise be unlawful for any person, after notice that a driver's license of any child has been suspended or revoked, to permit such child to operate a motor vehicle during the period that such driver's license is suspended or revoked. 
(Code 2000, § 10-5-40; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-123. - False statement; false credentials. 
    It is unlawful for any person under 21 years of age to make false statements, to furnish, present or exhibit any fictitious or false registration card, identification card, note or other document for any unlawful purpose, or to furnish, present or exhibit such documents issued to a person other than the one presenting the same for the purpose of gaining admission to prohibited places for the purpose of procuring the sale, gift or delivery of prohibited articles, including beer, liquor, wine or fermented malt beverages as defined in this chapter. 
(Code 2000, § 10-5-50; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-124. - Services of others. 
    It is unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to engage or utilize the services of any other person, whether for remuneration or not, to procure any article which the minor is forbidden by law to purchase. 
(Code 2000, § 10-5-60; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-125. - Loitering and other acts around schools. 
    It is unlawful for any person to loiter, idle, wander, stroll or play in, about or on any public, private or parochial school, college or seminary grounds or buildings, either on foot or in or on any vehicle, without having some lawful business therein or thereabout or in connection with such school or the employees thereof, or for any person to: 
(1)  Annoy, disturb or otherwise prevent the orderly conduct of classes and activities of any such school; 
(2)  Annoy, disturb, assault or molest any student or employee of any such school, college or seminary while in any such school building or on any school grounds; 
(3)  Conduct himself or herself in a lewd, wanton or lascivious manner in speech or behavior in or about any school building or school grounds; or 
(4)  Park or move a vehicle in the immediate vicinity of or on the grounds of any such school, college or seminary for the purpose of annoying or molesting the students or employees thereof or in an effort to induce, entice or invite students into such vehicles for immoral purposes. 
(Code 2000, § 10-5-70; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-126. - Abandoned containers and appliances. 
    No person shall leave or permit to remain outside of any dwelling, building or other structure or within any unoccupied or abandoned building, structure or dwelling under his or her control, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded ice box, refrigerator, washer, dryer, freezer or other container or appliance which has a door, lid, snap lock or other locking device which may not be released from the inside, without first removing said door, lid, snap lock or other locking device. 
(Code 2000, § 10-4-100; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-127. - Furnishing, purchasing or possessing tobacco products. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any business proprietor, manager or other person in charge or control of a retail business of any kind to engage, employ or permit any individual under the age of 18 years to sell cigarettes or tobacco products, as defined by C.R.S. § 18-13-121(5), from any retail business. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any business proprietor, manager or other person in charge or control of a retail business of any kind to stock or display cigarettes or tobacco products in any way which allows a customer to access such products without first securing the physical assistance of a business employee for each transaction. The provisions of this section shall not apply to places where minors are prohibited entry by law. 
(Code 2000, § 10-5-80; Ord. No. 1129, § 1, 2009) 
State Law reference- Teen Tobacco Use Prevention Act, C.R.S. § 25-14-301. 
Sec. 14-128. - Prohibition of commercial non-sale distribution of cigarettes and tobacco products. 
(a)  No person, including, but not limited to, tobacco manufacturers, wholesalers, retailers or any agent or employee representing said manufacturers, wholesalers or retailers, shall engage in the non-sale commercial distribution of any cigarette, tobacco product or coupon for tobacco products. 
(b)  No person shall permit the commercial non-sale distribution of any cigarette, tobacco product or coupon for tobacco products: 
(1)  Anywhere in any public place under the legal control of the person; or 
(2)  Through any agent or employee of the person. 
(Code 2000, § 7-2-140; Ord. No. 1129, § 2, 2009) 
Sec. 14-129. - Definitions. 
    In sections 14-128 through 14-131, the term "minor" means a person under the age of 18 years. 
(Code 2000, § 10-10-10; Ord. No. 1057, 2003) 
Sec. 14-130. - Unattended minors at the Lamar Public Library. 
(a)  Every minor under the age of seven years who is present in or upon the grounds of the Lamar Public Library during the hours that the library is open for business must be accompanied by an adult or a person who has attained the age of at least 12 years. 
(b)  Every minor under the age of 12 years who is present in or upon the grounds of the Lamar Public Library at times when the library is not open for business must be accompanied by an adult, parent or legal guardian or custodian. 
(c)  Every parent, legal guardian or legal custodian who allows or permits a minor in his or her custody to violate any provision of this section shall be guilty of violation. 
(d)  Upon the occurrence of a minor being present in or upon the grounds of the Lamar Public Library in violation of subsection (a) or (b) of this section, any public official discovering the minor shall, after staying with the minor for a period not to exceed 15 minutes, contact the local law enforcement officials for assistance in contacting the parent, legal guardian or legal custodian of the minor. The local law enforcement officials shall make every effort to locate the minor's parent, legal guardian or legal custodian and return the minor to his or her parent, legal guardian or legal custodian. If the minor's parent, legal guardian or legal custodian cannot be located, the local law enforcement officials shall contact the department of human services. 
(Code 2000, § 10-10-20; Ord. No. 1057, 2003) 
Sec. 14-131. - Unattended minors at the Lamar City Complex. 
(a)  Every minor under the age of seven years who is present in or upon the grounds of the Lamar City Complex during the hours that the complex is open for business must be accompanied by an adult or a person who has attained the age of at least 12 years. 
(b)  Every minor under the age of 12 years who is present in or upon the grounds of the Lamar City Complex at times when the complex is not open for business must be accompanied by an adult, parent or legal guardian or custodian. 
(c)  Every parent, legal guardian or legal custodian who allows or permits a minor in his or her custody to violate any provision of this section shall be guilty of violation of this section, and, upon conviction by the municipal court, shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of section 1-21. 
(d)  Upon the occurrence of a minor being present in or upon the grounds of the Lamar City Complex in violation of subsection (a) or (b) of this section, any public official discovering the minor shall, after staying with the minor for a period not to exceed 15 minutes, contact the local law enforcement officials for assistance in contacting the parent, legal guardian or legal custodian of the minor. The local law enforcement officials shall make every effort to locate the minor's parent, legal guardian or legal custodian and return the minor to his or her parent, legal guardian or legal custodian. If the minor's parent, legal guardian or legal custodian cannot be located, the local law enforcement officials shall contact the department of human services. 
(Code 2000, § 10-10-30; Ord. No. 1057, 2003) 
Sec. 14-132. - Unattended minors at the Lamar Community Building. 
(a)  No minors under the age of 13 years shall be allowed in the cardiovascular and weight room facilities at the Lamar Community Building. 
(b)  Every minor between the ages of 13 years and 15 years who is present in the cardiovascular and weight room facilities at the Lamar Community Building during the hours that the cardiovascular and weight room facilities are open for business must be accompanied by an adult who has attained the age of 18 years. 
(c)  Every minor 16 years or older may use the cardiovascular and weight room facilities at the Lamar Community Building without adult supervision. 
(d)  Every minor under the age of seven years who is present in or upon the grounds of the Lamar Community Building during the hours that the Lamar Community Building is open for business must be accompanied by an adult or a person who has attained the age of at least 12 years. 
(e)  Every minor under the age of 12 years who is present in or upon the grounds of the Lamar Community Building at times when the Lamar Community Building is not open for business must be accompanied by an adult, parent or legal guardian or custodian. 
(f)  Every parent, legal guardian or legal custodian who allows or permits a minor in his or her custody to violate any provision of this section shall be guilty of violation of this section, and, upon conviction by the municipal court, shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of section 1-21. 
(g)  Upon the occurrence of a minor being present in or upon the grounds of the Lamar Community Building in violation of subsection (a), (b), (c), (d) or (e) of this section, any public official discovering the minor shall, after staying with the minor for a period not to exceed 15 minutes, contact the local law enforcement officials for assistance in contacting the parent, legal guardian or legal custodian of the minor. The local law enforcement officials shall make every effort to locate the minor's parent, legal guardian or legal custodian and return the minor to his or her parent, legal guardian or legal custodian. If the minor's parent, legal guardian or legal custodian cannot be located, the local law enforcement officials shall contact the department of human services. 
(Code 2000, § 10-10-40; Ord. No. 1057, 2003) 
Sec. 14-133. - Unattended minors at the Lamar Municipal Swimming Pool. 
(a)  Every minor under the age of seven years who is present in or upon the grounds of the Lamar Municipal Swimming Pool during the hours that the pool is open for business must be accompanied by a person who has attained the age of at least 16 years. 
(b)  Every minor under the age of 12 years who is present in or upon the grounds of the Lamar Municipal Swimming Pool at times when the pool is not open for business must be accompanied by an adult, parent or legal guardian or custodian. 
(c)  Every parent, legal guardian or legal custodian who allows or permits a minor in his or her custody to violate any provision of this section shall be guilty of violation of this section, and, upon conviction by the municipal court, shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of section 1-21. 
(d)  Upon the occurrence of a minor being present in or upon the grounds of the Lamar Municipal Swimming Pool in violation of subsection (a) or (b) of this section, any public official discovering the minor shall, after staying with the minor for a period not to exceed 15 minutes, contact the local law enforcement officials for assistance in contacting the parent, legal guardian or legal custodian of the minor. The local law enforcement officials shall make every effort to locate the minor's parent, legal guardian or legal custodian and return the minor to his or her parent, legal guardian or legal custodian. If the minor's parent, legal guardian or legal custodian cannot be located, the local law enforcement officials shall contact the department of human services. 
(Code 2000, § 10-10-50; Ord. No. 1057, 2003) 
Secs. 14-134-14-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - NOISE 

Sec. 14-146. - Unreasonable noise. 
    No person shall make, continue or cause to be made or continued any unreasonable noise; and no person shall knowingly permit such noise upon any premises owned or possessed by such person or under such person's control. For purposes of this section, members of the police department are empowered to make a prima facie determination as to whether a noise is unreasonable. 
(Code 2000, § 10-9-10; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-147. - Sound systems in vehicles. 
(a)  It is unlawful to make, create or permit any excessive or unusually loud noise by means of any sound system installed or otherwise located within a motor vehicle within the city. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, an excessive or unusually loud noise is a noise which can be heard at a distance of at least 50 feet from its source. Words or phrases need not be discernible. 
(c)  For the purpose of this section, the term "sound system" means, but is not limited to, any public address system, radio, stereo, tape player, compact disc player or other electronic device used for the amplification of sound. Sound systems shall not include those devices utilized for the amplification of sound in conjunction with any government-sponsored or permitted activity or those activities conducted pursuant to the express consent of the governmental entity. 
(d)  The complaint may include, but need not be limited to, police officers acting under color of their authority. 
(Code 2000, § 10-9-20; Ord. No. 962, 1996; Ord. No. 1018, §§ 1, 2, 2000; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-148. - Motor vehicles. 
(a)  It is unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle to utilize any device designed to control, regulate or allow the release or escape of engine compression so as to slow the speed of said vehicle in such manner that the use of such braking device results in or creates excessive, loud or explosive noise from said vehicle. This section is intended to prohibit the practice commonly referred to as Jake braking, compression braking or cut-out braking. It shall be sufficient for prosecution and conviction of a violation of this offense if the Jake braking or compression braking is overheard and if the motor vehicle is observed to be operating in the general proximity of the occurrence of the noise. 
(b)  It is an affirmative defense to an alleged violation of subsection (a) of this section if the motor vehicle is in an emergency situation and, in an effort to avoid collision with any other vehicle, stationary object, moving object or living person or animal, such Jake braking or compression braking was used in conjunction with the avoidance of a collision as anticipated in this subsection, and the defendant shall be exonerated from any liability under subsection (a) of this section as to the criminal offense anticipated therein. Nothing contained herein shall expand or limit any civil liability, if any. 
(Code 2000, § 10-9-30; Ord. No. 991, 1998; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-149. - Sirens, whistles, gongs and red lights. 
    It is unlawful for any person to carry or use upon a vehicle, other than police or fire department vehicles or emergency vehicles for public use, any gong, siren, whistle or red light similar to that used on ambulances or vehicles of the police and fire departments. 
(Code 2000, § 10-9-50; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 14-150-14-163. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - WEAPONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Local government is preempted from regulating travel with weapons in vehicles or private conveyances, C.R.S. § 18-12-105.6; local government may not regulate concerning the issuance of concealed weapon permits, C.R.S. § 18-12-201. 

Sec. 14-164. - Definitions. 
(a)  As used in this article, unless the context otherwise requires, the following items shall be deemed weapons: 
    Ballistic knife means any knife that has a blade which is forcefully projected from the handle by means of a spring-loaded device or explosive charge. 
    Blackjack includes any billy, sand club, sandbag or other hand-operated striking weapon consisting, at the striking end, of an encased piece of lead or other heavy substance and, at the handle end, a strap or springy shaft which increases the force of impact. 
    Bomb means any explosive or incendiary device or Molotov cocktail, as defined in C.R.S. § 9-7-103, or any chemical device which causes or can cause an explosion which is not specifically designed for lawful and legitimate use in the hands of its possessor. 
    Firearm silencer means any instrument, attachment, weapon or appliance for causing the firing of any gun, revolver, pistol or other firearm to be silent or intended to lessen or muffle the noise of the firing of any such weapon. 
    Gas gun means a device designed for projecting gas-filled projectiles which release their contents after having been projected from the device, and includes projectiles designed for use in such device. 
    Gravity knife means any knife that has a blade released from the handle or sheath thereof by the force of gravity or the application of centrifugal force that, when released, is locked in place by means of a button, spring, lever or other device. 
    Handgun means a pistol, revolver or other firearm of any description, loaded or unloaded, from which any shot, bullet or other missile can be discharged, the length of the barrel of which, not including any revolving, detachable or magazine breech, does not exceed 12 inches. 
    Knife means any dagger, dirk, knife or stiletto with a blade over 31/2 inches in length, or any other dangerous instrument capable of inflicting cutting, stabbing or tearing wounds; but does not include a hunting or fishing knife carried for sports use. The issue that a knife is a hunting or fishing knife must be raised as an affirmative defense. 
    Short rifle means a rifle having a barrel less than 16 inches long or an overall length of less than 26 inches. 
    Short shotgun means a shotgun having a barrel less than 18 inches long or an overall length of less than 26 inches. 
    Stun gun means a device capable of temporarily immobilizing a person by the infliction of an electrical charge. 
    Throwing star means a disk having sharp radiating points or any disk-shaped bladed object which is handheld and thrown and which is in the design of a weapon used in connection with the practice of a system of self-defense. 
    Weapon means any pistol, revolver, rifle, shotgun, paintball gun or other device from which any shot, bullet or other missile can be discharged. 
(b)  It is an affirmative defense to any provision of this article that the act was committed by a peace officer in the lawful discharge of his or her duties. 
(Code 2000, § 10-8-10; Ord. No. 1001, § 1, 1999; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-165. - Carrying concealed weapon; forfeiture. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to wear under his or her clothes or concealed about his or her person, or to display in a threatening manner any dangerous or deadly weapon, including, but not limited to, any pistol, revolver, cross-knuckles or lead, brass or other metal, knife, dirk, dagger or knife resembling a knife, or any other dangerous or deadly weapon unless said person is duly licensed per state statute and in full compliance with state law. 
(b)  Every person convicted of any violation of this section shall forfeit to the city such dangerous or deadly weapon so concealed or displayed. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to forbid United States marshals, sheriffs, constables and their deputies and any regular, special or ex officio police officer or any other law enforcement officer from carrying or wearing such weapons as shall be necessary in the proper discharge of their duties. 
(Prior Code, § 17-5; Code 2000, § 10-8-20; Ord. No. 87, § 11; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-166. - Disposition of confiscated concealed weapons. 
    It shall be the duty of every police officer, upon making any arrest and taking such a concealed weapon from the person of the offender, to deliver the same to the municipal judge, to be held by him or her until the final determination of the prosecution for said offense; and upon the finding of guilt, it shall then be the duty of the municipal judge to deliver said weapon forthwith to the chief of police, who shall make disposition of the weapon. 
(Code 2000, § 10-8-30; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-167. - Prohibited use of weapons. 
(a)  A person commits a misdemeanor if he or she: 
(1)  Knowingly and unlawfully aims a weapon or firearm at another person; 
(2)  Discharges a firearm or weapon within the city limits; 
(3)  Knowingly sets a loaded gun, trap or device designed to cause an explosion upon being tripped or approached, and leaves it unattended by a competent person immediately present; 
(4)  Has in his or her possession a firearm while he or she is under the influence of intoxicating liquor or of a controlled substance. Possession of a permit issued under C.R.S. § 18-12-105.1 is no defense to a violation of this section; or 
(5)  Knowingly aims, swings or throws a knife, throwing star or nunchaku at another person, or knowingly possesses a throwing star or nunchaku in a public place except for the purpose of presenting an authorized public demonstration or exhibition or pursuant to instruction in conjunction with an organized school or class. When transporting throwing stars or nunchaku for a public demonstration or exhibition or for a school or class, they shall be transported in a closed, non-accessible container. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not prevent the operation of a private firing range within the city under the following conditions: 
(1)  Such range shall, at all times, be subject to rules and regulations as established by the chief of police with city council approval, and a permit shall first be obtained. 
(2)  Such permit shall be revocable at any time the chief of police or city council determines that the activities on such range are creating a hazard or a nuisance. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this section shall prevent the use of any such instruments in shooting galleries or in any private grounds or residences under circumstances when such instrument can be fired, discharged or operated in such a manner as not to endanger persons or property, and also in such a manner as to prevent the projectile from traversing any grounds or space outside the limits of such gallery, grounds or residence; and further provided that nothing herein contained shall be construed to prevent the carrying of any type of gun whatsoever, when unloaded and properly cased, to or from any range or gallery. 
(d)  Nothing contained in this section shall prevent the use of any such instruments by any peace officer as shall be necessary in the proper discharge of his or her duties. 
(Prior Code, §§ 9A-1, 9A-2; Code 2000, § 10-8-40; Ord. No. 543, § 1; Ord. No. 656, § 1; Ord. No. 1001, § 2, 1999; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 14-168. - Providing weapons to intoxicated persons. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to purchase, sell, loan or furnish any gun, pistol or other weapon or firearm in which any explosive substance can be used, to any person under the influence of alcohol or any narcotic drug, stimulant or depressant, to any person in a condition of agitation and excitability, or to any minor under the age of 18 years not in the presence of a parent or guardian. 
(b)  Such unlawful purchase, sale, loan or furnishing shall be grounds for revocation of any license issued by the city to such person. 
(Code 2000, § 10-8-50; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Chapter 16 - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Adoption. 
    Pursuant to C.R.S. § 31-16-201 et seq., there is adopted as the property maintenance code of the city, by reference thereto, the International Property Maintenance Code, 2006 edition, together with all appendices and tables thereto, published by the International Code Council, Inc., 5203 Leesburg Pike, Suite 708, Falls Church, Virginia 22041, that code to have the same force and effect as if set forth in this article in every particular, save and except such portions as are added, amended, deleted or replaced in this article. 
(Code 2000, § 18-8-10; Ord. No. 1052, § 7, 2002; Ord. No. 1104, § 1, 2007) 
Sec. 16-2. - Copy on file. 
    At least one copy of the International Property Maintenance Code, certified to be a true copy, has been and is now on file in the office of the city clerk and may be inspected by any interested person between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, holidays excepted. The code, as finally adopted, shall be available for sale to the public through the office of the city clerk at a moderate price. 
(Code 2000, § 18-8-20; Ord. No. 1052, § 7, 2002; Ord. No. 1104, § 1, 2007) 
Sec. 16-3. - Amendments. 
(a)  The code adopted herein is hereby modified by the following amendments: 
(1)  Section 101.1, Title, is amended by inserting "The City of Lamar." 
(2)  Section 102.3, Application of other codes, is amended by: 
a.  Replacing "ICC Electrical Code" with "the electrical code adopted by the State of Colorado." 
b.  Replacing "International Zoning Code" with "Lamar Zoning Code." 
(3)  Section 103.1, General, is amended to as follows, "The department of property maintenance inspection is hereby created and the executive official in charge thereof shall be known as the Chief Building Official." 
(4)  Section 103.3, Deputies, is amended as follows, "In accordance with the prescribed procedures of this jurisdiction and with the concurrence of the appointing authority, the code official shall have the authority to appoint a deputy code official, other related technical officers, inspectors, code enforcement officers and other employees." 
(5)  Section 103.5, Fees, is amended by inserting "as established by the City of Lamar." 
(6)  Section 104.5, Identification, is deleted in its entirety. 
(7)  Section 111.2, Membership of board, is amended by replacing "three" with "five" as the minimum number of members. 
(8)  Section 111.2.1, Alternate members, is deleted in its entirety. 
(9)  Section 111.2.5, Compensation of members, is deleted in its entirety. 
(10)  Section 201.3, Terms defined in other codes, is amended by replacing "ICC Electrical Code" with "electrical code adopted by the State of Colorado." 
(11)  Section 302.4, Weeds, is amended by inserting "12 inches" as the allowable height of weeds. 
(12)  Section 304.14, Insect screens, is amended by the insertion of "April 15" and "September 15." 
(13)  Section 307.3.1, Garbage facilities, is deleted in its entirety. 
(14)  Section 307.3.2, Containers, is deleted in its entirety. 
(15)  Section 506.1, General, is deleted in its entirety and replaced with the following: "All plumbing fixtures shall be properly connected to a public sewer system." 
(16)  Section 602.3, Heat supply, is amended by changing "October 1" to "May 1." 
(17)  Section 602.4, Occupiable work spaces, is amended by changing "October 1" to "May 1." 
(18)  Section 603.2, Removal of combustion products, is amended by the deletion of the exception. 
(19)  Section 604.2, Service, is amended by replacing "ICC Electrical Code" with "the current electrical code adopted by the State of Colorado." 
(20)  Chapter 8, Referenced standards, is amended by replacing "ICC EC-06, ICC Electrical Code" with "the electrical code adopted by the State of Colorado." 
(b)  The accumulative supplement to the International Property Maintenance Code is hereby adopted within the city. 
(Code 2000, § 18-8-30; Ord. No. 1052, §§ 2, 7, 2002; Ord. No. 1104, § 1, 2007) 
Sec. 16-4. - Report of costs. 
    Upon the completion of any work by the city contemplated by this chapter, the appropriate designee shall report, in writing, to the city administrator, which report shall make a clear statement of the work done by the city and the expense incurred in so doing, so that the city administrator may determine the cost of such work. A separate report for each lot or parcel of land shall be made. 
(Code 2000, § 7-1-100; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 16-5. - Assessment of property. 
    After considering the report required by section 16-1, the city administrator shall determine and assess the whole cost for the abatement thereof, including five percent for the inspection and other incidental costs in connection therewith, upon the lots and tracts of land from which the nuisance was abated. 
(Code 2000, § 7-1-110; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 16-6. - Notice of assessment. 
    The city clerk, as soon as may be after such assessment is made, shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the owner of such lots or tracts of land at the reputed post office address, a notice of such assessment, which notice shall contain a description of the lots or parcels of land, the name of the owner and the amount of the assessment. 
(Code 2000, § 7-1-120; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 16-7. - Payment of assessment. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner to pay such assessment or object thereto, in writing, within 30 days after the receipt of such notice, and in case of his or her failure to do so, he or she shall be liable personally for the amount of the assessment. The same shall be a lien upon the respective lot or parcel of land from the time of such assessment, and the city shall have all remedies for collection thereof provided by state statutes, for the purpose of having the same placed upon the tax list and collected in the same manner as taxes are now collected. The assessment shall be a lien against each lot or tract of land until it is paid and shall have priority over all other liens except general taxes and prior special assessments. 
(b)  The amount of such assessment may be paid to the city clerk at any time before the tax list is placed in the hands of the county treasurer, but thereafter only to the county treasurer. 
(Code 2000, § 7-1-130; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 16-8. - Certified assessment. 
    In case the owner shall fail to pay such assessment or object thereto within the required time as provided in section 16-4, then it shall be the duty of the city clerk to certify the amount of the assessment to the proper county officers, who shall collect the assessment as provided for by state law for the collection of delinquent general taxes. 
(Code 2000, § 7-1-150; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 16-9-16-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DECLARATION OF NUISANCES 

Sec. 16-31. - Posting handbills, posters and placards. 
    Any handbill, poster, placard or painted or printed matter which shall be stuck, posted or pasted upon any public or private house or other building or upon any fence, power pole, telephone pole or other structure or vehicle without the permission of the owner, agent or occupant shall be deemed a nuisance and may be abated as provided in this chapter. 
(Code 2000, § 7-2-20; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 16-32. - Dead animal removal. 
    When any animal dies in the city, it shall be the duty of the owner or keeper thereof to remove the body of such animal forthwith beyond the limits of the city. If such body is not forthwith removed, the same shall be deemed a nuisance, and such owner or keeper will be the author of the nuisance. When the body of any such dead animal is in any street, highway or public grounds in the city, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to cause such body to be removed forthwith beyond the limits of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 7-2-100; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 16-33. - Removal of animal waste. 
    The owner or keeper of any animal shall be responsible for the immediate removal of any feces deposited by such animal on any property, public or private, not owned or exclusively occupied by the owner or keeper. 
(Code 2000, § 7-2-110; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Chapter 18 - SOLID WASTE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garbage means all animal and vegetable waste attending the handling, preparation, cooking, consumption or storage of meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruits or vegetables, excluding dead animals and slaughterhouse offal. 
    Junk includes, but is not limited to, used lumber, scrap metals and materials, discarded furniture, fixtures, appliances and all wrecked, abandoned, demolished, dismantled or inoperable machinery, trailers and other goods that are so worn or deteriorated as to make them unusable in their existing condition. 
    Refuse means all hay, straw shavings, excelsior, grass cuttings, paper and paper products, containers, boxes, glass, cans, bottles and other materials commonly known as rubbish or refuse as are commonly produced in homes, stores and institutions; excluding, however, debris or rubbish from the construction, demolition or repair of buildings and other structures, trees and tree limbs, dead animals, abandoned large machinery, vehicles and furniture. 
    Rubbish and debris mean all waste, refuse and rejected matter and material, whether animal, vegetable, manufactured or natural deposits or accumulations. It shall be unlawful to deposit, accumulate, store, keep or abandon, or to allow the deposit, accumulation, storage, keeping or abandonment of junk, rubbish, debris or scrap material on private or public property within the city other than in areas zoned for such junk, rubbish or debris, if such deposit, accumulation, storage, keeping or abandonment causes harm, danger, detriment, injury, disturbance or undue annoyance to health, safety, welfare or property of persons in the neighborhood or the public in general. 
(Prior Code, § 12-1; Code 2000, § 7-4-10; Ord. No. 606, § 1; Ord. No. 707, §§ 2, 6, 7; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 18-2-18-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND REMOVAL OF SOLID WASTE 

Sec. 18-21. - Collection and removal by city or contractor; exceptions. 
(a)  Except as herein provided, all garbage and refuse shall be collected, removed and disposed of by the city or by persons under contract to the city. Except as specifically provided for herein, no other person or entity shall collect any garbage or refuse within the city or convey the same through or over any street, alley, road or highway within the city. 
(b)  Nothing herein shall prohibit any person from hauling his or her own refuse to the city dump, provided that it is done at a time when the dump is officially open, and the refuse is transported in such a manner as to preclude any of it from being deposited on any street, alley or other property en route. Any person so hauling his or her own refuse shall not be excused from paying the applicable collection charge provided for herein by the city. 
(c)  Any restaurant owner or operator, or the owner or operator of any similar business having garbage fit for livestock feeding, may contract with any other person to haul away such garbage. 
(d)  Any person so hauling away such garbage shall transport the same in covered containers acceptable to the city, and in such a manner as to preclude the emitting of offensive smells and the falling, dripping or spilling of the same on the ground or on the bed of the transporting vehicle. 
(e)  Any owner or operator so electing to dispose of his or her garbage shall not thereby be excused from the payment of the regular charge applicable to him or her for removal by the city. 
(Prior Code, § 12-2; Code 2000, § 7-4-20; Ord. No. 606, § 2; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 18-22. - Materials too bulky or heavy for containers. 
    All rubbish, trash or other waste materials too bulky or heavy to be placed in city containers, including, but not limited to, debris and rubbish resulting from the construction, repair and demolition of buildings and other structures, trees and tree limbs, industrial refuse, dead animals, machinery, vehicles, furniture and other like items, shall be removed and disposed of by the owner or occupant of the premises where the same are located at his or her own expense, provided that nothing herein shall preclude the city from undertaking to remove any of these items at its option and at charges to be determined by resolution. 
(Prior Code, § 12-4; Code 2000, § 7-4-30; Ord. No. 606, § 4; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 18-23. - Placement for collection. 
(a)  Garbage and refuse in proper containers, as herein provided for, shall be placed out for collection at a convenient place on the property of the user, adjacent to the street or alley, or at such other convenient place as the city may from time to time determine with respect to individual properties or users. 
(b)  The city may permit a user to place such containers at a place selected by the user; provided that if such spot selected is more than ten feet from the spot for collection designated by the city, the city may make an additional charge to the user over and above the regular collection charge. 
(Prior Code, § 12-5; Code 2000, § 7-4-40; Ord. No. 606, § 6) 
Sec. 18-24. - Collection frequency. 
    Collection shall be made at such times and frequencies as the city may from time to time determine, acting in its administrative capacity. 
(Prior Code, § 12-6; Code 2000, § 7-4-50; Ord. No. 606, § 7) 
Sec. 18-25. - Charges for collection. 
(a)  All charges for the collection and disposal of garbage and refuse shall be set by the city by resolution, and may be changed by resolution. 
(b)  Charges for garbage and refuse removed shall be a lien on the property served until paid in full. 
(c)  If payment of any such charge is not made within 90 days after the same is due, the city clerk shall certify such charges as assessed to the county treasurer, to be placed on the tax list for the current year, to be collected in the same manner as taxes are collected, with a ten percent penalty to defray the cost of collection, as provided by state law. 
(Prior Code, § 12-7; Code 2000, § 7-4-60; Ord. No. 606, § 8) 
State Law reference- Procedures for collection of unpaid taxes and assessments, C.R.S. § 39-10-101 et seq. 
Sec. 18-26. - Matters determined by resolution. 
    The city council may, by resolution, determine and redetermine any of the following matters: 
(1)  The method and manner of transporting garbage and refuse under section 18-21; 
(2)  The size, type, kind and weight of bags to be used; 
(3)  The adequacy of the containers for refuse; 
(4)  The place where garbage and refuse must be placed for collection under section 18-23; 
(5)  The hours, frequencies and routes of collection by the city, and the hours the city dump shall be officially open; and 
(6)  Such other matters as may be necessary to effectively implement the provisions of this article. 
(Prior Code, § 12-8; Code 2000, § 7-4-70; Ord. No. 606, § 9; Ord. No. 621, § 3; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 18-27. - Prohibitions and restrictions. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person engaged as a commercial hauler of garbage and refuse to dispose of said garbage and refuse in the landfill belonging to the city or in any garbage and refuse collection transfer facility belonging to the city, as may now exist or be hereafter established, unless under contract and with permission of the city. 
(b)  A rebuttable presumption is hereby created that any person is engaged as a commercial hauler of garbage and refuse if such person: 
(1)  Publicly advertises or solicits business by offering to collect, remove or dispose of garbage and refuse; 
(2)  Receives any compensation in excess of the actual transportation expense incurred in the collection, removal or disposal of garbage and refuse; or 
(3)  Conducts or operates any regularly scheduled route, either within or outside the city, for the collection and removal of garbage and refuse, or for the disposal of garbage and refuse at any city collection transfer facility or landfill. 
(c)  A commercial hauler of garbage and refuse shall not include any person hauling his or her own refuse, any restaurant or similar business owner or operator contracting with any person to haul away garbage to be used as feed for livestock, or any person hauling garbage and refuse incident to a regular business pursuit engaged in by such person, such as, by way of example, but not limited to, demolition contractors. 
(Code 2000, § 7-4-90; Ord. No. 924, § 1, 1993; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 18-28. - Disturbing or removing containers. 
    No person shall molest, remove, handle or disturb any garbage or refuse container placed out for collection, provided that this shall not apply to persons legally collecting the same under this article. 
(Prior Code, § 12-9; Code 2000, § 7-4-100; Ord. No. 606, § 10) 
Chapter 20 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PROPERTY 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Obstruction of streets prohibited. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, no person shall in any manner encumber or obstruct any street, alley, sidewalk or public ground within the city; erect any building or stairway, in whole or in part, upon any street, alley, sidewalk or public ground; place or keep merchandise, boxes, bales or any commodities of any kind whatever upon any street, alley, sidewalk or public ground; or make excavations, holes or ditches or do any other thing to or upon any street, alley, sidewalk or public ground that may endanger the safety of the public within the city. 
(b)  No person shall fail or refuse to remove any encumbrance or obstruction in any street or to make safe for travel and use by the public any place upon any street, alley, sidewalk or public grounds occupied by him or her, within 24 hours of the time he or she is notified by the chief of police, public works director or other authorized designee of the city to remove or repair the same. 
(Prior Code, § 22-1; Code 2000, § 11-1-10; Ord. No. 112, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 20-2. - Placing building materials on street during construction. 
    No contractor, builder, owner or other person shall be permitted to occupy a part of any street, not to exceed one-half of the street in front of any lot or premises upon which such contractor, builder, owner or other person is erecting or is about to erect or construct any building or do any work or make any improvement, for a period not to exceed 90 days without first making application 48 hours in advance to the chief of police. 
(Prior Code, § 22-2; Code 2000, § 11-1-20; Ord. No. 112, § 1) 
Sec. 20-3. - Trees and shrubs obstructing streets. 
    No owner or occupant of any lot or premises within the city shall allow or permit any trees, shrubs or plants to grow or be grown upon such lot or premises in such a manner as to obstruct or hinder the free, uninterrupted and safe passage of pedestrians or vehicles along the sidewalks or streets and along and through the alleys within the city. No owner or occupant of any lot or premises within the city shall plant any trees or shrubs upon any such lot or premises within three feet from the lot line of such lot or premises. 
(Prior Code, § 22-7; Code 2000, § 11-1-70; Ord. No. 112, § 7) 
Sec. 20-4. - Sidewalk construction and repair. 
(a)  Sidewalks shall be constructed by the owners of property abutting upon the same or at their expense, as provided in this article, throughout the city upon both sides of the streets whenever such streets are laid out, improved and in common use. 
(b)  The city council may order by ordinance the construction or rebuilding of a sidewalk upon any street or part of a street in the city. In the ordinance ordering such construction or rebuilding, there shall be clearly set forth the place where such sidewalk shall be constructed or rebuilt, a description of every lot and parcel of land upon which the same abuts or is contiguous, and the style, dimensions and material of such sidewalk. Any such ordinance may contain orders and directions for the construction or rebuilding of any number of such sidewalks on any number of streets. 
(c)  At any time within 30 days after the publication of an ordinance ordering construction or rebuilding of a sidewalk, the owner of any lot or parcel of land upon which such sidewalk abuts shall, at his or her own expense, construct or rebuild so much of such sidewalk as abuts upon his or her premises. 
(Prior Code, § 22-8; Code 2000, § 11-1-80; Ord. No. 21, §§ 4, 5, 16; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 20-5. - Failure of property owner to construct or rebuild. 
    In case of the failure of any owner of premises abutting any sidewalk to construct or rebuild such sidewalk as provided in this article, upon order of the city council, it shall be the duty of the public works department to report to the city council such person who has failed to construct or rebuild his or her part of the sidewalk, the length of the sidewalk required to be constructed or rebuilt, and the place where the same should be constructed or rebuilt. Upon order of the city council to be entered of record, the public works department shall proceed to construct or rebuild without delay so much of such sidewalk as shall remain to be constructed or rebuilt in the manner directed in such order, and the city council shall authorize the public works department to incur the necessary expenses therefor. The public works department shall report to the city council, at the next meeting after the sidewalk is completed, the expense of construction or rebuilding such sidewalk along each lot or premises in front of or beside which the same is constructed or rebuilt. 
(Prior Code, § 22-9; Code 2000, § 11-1-90; Ord. No. 21, § 7; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 20-6. - Repairs of sidewalks by owners. 
    Whenever any sidewalk in the city is in need of repair, the city council may order the same repaired. It shall be the duty of the public works department to give notice to the owner or person in charge of any property which abuts such sidewalk to have the same repaired within five days. On failure to have such repairs made, the public works department shall proceed at once to make such repairs, at the expense of the city, and to report the expense thereof to the city council at its next meeting. In case it is not known or ascertained, after due inquiry, who the owner or person in charge of such property is, or in case the public security would be endangered for the lack of such repairs immediately, in the opinion of the public works department, it shall proceed to make such repairs without giving such notice. The expense for the repairs shall be collected as provided in this article. 
(Prior Code, § 22-10; Code 2000, § 11-1-100; Ord. No. 21, § 6; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 20-7. - Assessment and collection of costs. 
(a)  Upon the report of the public works department to the city council of the expense of repairing sidewalks by the city pursuant to this article, and of constructing and rebuilding sidewalks, as provided in section 20-5, the city council shall by resolution assess and determine the amount chargeable against each owner and against each lot or parcel of land, or any part thereof, on account of the construction, rebuilding or repairing of any such sidewalk by the city. Such resolution shall state the total amount charged and assessed against each owner, and the separate sums charged and assessed against each lot or parcel of land, or any part thereof. 
(b)  The cost and expense of constructing, rebuilding or repairing any sidewalk by order of the city council, when the same shall have been assessed, as provided in this section, shall be payable by the owners of the several lots or parcels of land upon which the same shall abut or be contiguous without further demand within ten days after the meeting of the city council to hear appeals from such assessment, as provided by law. Such assessment shall constitute a lien upon such property until the same is paid or the amount thereof has been reduced by the city council. In case of reduction by the city council of the original amount of such assessment upon appeal by the owner of the assessed property, such reduced assessment shall constitute a lien upon such property until the assessed amount is paid.
