In case of failure to pay any such assessment within ten days after the meeting of the city council to hear the appeal, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to certify such assessment to the proper officer then having custody of the tax list of the county for the then-current year, to be placed on such tax list for collection, together with a ten percent penalty to defray the collection costs. 
(c)  The city council, as soon as possible after such assessments have been made as provided in this section, shall cause to be published in a newspaper published in the city a notice of such assessments, containing the name of the owners respectively of the several lots or parcels of lands named in such assessment, a description of each lot or parcel of land assessed and the amount of the assessment against each, and shall also specify a time and place at which the owner of any lot or parcel of land so assessed may meet with the city council, appeal any such assessment and be heard as to the justice and correctness of the amount assessed. The city council shall meet and, if necessary, may adjourn from time to time and shall hear any owner of any lot or parcel of land so assessed who may appear before it, at such specified time or at any time to which the city council may adjourn for such purpose, as to the correctness of the amount so assessed against any such lot or parcel of land. Such property owner may appear before the city council either in person or by an agent. In case no appeal is made from an assessment, the same shall stand as assessed. In case any assessment shall be reduced on appeal, such assessment shall stand as reduced. If any assessment is not reduced or discharged, such assessment shall stand as confirmed, and the same, when so reduced or confirmed, shall stand as the assessment for the construction, rebuilding or repair of such sidewalk against the lot or parcel of land described in the assessment. 
(d)  An assessment to any extent and against any number of individuals or lots or parcels of lands may be made in one resolution. 
(e)  The city clerk shall maintain a record of the assessments against any owners of lots or parcels of land, giving the owner's name, when known, and the description of each lot or parcel of land assessed and upon which such assessment would be a lien, and the amount of any such assessment against any person or lot or parcel of land may be paid to the city clerk. In such cases, the city clerk shall give a receipt therefor, enter the record of payment in such book and accompany such record of payment by a sufficient reference to the corresponding assessment of the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 22-11; Code 2000, § 11-1-110; Ord. No. 21, §§ 8-12; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 20-8. - Type of material required. 
(a)  All sidewalks shall be constructed of concrete by the parties owning or controlling lots or lands adjoining or abutting upon the streets along which such sidewalks are laid. The same shall be not less than four inches of concrete laid upon a foundation of sand and gravel not less than four inches thick. All sidewalks shall be constructed in a good and workmanlike manner. 
(b)  The repair of any sidewalk shall be made with the same kind of materials used in the original construction of the sidewalk. 
(Prior Code, § 22-12; Code 2000, § 11-1-120; Ord. No. 21, §§ 2, 13; Ord. No. 74, § 1) 
Sec. 20-9. - Width and grade. 
    All sidewalks shall be of a uniform width on the same street and shall conform to the grade established by the city. 
(Prior Code, § 22-13; Code 2000, § 11-1-130; Ord. No. 21, § 3) 
Sec. 20-10. - Snow and ice removal from sidewalks. 
(a)  Every owner or occupant of any premises within the city having a sidewalk on or adjacent to the premises shall have the duty to keep the sidewalk clean of snow and ice. 
(b)  All snow and ice shall be removed within 24 hours of accumulation. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, premises shall mean any lot, parcel, outlot or other subdivision of real property, whether occupied or not, and whether or not a structure exists on the lot, parcel, outlot or other subdivision. 
(Code 2000, § 11-1-140; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 20-11-20-38. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ROADS AND SIDEWALK SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 20-39. - Standards, regulations and specifications. 
    The public works department, in consultation with the city administrator and the public works director, shall utilize CDOT Standard Specification of Road and Bridge Construction, as may be amended, in governing access, utilization and restoration of all streets, alleys and rights-of-way within the corporate limits of the city, which standards, regulations and specifications shall not constitute a barrier to the use and excavation of city facilities, but shall preserve the integrity of the facilities at the least possible cost to city taxpayers. 
(Code 2000, § 11-2-10; Ord. No. 968, § 2, 1996; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 20-40-20-67. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARK REGULATIONS 

Sec. 20-68. - Speed limit. 
    No person shall drive or operate any motor vehicle on any of the roadways in any park of the city at a speed in excess of ten miles per hour. 
(Prior Code, § 18-2; Code 2000, § 11-3-20; Ord. No. 338, § 2) 
Sec. 20-69. - Restrictions. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate any minibike, motorcycle, motor scooter or other motor-propelled, two-wheel vehicle in any city parks. 
(Prior Code, § 18-2.1; Code 2000, § 11-3-30; Ord. No. 643, § 1; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 20-70. - Exceptions. 
    Notwithstanding section 20-69, any vehicle which may be legally operated on a public highway within the state may also be operated in any city parks, but only on roadways in such parks which are open to the public for vehicular traffic. 
(Prior Code, § 18-2.2; Code 2000, § 11-3-40; Ord. No. 643, § 2; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 20-71. - Livestock at large in parks. 
    No person shall permit or allow any horses, cattle, sheep, goats, hogs or any other livestock to pasture, graze or run at large within the limits of any park owned by the city, whether within or outside the city; provided that this section shall not apply to animals placed therein by the city. 
(Prior Code, § 18-3; Code 2000, § 11-3-50; Ord. No. 338, § 3; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 20-72. - Authority of city in parks. 
    The provisions of this Code and any other ordinances of the city are extended to and shall be in full force and effect in any parks owned by the city, whether situated inside or outside the city, and all police officers and firefighters of the city shall have the same police power and authority within any city park that they possess within the city. 
(Prior Code, § 18-4; Code 2000, § 11-3-60; Ord. No. 338, § 5; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 20-73. - Recreational facilities. 
    All recreational facilities of the city owned by the city, or controlled by it or the city recreation commission, including, but not limited to, the swimming pool, parks and ball fields, are, for the purposes of maintenance, repairs and capital improvements, a part of the parks, cemetery and recreation department of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 18-5; Code 2000, § 11-3-70; Ord. No. 517, § 4) 
Sec. 20-74. - Park curfew. 
    It is unlawful for any person to remain, stay or loiter in any public park between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 4:30 a.m. of the following day unless permitted, allowed or sponsored by the city. The city administrator may authorize, upon request, use of a public park between 10:30 p.m. and 4:30 a.m. of the following day. 
(Prior Code, § 18-5.1; Code 2000, § 11-3-80; Ord. No. 580, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1043, § 1, 2002) 
Secs. 20-75-20-91. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CEMETERIES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 20-92. - Injuring, defacing of property. 
    No person shall cut, injure, mark or deface any public building, structure, fixture or equipment belonging to the city, or any tree, grass, flowers, flower bed, shrubs, sewer, water pipe, hydrant or ditch situated in any cemetery owned by the city, whether situated within or outside the city. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1; Code 2000, § 11-4-10; Ord. No. 338, § 1; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 20-93. - Speed limit in cemeteries. 
    No person shall drive or operate any motor vehicle on any of the roadways in any cemetery of the city at a speed in excess of ten miles per hour. 
(Prior Code, § 6-2; Code 2000, § 11-4-20; Ord. No. 338, § 2) 
Sec. 20-94. - Livestock at large in cemeteries. 
    No person shall permit or allow any horses, cattle, sheep, goats, hogs or any other livestock to pasture, graze or run at large within the limits of any cemetery owned by the city, whether within or outside the city, provided that this section shall not apply to animals placed therein by the city. 
(Prior Code, § 6-3; Code 2000, § 11-4-30; Ord. No. 338, § 3; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 20-95. - Foundations and stones. 
(a)  To promote aesthetics, safety and maintenance operations in the city cemeteries, persons desiring to install gravestones or markers on gravesites must first secure a permit from city staff. The permit process will ensure the foundation and stone conform to the requirements for placement and construction. 
(b)  The city shall not be responsible for the placement of gravestones or monuments. 
(c)  Foundation charges shall be as established by the city council by resolution. 
(Code 2000, § 11-4-50; Ord. No. 1123, § 1, 2009) 
Sec. 20-96. - Cemetery service charges. 
(a)  For both the Riverside Cemetery and Fairmount Cemetery, charges for cemetery services shall be as established by the city council. 
(b)  Disinterments shall not be performed on Saturdays, Sundays or legal holidays. 
(c)  Burials shall not be permitted on Sundays or legal holidays. 
(Code 2000, § 11-4-60; Ord. No. 953, § 2, 1995; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 20-97. - Future prices, charges and fees. 
    In the absence of any contrary legislative enactment by any future city council, all prices shall on January 1 of each year thereafter be adjusted by an amount equal to inflation, as defined in article X, section 20(2)(f) of the TABOR Amendment to the state constitution, plus two percent. 
(Code 2000, § 11-4-70; Ord. No. 953, § 5, 1995; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 20-98-20-124. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RIVERSIDE CEMETERY 

Sec. 20-125. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a cemetery in the city to be known as Riverside Cemetery. 
(Prior Code, § 6-5; Code 2000, § 11-4-200; Ord. No. 19, § 1) 
Sec. 20-126. - Control and supervision. 
(a)  For the purpose of maintenance, repairs and capital improvements, Riverside Cemetery shall be under the control of the parks, cemetery and recreation department. 
(b)  All caskets accepted for burial spaces in Riverside Cemetery shall be enclosed in an industry standard, concrete cement burial vault and approved for use by the city's cemetery director. 
(Prior Code, § 6-6; Code 2000, § 11-4-210; Ord. No. 19, § 2; Ord. No. 769, § 1; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1206, 2016) 
Sec. 20-127. - Maintenance of records. 
    The city clerk shall keep all records of Riverside Cemetery and shall have charge of the sale of lots, plots and spaces therein, and such register shall also show the numbers of the lots and blocks wherein such persons were buried. 
(Prior Code, § 6-8; Code 2000, § 11-4-220; Ord. No. 19, § 5; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 20-128. - Price of lots. 
(a)  The price to be charged for lots in Riverside Cemetery shall be as established by the city council by resolution. There shall be no discount for purchase of spaces in excess of one space. 
(b)  Monthly installments in equal amounts may be accepted on the purchase price of cemetery lots, together with interest at the rate of five percent per annum. The minimum monthly installment shall be no less than $25.00, with a term not to exceed 36 months from the date of the lot purchase. Failure to make payment by the tenth day of each month may result in the lot being returned to the cemetery for resale and forfeiture of installments made. No burial shall be permitted unless the price of the lot to which interment will be made is paid in full. 
(c)  Lots, plots and spaces in Riverside Cemetery will be conveyed to the purchaser by deed, subject to the rules and regulations thereof, the provisions of this article and any other ordinances of the city in reference thereto, and to the laws of the state. 
(Code 2000, § 11-4-240; Ord. No. 1123, § 3, 2009) 
Secs. 20-129-20-154. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FAIRMOUNT CEMETERY 

Sec. 20-155. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a municipal cemetery, consisting of land owned by the city, to be known and designated as Fairmount Cemetery. 
(Prior Code, § 6-10; Code 2000, § 11-4-300; Ord. No. 237, §§ 1, 4) 
Sec. 20-156. - Control and supervision. 
(a)  All lots, plots and spaces in Fairmount Cemetery shall be held in accordance with, and subject to the rules, regulations and provisions of, this article or any other ordinance of the city, and the laws of the state. 
(b)  Caskets accepted for burial spaces in Fairmount Cemetery shall be enclosed in an industry standard, concrete cement burial vault and approved for use by the city's cemetery director. 
(c)  Grave markers of granite or bronze, set level or flush with the lawn, may be placed at the head of each grave. Foundations will be required for all monuments, mausoleums and structures of every description placed on lots, plots and spaces, such foundations to be constructed by the city, the rates to be fixed and established by resolution of the city council. No foundations will be required for flat markers. All orders for foundations shall be filed at the office of the city clerk, and payment therefor made to the city clerk. 
(Prior Code, §§ 6-6, 6-10, 6-14; Code 2000, § 11-4-310; Ord. No. 19, § 2; Ord. No. 237, §§ 1, 4, 7, 8, 10, 11; Ord. No. 769, § 1; Ord. No. 1206, 2016) 
Sec. 20-157. - Price of lots. 
(a)  The price to be charged for lots in Fairmount Cemetery shall be as established by the city council by resolution. There shall be no discount for purchase of spaces in excess of one space. 
(b)  Single spaces in Fairmount Cemetery will be sold in blocks numbered 21 to 42, inclusive thereof, and monuments will be permitted therein. 
(c)  Cremation spaces in Fairmount Cemetery will be sold in blocks numbered 105 and 105A, inclusive thereof, and monuments will be permitted therein. 
(d)  Monthly installments in equal amounts may be accepted on the purchase price of cemetery lots, together with interest at the rate of five percent per annum. The minimum monthly installment shall be no less than $25.00 with a term not to exceed 36 months from the date of lot purchase. Failure to make payment by the tenth day of each month may result in the lot being returned to the cemetery for resale and forfeiture of installments made. No burial shall be permitted unless the price of the lot to which interment will be made is paid in full. 
(e)  Lots, plots and spaces in Fairmount Cemetery will be conveyed to the purchaser by deed, subject to the rules and regulations thereof, the provisions of this article, and any other ordinances of the city in reference thereto and to the laws of the state. 
(Code 2000, § 11-4-320; Ord. No. 1123, § 4, 2010) 
Sec. 20-158. - Maintenance of records. 
    The city clerk shall keep all records of Fairmount Cemetery, and shall have charge of the sale of lots, plots and spaces therein and such register shall also show the number of the lot and block wherein such person was buried. 
(Prior Code, § 6-12; Code 2000, § 11-4-330; Ord. No. 237, § 3) 
Sec. 20-159. - Perpetual care. 
    The city shall perpetually care for and maintain all roads, walks, pathways, grass, ground, shrubbery, trees and improvements belonging or appertaining to Fairmount Cemetery, provided that all lot, plot or space owners are to care for and maintain all monuments, mausoleums and markers erected on their lots, plots or spaces, except ordinary care. 
(Prior Code, § 6-13; Code 2000, § 11-4-340; Ord. No. 237, §§ 5, 6) 
Sec. 20-160. - Monuments. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, monuments will be permitted in Fairmount Cemetery, subject to the rules and regulations thereof. No monument, mausoleum or other structure shall be placed in Fairmount Cemetery until a design of the same, with specifications, has been submitted to and approved by the Parks and Cemetery Director thereof. 
(b)  In order to maintain a park-like appearance, no monuments raised above the surface of the ground will be allowed in the following described blocks or lots: all of blocks one and two; lots six to 17 inclusive, in block three; lots nine to 15 inclusive, in block 15; lots six to 17 inclusive, in block 16; all of blocks 17, 18, 19 and 20; and circle lots 38 to 44 and 60 to 67, inclusive. All markers and headstones in such lots shall be set level or flush with the ground. 
(Prior Code, § 6-14; Code 2000, § 11-4-350; Ord. No. 237, §§ 7, 8, 10, 11; Ord. No. 769, § 1) 
Sec. 20-161. - Maintenance of lots. 
(a)  No lot, plot or space may be decorated by its owner or others with any trees or shrubs, nor shall the trees or shrubs planted thereon by the city be disturbed in any way. 
(b)  No lots, plots or spaces in Fairmount Cemetery may be defined or marked by any fence, coping, railing, hedge or embankment, nor shall any lot be filled above the established grade. Boundaries of lots, plots or spaces may be designated, if the owner so desires, by granite corners set level or flush with the ground and inside the corner of the lot, plot or space so marked. Such boundary markers shall be placed and maintained at the expense of the owner of the lot, plot or space. 
(Prior Code, § 6-14; Code 2000, § 11-4-360; Ord. No. 237, §§ 7, 8, 10, 11; Ord. No. 769, § 1) 
Sec. 20-162. - Use of funds. 
    All money received from the sale of lots, plots or spaces in Fairmount Cemetery shall be used for the improvement of such cemetery and the maintenance thereof, or for the payment of any indebtedness incurred in connection therewith or interest incurred thereon. One-half of all money so received shall be invested by the city treasurer under the direction of the city council in municipal, county, state or United States government bonds, or the bonds of school districts of the state of the first and second classes, and all interest derived therefrom shall be exclusively applied, appropriated and used for the perpetual improvement, preservation and embellishment of Fairmount Cemetery and its appurtenances. 
(Prior Code, § 6-16; Code 2000, § 11-4-370; Ord. No. 237, § 13) 
Secs. 20-163-20-192. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - VETERANS SECTION AT FAIRMOUNT CEMETERY 

Sec. 20-193. - Established. 
    The veterans section at Fairmount Cemetery shall be Section A-H on the south end of Fairmount Cemetery for the purpose of burial of honorably discharged veterans of military service to the United States of America. 
(Code 2000, § 11-4-400; Ord. No. 1031, 2001; Ord. No. 1217, § 1, 6-12-2017) 
Sec. 20-194. - Eligibility for interment in the veteran's section. 
    Eligibility for interment in the veterans section at Fairmount Cemetery shall be as follows: 
(1)  Prior to interment, veterans, their family members or representatives must present to the city clerk or his or her designee honorable discharge documentation from any branch of service of the United States of America, including, but not limited to, the Army, Navy, Marines, Air Force, Coast Guard, National Guard, and reserve units of said branches; 
(2)  Veterans must either at some time in their lifetimes or at the time of death have been residents of Prowers County or a community located within 30 miles of Fairmount Cemetery; 
(3)  The current spouse, or surviving spouse of a veteran who is eligible for interment in the veterans section of Fairmount Cemetery pursuant to subsections (1) and (2) of this section; 
(4)  The minor children of an eligible veteran. For purposes of eligibility for this benefit, a minor child is a child who is unmarried and is less than 18 years of age; 
(5)  The unmarried adult child of an eligible veteran who became permanently physically or mentally disabled and incapable of self-support before reaching age 21. Proper supporting documentation must be provided. 
(Code 2000, § 11-4-410; Ord. No. 1031, 2001; Ord. No. 1217, § 2, 6-12-2017) 
Sec. 20-195. - Plot designations. 
(a)  Plots shall be chosen for veterans and/or their eligible family members on the basis of next available, contiguous space. For eligible family members to be interred in adjoining plots, all spaces must be reserved at the time of the first death. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, veterans and/or their spouses may choose the next available, contiguous space at the time of purchase of a monument to be placed on said space; provided, however, that the monument is paid for and placed on the space at the time the space is chosen. 
(c)  Upon written notification of forfeiture from a veteran or spouse, any reserved but unused space shall revert back to the cemetery. Spaces shall not be transferrable. 
(Code 2000, § 11-4-420; Ord. No. 1031, 2001; Ord. No. 1036, 2001; Ord. No. 1217, § 2, 6-12-2017) 
Sec. 20-196. - Fees. 
(a)  Interment as a veteran or eligible spouse in the veterans section of Fairmount Cemetery shall be without assessment of charge or fees by the city for the plot only. It is not the intent of the city to waive any other fees associated with the interment other than the fee for the plot. 
(b)  Eligible family members of a veteran other than the spouse shall be assessed the normal charge or fees for interment by the city, including the usual and customary fee for the plot, as established by the city council by resolution. 
(Code 2000, § 11-4-430; Ord. No. 1031, 2001; Ord. No. 1036, 2001; Ord. No. 1217, § 2, 6-12-2017) 
Sec. 20-197. - Appearance and flag. 
    The veterans section of Fairmount Cemetery shall conform in appearance with all other sections of the cemetery. In addition to conforming appearance, an illuminated flagpole with adjoining landscaping and marker shall be allowed in the veterans section of Fairmount Cemetery. 
(Code 2000, § 11-4-440; Ord. No. 1031, 2001) 
Sec. 20-198. - Reservation for expansion of veterans section. 
    The city-owned property immediately adjoining the south side of Section A-H on the south end of Fairmount Cemetery shall be reserved for future expansion of the veterans section of Fairmount Cemetery. 
(Code 2000, § 11-4-450; Ord. No. 1031, 2001) 
Sec. 20-199. - Application of rules, regulations and provisions of division 3 of this chapter regarding Fairmount Cemetery. 
    All lots, plots and spaces of the veterans section of Fairmount Cemetery shall be subject to all rules, regulations and provisions applicable to the Fairmount Cemetery as set forth in sections 20-156, 20-158, 20-159, 20-160 and 20-161. 
(Code 2000, § 11-4-460; Ord. No. 1031, 2001) 
Chapter 22 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Plat requirement, C.R.S. § 31-23-101 et seq., authority to regulate subdivision of land, C.R.S. § 31-23-213 et seq.; requirements for local regulations, C.R.S. § 31-23-214. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Jurisdiction. 
    The scope of jurisdiction of the planning and zoning commission shall be limited to that area which is included within the corporate limits of the city and such contiguous unincorporated area, within three miles of the boundaries of the municipality not located in any other municipality; except that in the case of any such land lying within five miles of more than one municipality, the jurisdiction of each commission shall terminate at a boundary line equidistant from the respective municipal limits of such municipalities. The jurisdiction over the subdivision of lands outside the boundary of a municipality shall apply equally to any municipality. 
(Code 2000, § 17-1-10; Ord. No. 840, art. I, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-2. - Administration. 
    All plans for public thoroughfares, and all plans, plats, plots and replots of real property proposed in a subdivision or building lot, and all those portions to be dedicated to a public use or the use of owners and purchasers of lots fronting thereon, shall be submitted to the planning and zoning commission for approval, consistent with the requirements herein and state law, before they may be recorded. 
(Code 2000, § 17-1-20; Ord. No. 840, art. I, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means a public thoroughfare which provides only a secondary means of access to abutting property, the right-of-way of which is 20 feet or less in width. 
    Approved public sanitary sewer system means a sewage disposal plant, main sanitary sewer lines and other lines approved by the city council and/or the board of county commissioners and by the state department of health. 
    Approved public water system means a water treatment plant and service lines approved by the city council and/or the board of county commissioners and by the state department of health. 
    Block means a piece or parcel of land entirely surrounded by public highways, streets, streams, railroad rights-of-way or parks, etc., or a combination thereof. 
    Cul-de-sac means a street having one end open to traffic and being permanently terminated by a vehicle turnaround. 
    Design means the location of streets, alignment of streets, grades and widths of streets, alignment of easements, grades and widths of easements, alignment and rights-of-way for drainage and sanitary sewers, and the designation of minimum lot area, width and length. 
    Development means the act of building structures and installing site improvements. 
    Easement means a grant by the property owner to the public, a corporation or persons of the use of a strip of land for specific purposes. 
    Final plat means a plan or map prepared in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and any other applicable local regulation, which plat is prepared to be placed on record in the office of the register of deeds of the county. 
    Governing body means either of the following, as may be applicable to the particular area: 
(1)  City council. The term "city council" means the city council of the city. 
(2)  County commission. The term "county commission" means the board of county commissioners of the county. 
    Improvement means street work and utilities that are to be installed or are agreed to be installed by the subdivider on the land to be used for public or private use of the lot owners in the subdivision and local neighborhood traffic and drainage needs. 
    Lot means a portion of land in a subdivision, or other parcel of land, intended as a unit for transfer of ownership or for development. 
    Major thoroughfare means a street, highway or roadway designated as such on the official major street plan. 
    Marginal access street or frontage road means a minor street which is parallel and adjacent to a major street, highway or railroad right-of-way and provides access to abutting properties. 
    Pedestrian way means a right-of-way dedicated to public use, which cuts across a block to facilitate pedestrian access to adjacent streets and properties. 
    Planning and zoning commission means the city planning and zoning commission. 
    Planning area means the city and all land in the county lying outside the city, but within three miles of the nearest point of the city limits, unless otherwise altered by the scope of jurisdiction as set forth in section 22-1. 
    Preliminary plat means a map made for the purpose of showing the design of a proposed subdivision and the existing conditions in and around it. This map need not be based on an accurate or detailed final survey of the property. 
    Replat means the replanning and/or remapping of areas which have been previously platted and legally recorded, in order to change the existing pattern of land subdivision. 
    Resubdivision includes: 
(1)  Substandard lots of record that are combined into larger, more saleable plots in keeping with contemporary development ideas and in which new streets are opened up or in which recombination of the lots constitutes development; 
(2)  Small parcels and strips transferred to adjoining property owners in order to make minor property line adjustments; and 
(3)  Lots of adequate size that are divided or recombined in such a manner as to not let any fall below standards, but the marketability of the land is improved. 
    Secretary means the secretary of the planning and zoning commission. 
    Setback line or building line means a line on a plat, generally parallel to the street right-of-way, indicating the limit beyond which buildings or structures may not be erected or altered. 
    Street means a right-of-way, other than an alley, dedicated to the public use, or a private right-of-way serving more than one ownership, which provides principal vehicular and pedestrian access to adjacent properties. 
    Subdivider means a person, firm, corporation, partnership or association who causes land to be divided into a subdivision for himself or herself, or for others. 
    Subdivision means any parcel of land which is to be used for condominiums, apartments, or any other multiple-dwelling units, unless such land was previously subdivided and the filing accompanying such subdivision complied with applicable regulations in existence pertaining to subdivisions of substantially the same density; or the division of a lot, tract, or parcel of land into two or more lots, plats, sites, or other divisions of land for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale or of building development. The term "subdivision" includes resubdivision and, when appropriate to the context, relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or territory subdivided. 
(Code 2000, § 17-1-30; Ord. No. 840, art. II, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-4. - Pre-application. 
(a)  Discussion with the city-designated planning and zoning official is in particular recommended in order to obtain the necessary basic information and regulations. Further information should be sought and obtained from an attorney and an engineer or land surveyor by any person contemplating platting a parcel of land. The city-designated planning and zoning official shall consult with and inform other appropriate city officials as necessary regarding any proposed subdivision. 
(b)  In the discussion with the city-designated planning and zoning official, a pre-application sketch plan shall be submitted in order to resolve possible points of disagreement and in order to clarify the developer's intent. 
(c)  The sketch plan and accompanying documents, if any, shall contain at least the following information: 
(1)  Layout of streets and lots; 
(2)  Existing and proposed covenants and zoning; 
(3)  Available utilities; 
(4)  Construction types and sizes; 
(5)  Price ranges; 
(6)  Proposed commercial uses; and 
(7)  Relation to traffic arteries, schools, churches and shopping. 
(d)  The sketch plan shall be to approximate scale, but need not be drawn mechanically. 
(Code 2000, § 17-1-40; Ord. No. 840, art. III, 1986; Ord. No. 979, § 1, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-5. - Preliminary plat. 
(a)  After reaching the preliminary conclusions regarding the requirements for the proposed subdivision, the subdivider shall submit a preliminary plat together with supplementary information to the secretary of the planning and zoning commission. 
(b)  A filing fee shall accompany the filing of each preliminary plat. 
(c)  The subdivider shall submit ten copies of the preliminary plat and ten copies of a vicinity map, if the vicinity map is not on the preliminary plat, showing the location of the proposed subdivision. These plans shall be filed with the secretary at least ten days prior to the regular planning and zoning commission meeting at which the preliminary plat is to be considered. A sample plat is available in the planning department. 
(d)  Preliminary plats shall contain: 
(1)  Name and address of the subdivider; 
(2)  Designer of the subdivision and date; 
(3)  Certificate by a registered and licensed surveyor or engineer; 
(4)  Name of the subdivision; 
(5)  Topography at five-foot intervals; 
(6)  Zoning on the tract; 
(7)  A scale of one inch equals 100 feet, and a true north arrow; 
(8)  Approved control points; 
(9)  Locations and descriptions of monuments; 
(10)  Locations and principal dimensions for all proposed areas to be reserved for parks, schools and other public uses; 
(11)  Proposed sites, if any, for nonpublic use exclusive of single-family residences; 
(12)  Numbers to identify each lot and block; 
(13)  Site data, including the number of lots, typical lot size and total acres; 
(14)  Locations and dimensions, angles, bearings, lines and radii, arcs and central angles of all curves of utilities, tract boundary lines, streets (including names), easements and rights-of-way, property lines, section lines and alleys; 
(15)  Vicinity map showing the relationship of the proposed plat to the surrounding area, including: 
a.  Zoning of adjacent property; 
b.  Names of abutting subdivisions; 
c.  Names of the owners of abutting unplatted property; and 
d.  References to permanent survey monuments with ties to sections or quarter sections corners; and 
(16)  Engineering drawings, including the following: 
a.  Profiles and cross-sections of site improvements; and 
b.  Grading plans for streets and lots. 
(e)  In addition to the required preliminary plat information, the subdivider shall also submit the following: 
(1)  Performance guarantee of a type approved by the city; 
(2)  Estimate of the cost of the following: 
a.  Permanent survey monuments; 
b.  Waterlines; 
c.  Fire hydrants; 
d.  Sanitary sewers and manholes; 
e.  Storm sewers and/or drainage improvements; 
f.  Street grading, base, paving, curb and gutter and sidewalk (if required); 
g.  Street trees, signs and lights; 
h.  Gas service lines and risers; 
i.  Electric service, if underground; 
j.  Culverts, bridges or other special requirements; and 
(3)  Mailing address. 
(f)  Planning and zoning commission procedures. 
(1)  Following document submission at the next regular planning and zoning commission meeting, the preliminary plat shall be reviewed in general, and, if acceptable, shall be referred by the planning and zoning commission to the following offices for study: 
a.  City engineer's office; 
b.  Electric company; 
c.  Gas company; 
d.  Telephone company; 
e.  Cable television company; 
f.  All other franchised utility companies doing business in the city; and 
g.  Cities located within five miles of the area to be subdivided, the school district, and, where applicable, special utility districts, and the state department of transportation. 
(2)  Each of these offices shall return its recommendation to the planning and zoning commission within 30 days of receipt of its copy of the preliminary plat. 
(3)  Failure to respond within this comment period will be interpreted as no objection, and the city shall have no further responsibility for plat review coordination with nonresponding offices. 
(4)  At the following regular planning and zoning commission meeting, and after discussion with the subdivider on changes deemed advisable, including the kind and extent of improvements to be made by him or her, the planning and zoning commission shall disapprove, approve as submitted, or approve as modified the preliminary plat. 
(5)  Action by the planning and zoning commission shall be conveyed to the subdivider, in writing, within ten days after the official planning and zoning commission meeting at which the plat was considered. In case the plat is disapproved, the subdivider shall be notified of the reason for such action and what requirements shall be necessary to meet the approval of the planning and zoning commission. The approval of the preliminary plat does not constitute an acceptance of the subdivision, but is deemed to be an authorization to proceed with the preparation of the final plat. The approval of the preliminary plat shall only be effective for a period of one year, unless an extension is granted by the planning and zoning commission. If the final plat has not been submitted for approval within the specified period, a preliminary plat must be submitted again to the planning and zoning commission for approval. 
(Code 2000, § 17-1-50; Ord. No. 840, art. III, 1986; Ord. No. 979, § 2, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-6. - Final plat. 
(a)  Submission. 
(1)  After approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider shall submit a final plat for recording purposes to the secretary of the planning and zoning commission. Such plat shall be accompanied by the required filing fee. A sample plat is available in the planning department. 
(2)  The original (on Mylar, tracing cloth or similar material) and ten prints thereof shall be submitted to the secretary of the planning and zoning commission at least ten days prior to the planning and zoning commission public hearing. 
(3)  The names and signatures of the owner or of the property duly acknowledged and notarized shall appear on the original copies submitted. 
(4)  The final plat, prepared for recording purposes, shall be drawn at a scale of at least one inch equals 100 feet or larger. The size of the sheet on which such final plat is prepared shall be 22 inches by 36 inches. 
(b)  Information. The final plat shall incorporate any required modifications of the preliminary plat and shall show and contain the following information: 
(1)  Name of subdivision, which shall not duplicate or too closely approximate the name of any existing subdivision; 
(2)  Location of section, township, range, county and state, including the descriptive boundaries of the subdivision based on an accurate traverse, giving angular and linear dimensions which must be mathematically close. The allowable error of closing on any portion of the plat shall be one foot in 5,000 feet; 
(3)  The locations of monuments shall be shown and described on the final plat. Locations of such monuments shall be shown in reference to existing official monuments or the nearest established street lines, including the true angles and distances to such reference points or monuments; 
(4)  The locations of lots, streets, public highways, alleys, parks and other features, with accurate dimensions in feet and decimals of feet, and with the length of radii on all curves, and other information necessary to reproduce the plat on the ground. Dimensions from all curves shall be shown to the lot lines; 
(5)  Lots shall be numbered clearly. Blocks shall be numbered or lettered clearly in the center of the block. All lots, however designated, shall be numbered in progressive numbers or by blocks in which they are situated, and their precise lengths and widths shall be stated on the map or plat; 
(6)  The exact locations, widths and names of all streets to be dedicated; 
(7)  Locations and widths of all easements and alleys to be dedicated; 
(8)  Boundary lines and descriptions of the boundary lines of any area, other than streets and alleys, which are to be dedicated or reserved for public use; 
(9)  Building setback lines on the front and side streets, with dimensions; 
(10)  Names and addresses of the developer and the registered professional engineer who prepared the plat; 
(11)  Scale of the plat (scale is to be shown graphically and in feet per inch), date of preparation and north point; 
(12)  Statement dedicating all easements; 
(13)  Statement dedicating all streets, alleys and all other public areas not previously dedicated; and 
(14)  Mailing address of the property after subdivision. 
(c)  Final plat review. 
(1)  At the next regular planning and zoning commission meeting, the planning and zoning commission shall check the final plat for conformity with the approved preliminary plat and other requirements of this chapter, and shall then approve or disapprove the final plat as submitted. 
(2)  As a condition to the approval of a final plat, the subdivider or landowner shall agree to install improvements as noted and specified in article III of this chapter. 
(d)  Recording. 
(1)  Not more than three months after approval of the final plat by the planning and zoning commission, the subdivider shall record the final plat in the manner and condition prescribed in section 22-69. After three months, the approving action of the planning and zoning commission shall be deemed to have been withdrawn. 
(2)  Also required is a final survey of utilities, as installed, to be submitted to the city engineer. It can be a simplified version of the engineering drawings, but it should record the necessary minor changes of location that are always made in the course of construction. Certificates of improvements completion will be withheld until this survey is made. 
(Code 2000, § 17-1-60; Ord. No. 840, art. III, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 22-7-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 22-31. - Blocks. 
(a)  Design. The lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due regard to: 
(1)  Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of the type of use contemplated; 
(2)  Zoning requirements as to lot sizes and dimensions; 
(3)  Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic; and 
(4)  Limitations and opportunities of topography. 
(b)  Length. Intersecting streets which determine block lengths shall be provided at such intervals as to serve cross-traffic adequately and to meet existing streets in the neighborhood. In residential districts, where no existing plats are recorded, the blocks shall not exceed 750 feet in length, except that in outlying subdivisions, a greater length may be permitted where topography or other conditions justify a departure from this maximum. In blocks longer than 600 feet, pedestrian ways and/or easements through the block may be required by the planning and zoning commission near the center of the block. Such pedestrian ways or easements shall have a minimum width of ten feet. Blocks for business use should normally not exceed 600 feet in length. 
(c)  Width. In residential subdivisions, the block width shall normally be sufficient to allow two tiers of lots of appropriate depth. Blocks intended for business or industrial use shall be of such width and depth as may be considered most suitable for the prospective use. 
(Code 2000, § 17-2-10; Ord. No. 840, art. III, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-32. - Streets, alleys and public ways. 
(a)  The arrangement of streets in new subdivisions shall make provisions for the continuation of the principal existing streets in adjoining additions (or their proper projection where adjoining property is not subdivided) insofar as they may be necessary for public requirements. 
(1)  The width of such streets in new subdivisions shall not be less than the minimum street widths established herein. 
(2)  Alleys, when required, and street arrangement must also be such as not to cause hardship to owners of adjoining property when they plat their land and seek to provide for convenient access to it. 
(3)  Whenever there exists a dedicated or platted half-street or alley adjacent to the tract to be subdivided, the other half of the street or alley shall be platted and dedicated as a public way. 
(b)  Streets that are obviously in alignment with other already existing named streets shall bear the names of the existing streets. 
(c)  Major streets through subdivisions shall conform with the major street plan as adopted by the planning and zoning commission and the governing body. 
(d)  Minor streets shall be so designed as to discourage through or non-local traffic. 
(e)  Cul-de-sacs or dead-end streets shall be permitted only when topography or ownership prevents normal subdivision of a tract or plot of ground. Said cul-de-sacs shall normally be no longer than 500 feet, including a turnaround at the closed end having an outside roadway diameter of at least 100 feet, with a street property line diameter of at least 110 feet. 
(f)  Under normal conditions, streets shall be laid out to intersect, as nearly as possible, at right angles. Where topography or other conditions justify a variation from the right angle intersection, the minimum angle shall be 60 degrees. 
(g)  Where lots front or side, but do not back on, railroad rights-of-way, limited access freeways or principal highways, a marginal access street or frontage road shall be provided, parallel and adjacent to the boundary of such right-of-way. The distance of the street from said right-of-way shall be determined with due consideration given to minimum distance required for approach connections to future grade separations. 
(h)  Dedication of half-streets will not be approved, except where it is essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision and is in conformity with the approved major street plan and other requirements of this chapter. 
(i)  Alleys shall be provided in commercial and industrial districts, except that the requirements may be waived where other definite and ensured provisions are made for service access to off-street loading and unloading areas and to off-street parking areas, consistent with and adequate for the uses proposed. Dead-end alleys shall be avoided wherever possible, but if unavoidable, adequate turnaround facilities shall be provided. Alleys may be required in certain residential areas. 
(Code 2000, § 17-2-20; Ord. No. 840, art. IV, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-33. - Minimum requirements. 
    All streets, alleys and public ways included in any subdivision hereafter dedicated and accepted shall not be less than the minimum dimensions for each classification, as follows: 
Classification Width Major Streets Arterial 80 feet Collector 70 feet Local street 60 feet Cul-de-sac 50-foot radius on turnaround Marginal Access Streets or Frontage Roads One-way 50 feet Two-way 60 feet Alley 20 feet Pedestrian way 10 feet  
(Code 2000, § 17-2-30; Ord. No. 840, art. IV, 1986) 
Sec. 22-34. - Additional requirements. 
(a)  When existing or anticipated traffic on arterial and collector thoroughfares warrants greater widths of rights-of-way, the additional width shall be provided. 
(b)  Drainage easements shall be required, in addition to street rights-of-way, where the streets adjoin or are parallel with streams or drainage areas, or where lots back on said drainage areas. The width of such drainage easement shall be determined by the city engineer, who shall notify the planning and zoning commission of his or her recommendation, in writing. 
(c)  The grades of streets, alleys and other public ways included in any subdivision shall not be greater than is necessary for the topographical conditions. 
(d)  Minimum horizontal and vertical alignment on all streets, except in unusual cases, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Horizontal alignment. Radii at the centerline: 
a.  Major streets: 300 feet. 
b.  Local streets: 100 feet. 
A tangent shall be provided between all reversed curves to provide for a smooth flow of traffic. 
(2)  Vertical alignment. All changes in street grade shall be connected by vertical curves of such length as to provide for the desired sight distance. 
(Code 2000, § 17-2-40; Ord. No. 840, art. IV, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-35. - Lots. 
(a)  The minimum lot width shall be 50 feet, except where additional width is required on corner lots to maintain a front yard on both streets. Said width shall be measured at the building setback line. 
(b)  The minimum lot depth shall be 120 feet, except where additional depth is required on corner lots. Said measurement shall be measured through the center of the lot and shall be perpendicular to the property line or radial to the property line on curved streets. 
(c)  Minimum area shall be subject to the zoning regulations of the district in which the subdivision is located. 
(d)  Lots in subdivisions to be served with an approved public water system, but not with an approved public sanitary sewer system, shall be sized according to soil percolation tests made by a registered professional engineer. Such tests shall be made in accordance with state department of health criteria. In no case shall any such lot contain less than one-half acre, and all lots shall be so proportioned as to permit future replotting consistent with good subdivision design. 
(e)  Lots in subdivisions to be served with an approved public sanitary sewer system, but not with an approved public water system, shall contain not less than one-half acre, unless otherwise approved by the planning and zoning commission. All lots shall be so proportioned that future replatting will be consistent with good subdivision design. 
(f)  Lots in subdivisions not served by either an approved public sewer system or an approved public water system shall be sized on the basis of soil percolation tests made by a registered professional engineer. Such tests shall be in accordance with state department of health criteria. In no case shall such lots be less than 21/2 acres in area, and all lots shall be so proportioned as to permit future replatting consistent with good subdivision design. 
(g)  All side lot lines shall bear 60 degrees to 90 degrees from the street right-of-way line on a straight street, or from the tangent of a curved street. 
(h)  Corner lots in residential subdivisions shall have additional width in order that the same setback on both streets may be observed. 
(i)  Double frontage lots shall be avoided unless, in the opinion of the planning and zoning commission, a variation to this rule will give better street alignment and lot arrangement. 
(j)  Every lot shall abut on a street other than an alley. 
(k)  Building or setback lines shall be shown on the preliminary and final plats for all lots in the subdivision and shall not be less than the setback required by chapter 30. 
(l)  The subdivision or resubdivision of a tract or lot shall not be permitted where said subdivision or resubdivision places an existing permanent structure in violation of the requirements of chapter 30. 
(Code 2000, § 17-2-50; Ord. No. 840, art. IV, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-36. - Easements. 
(a)  Where alleys are not provided, permanent easements of not less than 71/2 feet in width shall be provided on each side of all rear lot lines and on side lot lines where necessary for utility poles, wires and conduits; sanitary sewers; gas, water and heat mains; and other public utilities. These easements shall provide for a continuous right-of-way at least 15 feet in width. 
(b)  A 12-foot temporary construction easement shall be provided on each side of the permanent easement required in subsection (a) of this section for initial construction of water, sewer and other utility lines. 
(c)  Where a subdivision is traversed by, or is adjacent to, a watercourse, drainage way, channel or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially with the lines of such watercourse and such further width as may be required for the construction of necessary flood control measures. 
(Code 2000, § 17-2-60; Ord. No. 840, art. IV, 1986) 
Sec. 22-37. - Dedication or reservation of public sites and open spaces. 
    In all subdivisions, consideration shall be given to potential needs for sites for schools, parks, playgrounds or other public use areas and open spaces. Any such dedication or reservation shall conform as nearly as possible to the recommendations of the planning and zoning commission with regard to the intent of the comprehensive plan and to the recommendations of other public agencies to be involved. All areas to be dedicated or reserved for public use shall be shown on the preliminary plat, in order that it may be determined when and in what manner such areas will be dedicated to or acquired by the appropriate agency. 
(Code 2000, § 17-2-70; Ord. No. 840, art. V, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 22-38-22-62. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 22-63. - Generally. 
(a)  The subdivider shall cause to be installed and constructed all street and road improvements, public utilities, survey monuments and markers and lot grading. All such improvements shall conform to the requirements of this chapter and all other applicable county and state standards, specifications, codes and regulations. These standards may be obtained, among others, from the city clerk, county clerk, planning and zoning commission, state department of transportation and state department of health. General guidelines for such improvements include the following: 
(1)  Streets shall be surfaced with concrete, asphaltic concrete or materials and specifications in accordance with the city requirements and shall include curb and storm sewer inlets where applicable. 
(2)  Where an approved public water system is proposed to serve the subdivision, said water lines shall be installed in proper easements or within the limits of the street and alley right-of-way and shall be of a size as approved by the city council. 
(3)  Where an approved public sewer system is proposed to serve the subdivision, the sewer system shall be constructed to provide service to each lot within the subdivision. The system of mains and laterals shall collect the sewage within the subdivision and discharge it into a community disposal system approved by the city council. 
(4)  Street signs will be supplied and erected by the city council. 
(5)  Installation of electric service, power lines, transformers and street lights shall be provided and paid for in accordance with policies established by the utilities board. 
(6)  Sidewalks shall be installed on both sides of all streets and shall have a minimum width of five feet unless otherwise approved by the city council. 
(b)  If other improvements are required, such as tree planting, retaining walls, drainage structures, etc., such improvements shall be made in accordance with the recommendations and specifications of the city council. 
(Code 2000, § 17-3-10; Ord. No. 840, art. VI, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-64. - Financing of required improvements. 
(a)  The subdivider shall be responsible for the cost of required improvements which include the following: 
(1)  Setting of survey monuments and markers; 
(2)  Street and road construction for all minor street improvements, including base, grading, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, pavement, street trees, street name signs, culverts and bridges; 
(3)  Water and sewer line installations, including fire hydrants and manholes; 
(4)  Required storm sewer system and/or other drainage improvements; 
(5)  Lot grading and site preparation; 
(6)  Landscaping and fencing where this is made a provision of any approval; and 
(7)  Any other site improvement made a requirement for development by the planning and zoning commission or city council. 
(b)  The subdivider shall also be responsible for ensuring the installation of the following, by negotiating with public agencies or private companies, or by providing the cash for their installation: 
(1)  Electric lines; 
(2)  Telephone lines; 
(3)  Street lights; 
(4)  Natural gas lines where required by the planning and zoning commission; 
(5)  Street name signs; 
(6)  Cable television service lines; and 
(7)  Permanent survey monuments at locations approved by the planning and zoning commission in conjunction with the city engineer, provided that ordinarily such monuments shall not be more than 1,320 feet nor less than 660 feet apart; and, in addition, monuments of iron pipe, stone or concrete shall be set at all street intersections, at all tangent points, at alley intersections, at all lot corners and at such other points as may be required by the planning and zoning commission to make the retracing of the lines shown on the final plat reasonably convenient. 
(c)  In the event that improvements are required by the planning and zoning commission that are oversized for the improvement capacity required for the subdivision, the city, county, state or responsible district shall pay for improvement installation costs that are in excess of those necessary to meet the requirements of the subdivision. These may include, among others, the following: 
(1)  Street improvements in excess of those for minor or local streets but not including rights-of-way; 
(2)  Trunk sewer and water lines but not including easements; and 
(3)  Storm sewers of a size larger than required for proper drainage of the subdivision. 
(d)  The city may assess a subdivider on a pro rata basis for costs of improvements that have been made that benefit the subdivider or subdivision that would have been necessary costs to the subdivider had they not previously been expended. Such expenditures may have been made by either a governmental agency or by a private individual through arrangements with a governmental agency. Such improvements may include, among others, the following: 
(1)  Street improvements abutting unsubdivided land; or 
(2)  Sewer or water line installations that will serve unsubdivided land when subdivided. Any monies so collected shall be refunded to the agency or individual who made the original investment. 
(e)  The subdivider shall submit an estimate of the costs of constructing the required improvements to determine the amount of performance guarantee to be required. The estimate shall specify the sources used as a basis to determine unit and project costs. The planning and zoning commission shall make any checks and revisions in the estimates as they deem necessary prior to approval. At the request of the subdivider, the planning and zoning commission shall hold a notice-published public hearing prior to making any and all revisions in the subdivider's cost estimate. The cost of publishing notice of the hearing shall be borne by the subdivider. 
(Code 2000, § 17-3-20; Ord. No. 840, art. VI, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-65. - Engineering drawings. 
(a)  The planning and zoning commission, in conjunction with the city engineer and other appropriate public agencies, shall approve all engineering drawings and construction plans prior to the commencement of any work by the subdivider. All required supplementary engineering studies or tests as required by the planning and zoning commission shall be approved prior to any construction activities by or for the subdivider. 
(b)  All required engineering studies and exhibits shall be prepared by qualified and legally registered or certified engineers or engineering firms. 
(c)  Contractors engaged by the subdivider to install required improvements shall be licensed, registered, or certified as required by state or local law. 
(d)  A time construction schedule of installation of public improvements shall be submitted to and approved by the planning and zoning commission prior to the commencement of any and all construction activities. The approved schedule shall be flexible enough to allow delays due to inclement weather or other unavoidable circumstances. In the event that construction at some time can no longer adhere to the approved schedule, the subdivider shall submit a revised schedule to the planning and zoning commission for approval. 
(e)  It may be desirable, during construction of improvements, for the subdivider to modify some standards and specifications of the approved engineering drawings. In this event, the subdivider shall, prior to making such modifications, submit a schedule of such modifications with reasons of necessity to the planning and zoning commission for approval. 
(f)  In the event that any modifications as specified in subsection (e) of this section are approved by the planning and zoning commission, the subdivider shall submit as-built drawings. 
(Code 2000, § 17-3-30; Ord. No. 840, art. VI, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-66. - Guarantees of performance. 
(a)  Before acceptance of a plat by the planning and zoning commission, the subdivider shall have designated all necessary streets and alleys in the proposed subdivision together with sidewalks, curbs and gutters, in accordance with the requirements that the planning and zoning commission may impose and specify as to grading, paving, width, location, drainage, courts, culverts, bridges and other necessary requirements. The subdivider shall enter into a written agreement with the planning and zoning commission wherein the subdivider shall have deposited a performance bond in an amount established by the planning and zoning commission, or have deposited with the city sufficient funds to cover the cost of such improvements, or provide other improvement guarantees acceptable to the planning and zoning commission and the city council, which shall be recorded in the office of the county clerk. The amount of the performance bond or the funds in escrow shall be determined from the cost estimates as specified in this article. 
(b)  The planning and zoning commission shall also require a maintenance bond to remain in effect for one year after acceptance of said improvements, to be posted by the subdivider to ensure the repairs to any installations after completion and acceptance by the city that are made necessary due to negligence, whether intentional or accidental, by the subdivider. Such required repairs might include, among others, the following: 
(1)  Damage to streets and highways caused by transporting heavy construction equipment over them; or 
(2)  Cutting and breaking street improvements to provide additional utility connections. 
(Code 2000, § 17-3-40; Ord. No. 840, art. VI, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-67. - Inspection of improvements. 
(a)  The subdivider shall obtain construction permits for any construction work when required by state or local law. 
(b)  Inspection schedules as required by state or local law shall be adhered to by the subdivider. The subdivider shall notify the appropriate governmental agency, as required by law, when certain stages of construction have been reached. The responsible governmental agency shall, within 24 working hours, inspect the indicated construction and notify the subdivider of its acceptability or unacceptability. If for some reason an improvement is unacceptable, the inspector shall indicate to the subdivider, by reference to an unmet legal requirement, what steps shall be taken by the subdivider to make the improvement acceptable. 
(Code 2000, § 17-3-50; Ord. No. 840, art. VI, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-68. - Variances for hardship. 
    Whenever it is found that the land included in a subdivision plat presented for approval is of such size or shape, is subject to or is affected by such topographical location or conditions, or is to be devoted to such usage that full conformity to the provisions of this chapter is impossible or is impractical, the planning and zoning commission may recommend to the city council, by letter, that the city council authorize a variance or exception in the final plat so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured. In recommending such variance or exception, the planning and zoning commission shall find the following: 
(1)  That there are special circumstances or conditions affecting the property; 
(2)  That the variance or exception is necessary for the reasonable and acceptable development of the property in question; and 
(3)  That the granting of the variance or exception will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to adjacent property. 
(Code 2000, § 17-3-60; Ord. No. 840, art. VII, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-69. - Miscellaneous. 
(a)  Building and zoning permits. No building permit or zoning permit shall be issued for any structure that is located upon a lot in an area that has not been subdivided, unless the subdivision of said lands has been approved according to the requirements in effect at the time of subdivision. 
(b)  Recording. No plat, replat, dedication or deed of a street or public way shall be filed with the register of deeds until such plat, replat, dedication or deed shall have endorsed on it the fact that it has been submitted and approved by the planning and zoning commission and by the city council pursuant to the standards and procedures provided in for in this Code. Nothing in this article shall require the acceptance of any dedication or deed by the city council. 
(c)  Certifications required on final plat. When the final plat is approved, certifications shall be made on the final plat, signed and acknowledged by all parties holding title or having any title interest in the land subdivided and consenting to the preparation and recording of the plat as submitted. The original and ten copies of the plat submitted shall carry the signatures of the owners, and shall be duly notarized by a notary public. 
(d)  A registered professional engineer shall sign and place his or her seal on the final plat, certifying that the physical and mathematical details on the plat are correct. 
(e)  Certification of the official approval of the final plat shall provide for date and signature of the following: 
(1)  Chairperson and secretary of the planning and zoning commission; 
(2)  City council, to be signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk; 
(3)  Entry for the date and transfer of record with space for the signature of the county clerk; and 
(4)  Space for the recording of the instrument and the name of the register of deeds. 
(Code 2000, § 17-3-70; Ord. No. 840, art. VIII, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-70. - Supplemental documents to accompany the final plat. 
(a)  Two prints of profiles of streets to be dedicated, indicating the grades thereon, may be required by the planning and zoning commission for plats submitted. 
(b)  If private restrictions are to be filed affecting the subdivision or any part thereof, two copies shall be submitted to the planning and zoning commission with the final plat. 
(Code 2000, § 17-3-80; Ord. No. 840, art. VIII, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1030, 2001) 
Sec. 22-71. - Submission to city council. 
(a)  After approval of the final plat by the planning and zoning commission, such final plat, together with the recommendation of the planning and zoning commission, shall be transmitted to the city council for its review and action. 
(b)  Upon receipt of any approved final plat from the planning and zoning commission and its recommendation thereon, the city council shall schedule a public hearing upon said final plat and planning and zoning commission recommendation. Notice of such public hearing shall be given by posting of the premises proposed to be subdivided, and by publication in the manner of other legal publications at least ten days prior to the date of such public hearing. Following public hearing, the city council, in its discretion, may approve, approve as modified or disapprove any such final plat submitted. 
(Code 2000, § 17-3-90; Ord. No. 840, art. VIII, 1986; Ord. No. 979, § 3, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-72. - Recorded plats. 
    Ten copies of the recorded plat shall be provided by the subdivider and shall be submitted to the secretary of the planning and zoning commission, for distribution as follows: 
(1)  Planning and zoning commission file; 
(2)  City clerk; 
(3)  City engineer; 
(4)  Building official; and 
(5)  Utility companies (water, gas, electricity, telephone, cable television). 
(Code 2000, § 17-3-100; Ord. No. 840, art. VIII, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-73. - Amendment. 
    The planning and zoning commission and the city council may amend the requirements of this chapter after giving public notice of any such proposed amendment, and after holding a public hearing thereon, as provided by C.R.S. § 31-23-214. 
(Code 2000, § 17-3-110; Ord. No. 840, art. IX, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 22-74. - Interpretation. 
    In the interpretation and application of the provisions of this chapter, the following regulations shall govern: 
(1)  The provisions of this chapter shall be regarded as the minimum requirements for the protection of the public health, safety, comfort, morals, convenience, prosperity and welfare. This chapter shall therefore be regarded as remedial, and shall be liberally construed to further its underlying purposes. 
(2)  Whenever both a provision of this chapter and any other provisions of this chapter or any provision in any other law, ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation of any kind contain any restrictions covering any of the same subject matter, whichever restrictions are more restrictive or impose higher standards or requirements shall govern. 
(3)  This chapter is not intended to abrogate or annul: 
a.  Any permits issued before the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived; or 
b.  Any easement, covenant or other private agreement. 
(Code 2000, § 17-3-120; Ord. No. 840, art. X, 1986; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Chapter 24 - TAXATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Definitions and meaning. 
    Terms used in this chapter which are defined in C.R.S. title 39, art. 26, shall have the same meaning as provided for by the provisions of said state law, unless otherwise stated. 
Sec. 24-2. - Definitions applicable to the city. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City clerk means the city clerk of the City of Lamar. 
    City treasurer means the city treasurer of the City of Lamar. 
    Drugs dispensed in accordance with a prescription means drugs dispensed in accordance with any prescription or order in writing, dated and signed by any licensed practitioner of the healing arts and sciences, or given orally by a practitioner and immediately reduced to writing by the pharmacist, assistant pharmacist or pharmacy intern, specifying the name and address of the person for whom the medicine, drug or poison is offered and directions, if any, to be placed on the label. The term "drugs dispensed in accordance with a prescription" shall include medical marijuana dispensed following a doctor's written order or recommendation. 
    Sales price means the gross value of all the materials, labor, services and the profit thereon included in the price charged to the user or consumer. 
(Code 2000, §§ 4-1-10, 4-2-70; Ord. No. 577, §§ 1, 37, 1968; Ord. No. 917, § 1, 1993; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1032, § 2, 2001; Ord. No. 1152, §§ 1, 2, 2010; Ord. No. 1222, 11-27-2017) 
Sec. 24-3. - Definitions in general. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Agricultural producer means a person regularly engaged in the business of using land for the production of commercial crops or commercial livestock. The term "agricultural producer" includes farmers, market gardeners, commercial fruit growers, livestock breeders, dairy persons, poultry persons, and other persons similarly engaged, but does not include a person who breeds or markets animals, birds, or fish for domestic pets nor a person who cultivates, grows, or harvests plants or plant products exclusively for that person's own consumption or casual sale. 
    Aircraft means a device that is used or intended to be used for flight in the air. 
    Aircraft part means any tangible personal property that is intended to be permanently affixed or attached as a component part of an aircraft. 
    Aircraft simulator means a flight simulator training device (FSTD) as defined in part 1 of title 14 of the Code of Federal Regulations that is qualified in accordance with part 60 of title 14 of the Code of Federal Regulations for use in a Federal Aviation Administration-approved flight training program. 
    Aircraft simulator part means any tangible personal property that is originally designed and intended to be permanently affixed or attached as a component part of an aircraft, and which will also function when it is permanently affixed or attached as a component part of an aircraft simulator. 
    Airline company means any operator who engages in the carriage by aircraft of persons or property as a common carrier for compensation or hire, or the carriage of mail, or any aircraft operator who operates regularly between two or more points and publishes a flight schedule. The term "airline company" shall not include operators whose aircraft are all certified for a gross takeoff weight of 12,500 pounds or less and who do not engage in scheduled service or mail carriage service. 
    Auction means any sale where tangible personal property is sold by an auctioneer who is either the agent for the owner of such property or is in fact the owner thereof. 
    Automotive vehicle means any vehicle or device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway, or any device used or designed for aviation or flight in the air. The term "automotive vehicle" includes, but is not limited to, motor vehicles, trailers, semi-trailers, or mobile homes. The term "automotive vehicle" shall not include devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
    Business means all activities engaged in or caused to be engaged in with the object of gain, benefit, or advantage, either direct or indirect. 
    Candy means a preparation of sugar, honey, or other natural or artificial sweeteners in combination with chocolate, fruit, nuts, or other ingredients or flavorings in the form of bars, drops, or pieces. The term "candy" does not include any preparation containing flour, products that require refrigeration or marijuana-infused products. 
    Carrier access services means the services furnished by a local exchange company to its customers who provide telecommunications services which allow them to provide such telecommunications services. 
    Charitable organization means any entity which: 
(1)  Has been certified as a nonprofit organization under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code; and 
(2)  Is an organization which exclusively, and in a manner consistent with existing laws and for the benefit of an indefinite number of persons or animals, freely and voluntarily ministers to the physical, mental, or spiritual needs of persons or animals, and thereby lessens the burden of government. 
    Coins means monetized bullion or other forms of money manufactured from gold, silver, platinum, palladium or other such metals now, in the future or heretofore designated as a medium of exchange under the laws of the state, the United States or any foreign nation. 
    Collection costs shall include, but is not limited to, all costs of audit, assessment, bank fees, hearings, execution, lien filing, distraint, litigation, locksmith fees, auction fees and costs, prosecution and attorney fees. 
    Commercial packaging materials means containers, labels, and/or cases that become part of the finished product to the purchaser, used by or sold to a person engaged in manufacturing, compounding, wholesaling, jobbing, retailing, packaging, distributing or bottling for sale, profit or use, and is not returnable to said person for reuse. The term "commercial packaging materials" does not include commercial shipping materials. 
    Commercial shipping materials means materials that do not become part of the finished product to the purchaser which are used exclusively in the shipping process. The term "commercial shipping materials" includes but is not limited to, containers, labels, pallets, banding material and fasteners, shipping cases, shrink wrap, bubble wrap or other forms of binding, padding or protection. 
    Community organization means a nonprofit entity organized and operated exclusively for the promotion of social welfare, primarily engaged in promoting the common good and general welfare of the community, so long as: 
(1)  No part of the net earnings of which inures to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual; 
(2)  No substantial part of the activities of which is carrying on propaganda, or otherwise attempting to influence legislation; and 
(3)  Which does not participate in, or intervene in (including the publishing or distributing of statements), any political campaign on behalf of any candidate for public office. 
    Construction equipment means any equipment, including mobile machinery and mobile equipment, which is used to erect, install, alter, repair, remodel, or otherwise make improvements to any real property, building, structure or infrastructure. 
    Construction materials means tangible personal property which, when combined with other tangible personal property, loses its identity to become an integral and inseparable part of a structure or project including public and private improvements. The term "construction materials" includes, but is not limited to, such things as: asphalt, bricks, builders' hardware, caulking material, cement, concrete, conduit, electric wiring and connections, fireplace inserts, electrical heating and cooling equipment, flooring, glass, gravel, insulation, lath, lead, lime, lumber, macadam, millwork, mortar, oil, paint, piping, pipe valves and pipe fittings, plaster, plumbing fixtures, putty, reinforcing mesh, road base, roofing, sand, sanitary sewer pipe, sheet metal, site lighting, steel, stone, stucco, tile, trees, shrubs and other landscaping materials, wall board, wall coping, wallpaper, weather stripping, wire netting and screen, water mains and meters, and wood preserver. The above materials, when used for forms, or other items which do not remain as an integral or inseparable part of completed structure or project, are not construction materials. 
    Consumer means any individual person or person engaged in business in the city who uses, stores, distributes or otherwise consumes in the city tangible personal property or taxable services purchased from sources inside or outside the city. 
    Contract auditor means a duly authorized agent designated by the taxing authority and qualified to conduct tax audits on behalf of and pursuant to an agreement with the municipality. 
    Contractor means any person who shall build, construct, reconstruct, alter, expand, modify, or improve any building, dwelling, structure, infrastructure, or other improvement to real property for another party pursuant to an agreement.
