(Code 2000, § 4-1-120; Ord. No. 577, § 12, 1968; Ord. No. 664, § 8, 1974; Ord. No. 917, § 5, 1993; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1152, § 3, 2010) 
Sec. 24-135. - Credit sales. 
    Whenever an article is sold under a conditional sales contract whereby the seller retains title as security for all or part of the purchase price, or whenever the seller takes a chattel mortgage on the article to secure all or part of the purchase price, the total tax based on the total selling price shall become immediately due and payable. This tax shall be charged and collected by the seller. No refund or credit shall be allowed to either party to the transaction in case of repossession. 
(Code 2000, § 4-1-100; Ord. No. 577, § 10, 1968) 
Secs. 24-136-24-153. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - USE TAX 

Sec. 24-154. - Use tax levied. 
    There is hereby imposed, and there shall be collected from every person in the city, a tax or excise for the privilege of storing, using or consuming within the city any article of tangible personal property purchased at retail. The rate of such tax or excise hereby imposed shall be equal to three percent. 
(Code 2000, § 4-2-10; Ord. No. 577, § 31, 1968; Ord. No. 664, § 5, 1974; Ord. No. 754, § 5, 1990; Ord. No. 881, § 2, 1990; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1049, § 7, 2002) 
Sec. 24-155. - Exemptions from use tax. 
    The use tax imposed by this article shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  The storage, use or consumption of any tangible personal property, the sale of which is subject to the sales tax imposed, and which retail sales tax was paid. 
(2)  The storage, use or consumption of any tangible personal property purchased for resale in the city, either in its original form or as an ingredient of a manufactured or compounded product in the regular course of business. 
(3)  The storage, use or consumption of motor fuel upon which there has accrued or has been paid the motor fuel tax prescribed under the motor fuel tax under state law. 
(4)  The storage, use or consumption of tangible personal property brought into the city by a person not residing in the city for his or her own storage, use or consumption while temporarily within the city. 
(5)  The storage, use or consumption of tangible personal property, the sale or use of which is subject to an excise tax under federal or state laws, where such excise tax amounts to more than 121/2 percent of the sale price under said laws; or the storage, use or consumption of such property by the United States Government, by the state, its institutions or political subdivisions; or by religious or charitable corporations in the conduct of their regular religious or charitable functions. 
(6)  The storage, use or consumption of tangible personal property by a person engaged in the business of manufacturing, compounding for sale, profit or use any article, substance or commodity, which tangible personal property enters into the processing of or becomes an ingredient or component part of the production or service which is manufactured, compounded or furnished, and the exempt commercial packaging material thereof. 
(7)  The storage, use or consumption of electricity, coal, coke, fuel oil or gas, for use in processing, manufacturing, mining, refining, irrigation, building construction, telegraph, telephone and radio communication, street and railroad transportation service and all industrial use. 
(8)  The storage, use or consumption of printer ink and newsprint. 
(9)  The storage, use or consumption of cigarettes, fermented malt beverages and malt, vinous or spirituous liquors. 
(10)  Purchases of machinery or machine tools, or parts thereof, in excess of $500.00 to be used in the city, directly or predominantly in manufacturing tangible personal property, for sale or profit. 
(Code 2000, § 4-2-20; Ord. No. 577, § 32, 1968; Ord. No. 917, § 10, 1993; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1032, § 1, 2001) 
Sec. 24-156. - Use tax on motor vehicles and trailers. 
    Any person residing in the city who shall lease or purchase any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer, whether new or used, outside the corporate limits of the city for use within the city, shall immediately and prior to registering and obtaining a license therefor, make a return, showing such transaction to the city clerk, and thereupon pay to the city clerk the full amount of use tax applicable thereto, as provided in this article. All such motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers purchased or leased outside the corporate limits of the city for use in the city shall be registered with the county clerk and recorder, and no person person shall register any such motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer in any other county in the state or elsewhere. Any such registration shall constitute prima facie evidence of an attempt to evade payment of such tax. 
(Code 2000, § 4-2-80; Ord. No. 577, § 38, 1968; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 24-157. - Use tax; construction materials. 
(a)  The building official and the city clerk shall coordinate their efforts and cooperate each with the other to ensure proper collection of sales tax upon all construction materials utilized within the city. 
(b)  The building official, upon the issuance of each building permit issued by the building official, shall cause the receipt for said building permit to be endorsed with the following notice: 
NOTICE 
The owner of the project which constitutes the subject of the within building permit shall be responsible, upon the completion of construction of said project, for the payment of use tax at the current rate of three percent upon all materials utilized in the construction of said project which have not already been subject to sales tax collection by the city or any other municipal taxing entity. 
(c)  The city clerk shall, upon the projected completion date of any such construction project, mail to the owner thereof a use tax form. Whereupon the owner of said construction project, in respect of which said property owner has not theretofore paid sales tax to the city or any other municipal taxing authority, shall pay use tax at the current rate. 
(d)  Pursuant to C.R.S. § 29-2-109(7), the storage of construction materials is exempt from the tax established by this article. 
(Code 2000, § 4-2-90; Ord. No. 577, § 39, 1968; Ord. No. 905, § 4, 1992; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
State Law reference- Remittance of sales and use tax on construction and building materials, C.R.S. § 29-2-105(2). 
Chapter 26 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Adoption of codes by reference, C.R.S. § 31-16-201 et seq.; adoption of penalty provisions must include penalty provision, C.R.S. § 31-16-204. 

Sec. 26-1. - Adoption of Model Traffic Code. 
    Pursuant to C.R.S. § 31-16-201 et seq., there is hereby adopted by reference articles I and II, inclusive, of the 2010 edition of the Model Traffic Code promulgated and published as such by the state department of transportation, safety and traffic engineering branch, 4201 East Arkansas Avenue, EP 700, Denver, Colorado 80222. The subject matter of the Model Traffic Code relates primarily to comprehensive traffic control regulations for the city. The purpose of this chapter is to provide a system of traffic regulations consistent with state law and generally conforming to similar regulations throughout the state and the nation. Three copies of the Model Traffic Code adopted herein are now filed in the office of the city clerk at 102 East Parmenter Street, Lamar, Colorado, and may be examined during regular business hours. The 2010 edition of the Model Traffic Code is adopted as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 2000, § 8-1-10; Ord. No. 958, §§ 1, 2, 1996; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1061, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 1174, 2012) 
Sec. 26-2. - Amendments to Model Traffic Code. 
    The adopted code is subject to the following amendment: section 614 is added to read as follows: 
    "614. Designation of highway maintenance; repair; construction zones; signs; increase in penalties for speeding violations. (1) If maintenance, repair or construction activities are occurring or will be occurring within four hours on a state highway or municipal street, the department of transportation or municipal authorities, within their respective jurisdictions, may designate such portion of the highway as a highway maintenance, repair or construction zone. Any person who commits a speeding violation in a maintenance, repair or construction zone that is designated pursuant to the provisions of this section is subject to increased penalties and surcharges. 
a.  The department of transportation or municipal authorities, within their respective jurisdiction, shall designate by appropriate signs, a maintenance, repair or construction activity is taking place or will be taking place within four hours. Such sign shall notify the public that increased penalties for speeding violations are in effect in such zone. The department of transportation or local authorities shall erect or place a second sign after such zone indicating that the increased penalties for speeding violations are no longer in effect. A maintenance, repair or construction zone begins at the location of the sign indicating that increased penalties are in effect and ends at the location of the sign indicating that the increased penalties are no longer in effect. 
b.  Signs used for designating the beginning and end of a maintenance, construction or repair zone shall conform to department of transportation requirements. The department of transportation or local authority may display such signs on any fixed, variable or moveable stand. The department of transportation or local authority may place such a sign on a moving vehicle if required for certain activities, including, but not limited to, highway painting work." 
(Code 2000, § 8-1-20; Ord. No. 958, § 3, 1996; Ord. No. 984, § 1, 1997; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1061, § 1, 2003) 
Sec. 26-3. - Application. 
    This chapter shall apply to every street, alley, sidewalk area, driveway, park and every other public place or public way or public parking area, either within or outside the corporate limits of the city, the use of which the city has jurisdiction and authority to regulate. The provisions of sections 1401, 1402 and 1413 of the adopted Model Traffic Code, respectively concerning reckless driving, careless driving and eluding a police officer, shall apply not only to public places and ways but also throughout the city. 
(Code 2000, § 8-1-30; Ord. No. 958, § 5, 1996; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1061, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 1174, 2012) 
Sec. 26-4. - Interpretation. 
    This chapter shall be so interpreted and construed as to effectuate its general purpose to conform with the state's uniform system for the regulation of vehicles and traffic. Article and section headings of this article and the adopted Model Traffic Code shall not be deemed to govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or extent of the provisions of any article or section thereof. 
(Code 2000, § 8-1-40; Ord. No. 958, § 8, 1996; Ord. No. 1061, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 1174, 2012) 
Sec. 26-5. - Penalties. 
    In accordance with C.R.S. § 13-10-113(1.5) and the city Charter, any person convicted of a violation of this chapter may suffer the penalties provided by this Code; in addition, pursuant to C.R.S. § 42-4-1710, certain penalties shall result due to failure to pay a penalty for traffic offenses, and/or failure of a parent or guardian to sign a penalty assessment notice, as follows: 
(1)  a.  Unless a person who has been cited for a traffic infraction pays the penalty assessment as provided in this Code and surcharge thereon pursuant to C.R.S. § 24-4.2-104(1), the person shall appear at a hearing on the date and time specified in the citation and answer the complaint against such person. 
b.  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (1)a of this section, a minor under the age of 18 years shall be required to appear at a hearing on the date and time specified in the citation and answer the complaint if the penalty assessment was timely paid but not signed and notarized in the manner required by C.R.S. § 42-4-1709(1.5). 
(2)  If a minor under the age of 18 years is required to appear at a hearing pursuant to subsection (1) of this section, the minor shall so inform his or her parent or legal guardian, and the parent or legal guardian shall also be required to appear at the hearing. 
(3)  If the violator answers that he or she is guilty or if the violator fails to appear for the hearing, judgment shall be entered against the violator. 
(4)  If the violator denies the allegations in the complaint, a final hearing on the complaint shall be held subject to the provisions regarding a speedy trial which are contained in C.R.S. § 18-1-405. If the violator is found guilty or liable at such final hearing or if the violator fails to appear for a final hearing, judgment shall be entered against the violator. 
(5)  If judgment is entered against a violator, the violator shall be assessed an appropriate penalty and surcharge thereon, a docket fee, and other applicable costs authorized by ordinance or the court. If the violator had been cited by a penalty assessment notice, the penalty shall be assessed pursuant to this Code. 
(Code 2000, § 8-1-50; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1061, § 1, 2003; Ord. No. 1174, 2012) 
Sec. 26-6. - Certification. 
    The city clerk shall certify to the passage of this article and make no less than three copies of the adopted code available for inspection by the public during regular business hours. 
(Code 2000, § 8-1-60; Ord. No. 1174, 2012) 
Sec. 26-7. - Parking prohibited at certain times and places; penalty. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person or operator of any motor-propelled vehicle, or other vehicle used to transport or carry persons or property, to park on any street or alley in the city for a period of time longer than that shown on the official signs so stating the maximum period of parking, provided that it shall not be unlawful for any such vehicles to park beyond such maximum time in such designated places as shown by such official signs between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. and on Sundays and legal holidays. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any vehicle weighing more than 20,000 pounds to be parked, stored, or left unattended on any residential street or alley which is maintained by the city. Residential streets shall be defined as those city-maintained streets located within the zones, or districts, as shown on the official zoning map designated as R-1 Residence District, R-2 Residence District, R-3 Residence District, M-H Mobile Home District, PUD Planned Unit Development District, and O-E Open Estates. 
(c)  No vehicle shall be parked beyond the maximum time limit designated in subsection (a) of this section. Parking a vehicle for one or more subsequent periods of time in excess of the time designated shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Prior Code, § 16-4; Code 2000, § 8-2-10; Ord. No. 525, §§ 1-3; Ord. No. 1174, 2012; Ord. No. 1197, pt. 1, 2015) 
Sec. 26-8. - Designation and use of unmetered parking zones. 
(a)  The city council or the traffic engineer may from time to time designate unmetered parking spaces within such areas as the city council or the traffic engineer may determine, and such hourly times for parking in such spaces may be designated by the city council by resolution or by the traffic engineer. 
(b)  During such designated hourly times or any which may be from time to time adopted by the city council, no person shall cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his or her name to be parked or standing under and within any such unmetered parking space when such vehicle has been parked within such space longer than the designated hours. 
(Prior Code, § 16-5; Code 2000, § 8-2-20; Ord. No. 448, § 4; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 26-9. - Parking and speed regulations. 
(a)  Parking is prohibited at those points along the portions of U.S. Highways 50 and 287 which are within 20 feet of any intersection. Parking is also prohibited at all times along the portion of such street which is between the northerly ATSF Railroad track and Beech Street. Parking when and where permitted shall be parallel, as provided by law for parallel parking. Upon the basis of engineering and traffic investigations by the state department of transportation and by the city, it has been determined that reasonable and true prima facie speed limits on such portions of such street, except as otherwise provided in this section, shall be 35 miles per hour in the business district and 35 miles per hour on the remaining portions, provided that standard signs are erected giving notice of the authorized speed as provided by state statutes. 
(b)  Upon the basis of engineering and traffic investigations and determinations pursuant to state statutes, such investigations and determinations having been made by the state department of transportation in behalf of the city, it is hereby declared that when standard signs are erected giving notice thereof, a reasonable and true prima facie speed limit on the portions of streets named below shall be as specified in the following schedule:

Sec. 26-10. - State approval of parking and traffic regulations. 
    All traffic and parking regulations hereafter adopted which pertain to the streets and roadways which form a part of the state highway system or being a connecting link thereof shall be submitted to the state department of transportation for approval in accordance with the provisions of state law before they shall become effective.

    Any city police officer is authorized to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior Code, § 16-13; Code 2000, § 8-2-50; Ord. No. 443, § 9; Ord. No. 488, § 10; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 26-12. - Refusal to observe barricades and traffic cones. 
    It is unlawful to remove, alter or change any traffic control device, sign, barricade or traffic cone. It is also unlawful to drive around barricades or traffic cones in the roadway, or enter parking lots that are closed by the city. 
(Code 2000, § 8-3-10; Ord. No. 1112, § 1, 2007) 
Chapter 28 - UTILITIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 28-1-28-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND SEWER SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-19. - Water conservation. 
(a)  The public works department is hereby directed to, at all times, closely and diligently monitor the water supply available to the municipal water system, to inform the city council and the water advisory board on a timely basis as to the condition and circumstances of the then-available water supply, and to take such measures as the department may deem necessary to educate and inform the public as to the need for conservation of the city water supply and methods whereby said water supply might be conserved, and to investigate all measures aimed toward preserving the integrity of the municipal water system. 
(b)  In the discretion of the city council, in consultation with the public works department and the water advisory board, and as water availability and quality circumstances might dictate, the city council is hereby authorized and directed to implement voluntary water conservation restrictions on the use of water for some or all purposes by some or all users of the municipal water system. Said voluntary conservation restrictions shall be as set forth by resolution adopted by the city council. 
(Code 2000, § 13-2-60; Ord. No. 877, §§ 1, 2, 1989; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1059, 2003) 
Sec. 28-20. - Water use restrictions. 
(a)  Mandatory water use restrictions shall be considered for implementation at any time the following criteria are met: 
(1)  An emergency occurs, as determined by the public works director in consultation with the city administrator, which disrupts the city's ability to distribute water through its water distribution system; or 
(2)  Water availability and quality conditions, as determined by the public works director in consultation with the city administrator and the water advisory board, dictate the need for mandatory water use restrictions. 
(b)  In the event that the criteria for mandatory water use restrictions described in subsection (a) of this section shall be disclosed to the city council by the public works director and city administrator, the city council, as water availability and quality circumstances might dictate, is hereby authorized to implement mandatory water use restrictions on the use of water for some or all purposes by some or all users of the municipal water system. Said mandatory water use restrictions shall be as set forth by resolution adopted by the city council by a phone poll or an in-person majority vote. 
(Code 2000, § 13-2-70; Ord. No. 877, § 3, 1989; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000; Ord. No. 1059, 2003) 
Sec. 28-21. - Emergency restrictions. 
    Nothing herein contained shall be construed or interpreted as limiting or prohibiting the imposition of water use restrictions more stringent than as described above, provided that such further restrictions shall be implemented, if at all, by the city council in emergency circumstances. 
(Code 2000, § 13-2-80; Ord. No. 877, § 7, 1989) 
Sec. 28-22. - Unauthorized tapping and usage prohibited. 
    No person, without first having obtained permission therefor, shall tap any water main, pump or hydrant of the city water system, nor in any manner take or use any water therefrom or interfere with, injure or destroy the same. 
(Prior Code, § 24-14; Code 2000, § 13-2-90; Ord. No. 46, § 1) 
Secs. 28-23-28-49. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTION REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 28-50. - Water and sewer taps. 
(a)  This article shall provide standards, rules and regulations, and shall govern the provisions of all water and sewer services furnished by the city, whether inside or outside the city limits. 
(b)  Any applicant or developer seeking to obtain city water and sewer services, or any other city services exclusive of electrical service, to premises outside of the city shall be required, as a condition precedent to the furnishing of such services, to execute and deliver agreements governing the usage of said extraterritorial premises, including, but not limited to, agreements requiring annexation, agreements concerning water restrictions and agreements in respect of the city's zoning and subdivision ordinances, including, but not limited to, street lighting plans, traffic regulatory sign plans, street names, sign plans, stormwater system plans and street system layouts and plans for the purpose of street extension, alignment, orderly growth and traffic flow; and finally, all applicable building and construction codes of the city, such as, but not limited to, building code, building code standards, fire code, fire code standards, mechanical code, housing code, plumbing code and the code for abatement of dangerous buildings. No water, sewer or other city services, excepting electrical service, shall be extended to serve any building, development or subdivision outside of the city's corporate limits without such agreements as may be required, and without satisfactory guaranty to the city of the ability to comply with the requirements of said agreements. Said agreements shall be binding upon the applicant or developer, his or her heirs, successors, administrators and assigns, and shall be considered as covenants running with the land thus developed. 
(c)  Applicants or developers shall be required to grant and convey to the city all necessary rights-of-way and easements for installation and maintenance of city utility lines. All lines and equipment necessary for the furnishing of extraterritorial water and sewer services, with the exception of service lines, shall be conveyed to the city. 
(d)  All installations of extraterritorial water and sewer service shall be performed at the cost of the applicant or developer, with all fees, including tap fees, to be paid in advance of the issuance of connection. All connections shall be inspected by the building official or by appropriate city personnel, with the applicant or developer to pay any costs incurred. All such water and wastewater taps shall be restricted exclusively to the site designated in the application. Fees and costs incurred by the applicant or developer are not refundable, and the applicant or owner shall be required to furnish appropriate performance, construction or other types of bonding as may be required by the city to protect its interest. At the city's discretion, appropriate escrow arrangements may be substituted in lieu of required bonding. 
(e)  The minimum size of any water main shall be six inches. The city reserves the right to establish type, size, location and all other specifications regarding water mains, sewer trunk lines, valves and other necessary equipment. All water mains shall be looped, in accordance with state health department regulations and city requirements. Water mains shall be sufficient to provide for fire protection, with fire hydrants to be installed by city personnel at the expense of the applicant or developer. 
(f)  The city shall determine, in its sole discretion, the number of taps to be provided, along with location and size, depending upon capacity and water availability. Use restrictions may be implemented by the city council, at its discretion, and by the public works department in the event of emergencies. Nothing in this article or rising out of the city's provisions of extraterritorial water and sewer services shall operate to transform the city into a public utility, it being fully understood that the city is not a public utility but is a municipally-operated water and sewer system, with citizens of the city having first and prior privilege to draw upon the city's water and sewer installations. 
(g)  In appropriate circumstances and at the sole discretion of the city council, water districts may be formed, in which cases, master meters shall be installed by city personnel with the cost incurred being borne by the applicant or developer. Said master meters shall be owned and maintained by the city, and such districts shall be governed by such agreements as may be entered into between such districts and the city council. Mergers and dissolutions of existing city districts shall be reviewed and adopted by agreement between the applicant or owner and the city council. 
(h)  Any agreement for the provision of extraterritorial water and sewer services by the city shall include penalty provisions for noncompliance by the applicant or owner of any part of any agreement entered into pursuant to this section, or for any violation of this section. Any such agreement shall further provide provisions regarding main extension or reimbursement, whereby the owner or developer shall be enabled to recover a reasonable portion of the expenses incurred in the process of installing water or sewer services, but the city retains the right to refuse permission for any extension or expansion of extraterritorial water or sewer services. 
(i)  Upon proper application, the water advisory board may consider application for waiver of any of the provisions hereinabove set forth, and may forward to the city council a recommendation for such waiver to be granted in respect of any of the provisions of this section wherein waiver might be deemed appropriate. Such recommendation by the water advisory board is recommendatory only, and shall not be binding upon the city council. The city reserves the right to require recordation of all or any portion of any agreement entered into in respect of this section. 
(Code 2000, § 13-1-20; Ord. No. 872, 1989; Ord. No. 963, § 1, 1996; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-51. - Connection to sewage system required. 
    No person shall construct or maintain a privy vault or toilet unconnected with the sewage system of the city or a cesspool on any lot or parcel of land where such lot or parcel of land is so situated that it can be connected with the city sewage system, except when the city shall find that such connection cannot be made. 
(Prior Code, § 21-1; Code 2000, § 13-1-30; Ord. No. 286, § 1) 
Sec. 28-52. - Sewer connections. 
    The city shall make the tap for connection into the main with materials furnished by the property owner or person making the connection, and no connection shall be made by any person other than in this manner. The lines from the main to the property line shall be vitrified clay or its equal and shall be joined together by GK material or equal. Each connection shall be four inches or larger in size. All connections shall be made to the satisfaction of the city, including refilling and replacing of dirt removed to make such connection. 
(Prior Code, § 21-2; Code 2000, § 13-1-40; Ord. No. 449, § 2; Ord. No. 459, § 1; Ord. No. 869, § 1, 1989; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-53. - Water meters. 
(a)  All persons obtaining water from the city shall have such water supplied only through a water meter. Separate meters shall be required for each consumer. 
(b)  No water meter in excess of one inch shall be furnished, installed or connected to any water main of the city to furnish water to any property used for residential purposes, provided that hotels and motels shall not be considered residential purposes. Consumers other than residential shall be entitled to meters in excess of one inch, provided that all the provisions of this article applicable to such meters are followed. 
(c)  When any water meter in excess of one inch used to measure water to property used for residential purposes shall be disconnected for seasonal purposes or otherwise, the same shall be replaced only by a one-inch meter or less. 
(d)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, any water consumer may apply for and have any noncomplying water meter exchanged for any smaller size meter which complies with this article, without any charge for connection, disconnection or differential in meter sizes. 
(e)  Any water consumer entitled to the installation of a meter in excess of three-quarters of an inch shall pay to the city prior to the installation and connection of such meter a sum equal to the difference in cost to the city between a three-quarter-inch meter and the size meter desired. Such cost shall be the cost at the time of application of the installation of such meter. 
(f)  There shall be assessed and collected by the city a reconnection charge as established by the city council to reconnect any meter which has been disconnected for seasonal purposes or otherwise. 
(g)  If any water meter shall fail to register during any given month, the consumer chargeable for such meter shall be charged for use of water for such month a sum equal to the average charge for consumption as shown by such meter, when in order, for a period of 12 months prior to such month. 
(Prior Code, §§ 24-2-24-8; Code 2000, § 13-2-20; Ord. No. 419, §§ 3-5; Ord. No. 471, § 2; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 28-54-28-79. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FEES AND BILLING 

Sec. 28-80. - Plant investment fees. 
(a)  Plant investment fees are as established by the city council. 
(b)  In addition to the plant investment fees, customers shall pay to the city the actual cost of labor, equipment usage and materials furnished for installation of such taps. 
(c)  All plant investment fees charged to users located outside the city shall be double the specified plant investment fees. 
(Code 2000, § 13-1-50; Ord. No. 869, § 2, 1989; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-81. - Water fees. 
    Rates and charges for use of water from the city water system shall be as established by the city council. 
(Code 2000, § 13-1-60; Ord. No. 869, § 3, 1989; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-82. - Sewer system fees. 
(a)  Rates and charges for the use of the city sewer system for each user shall be as established by the city council. 
(b)  For commercial users of the city sewer system, the volume charge fee levied for sewer usage in excess of the monthly minimum of 900 cubic feet shall be based upon the average metered water consumption of such consumer for the months of December, January and February of each preceding year; provided, however, that all businesses engaged in the washing of motor vehicles shall be liable for a sewer rate charge based upon actual monthly usage of metered water supply. 
(Code 2000, § 13-1-70; Ord. No. 869, § 4, 1989; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-83. - Miscellaneous fees. 
    Additional charges as established by the city council are hereby levied for services performed and for usage of the city's water and sewer utilities. 
(Code 2000, § 13-1-80; Ord. No. 869, § 5, 1989; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-84. - Amendment. 
    All rates, charges and fees established for water and sewer connection and usage may hereafter be established, amended and modified by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 2000, § 13-1-90; Ord. No. 869, §§ 6, 7, 1989; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-85. - Connection charges. 
(a)  Connection charges for connecting water lines to the city water distribution system shall be as established by the city council. 
(b)  There is hereby established by the city council a charge for the disconnection of any existing water meter, and a charge for the reconnection of any existing water meter so disconnected under this section. 
(Prior Code, § 24-1; Code 2000, § 13-2-10; Ord. No. 457, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 791, §§ 1-4; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-86. - Rates and charges generally. 
    The rates and charges per meter, per month, for the use of water from the city water system for each consumer shall be as established by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 24-9; Code 2000, § 13-2-30; Ord. No. 419, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 471, § 1; Ord. No. 511, § 2; Ord. No. 556, § 1; Ord. No. 617, § 1; Ord. No. 679, § 1; Ord. No. 728, § 1; Ord. No. 775, § 1; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-87. - Billing procedure. 
    All city water used shall be billed to each consumer each month and shall be paid for by the consumer on or before the tenth day of the following month. 
(Prior Code, § 24-10; Code 2000, § 13-2-40; Ord. No. 419, § 4) 
Sec. 28-88. - Delinquent accounts. 
(a)  All rates and charges for the use of water shall be charged against and constitute a lien upon the real estate to which the water is furnished, and shall constitute a charge against the owner thereof. If for any cause any such charges shall become delinquent, the water supply for such real estate shall be cut off by the city, and in no case shall it be turned on to the same real estate until all such delinquencies have been paid in full, together with interest at the rate of five percent per annum, plus a charge as established by the city council. No change of ownership or occupation of such real estate shall bar the application of this section. 
(b)  In addition to the remedies for delinquent water bills set out in this article, the city clerk, when ordered by the city council, shall cause any delinquent charges for the use of water to be certified to the county clerk to be collected and paid to the county treasurer, in the same manner as taxes are collected and paid under state law. 
(Prior Code, §§ 24-11, 24-12; Code 2000, § 13-2-50; Ord. No. 419, §§ 6, 7; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 28-89-28-119. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - WATER ENTERPRISE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Water activities enterprises, C.R.S. § 37-45.1-101 et seq. 

Sec. 28-120. - Water enterprise. 
(a)  There is hereby established, pursuant to the terms and provisions of the Water Activity Law, C.R.S. § 37-45.1-101, the City of Lamar Water Activity Enterprise (the enterprise). The enterprise shall consist of the business represented by all of the city's water and sewer facilities and properties, now owned or hereafter acquired, whether situated within or outside the city boundaries, including all present or future improvements, extensions, enlargements, betterments, replacements or additions thereof or thereto (the system). The enterprise shall have all of the authority, powers, rights, obligations and duties as may be provided or permitted by the Water Activity Law and the state constitution, and as may be further prescribed by ordinance or resolution of the city. 
(b)  The governing body of the enterprise shall be the city council, and shall be subject to all of the applicable laws, rules and regulations pertaining to the city council. Whenever the city council is in session, the governing body shall also be deemed to be in session. It shall not be necessary for the governing body to meet separately from the regular and special meetings of the city council, nor shall it be necessary for the governing body to specifically announce or acknowledge that actions taken thereby are taken by the governing body of the enterprise. The governing body may conduct its affairs in the same manner and subject to the same laws which apply to the city council, for the same or similar matters, provided, that in accordance with C.R.S. § 37-45.1-104(2), the governing body may authorize the issuance of bonds by adoption of a resolution provided that all provisions of the Home Rule Charter shall be complied with. 
(c)  The enterprise shall at all times and in all ways conduct its affairs so as to continue to qualify as a water activity enterprise within the meaning of C.R.S. § 37-45.1-102, and as an enterprise within the meaning of article X, section 20 of the state constitution. Specifically, but not by way of limitation, the enterprise is not authorized to, and shall not, receive ten percent or more of its annual revenue in grants from all state and local governments combined. 
(d)  The enterprise is authorized to issue bonds, notes or other obligations payable from the revenues derived or to be derived from the system, in accordance with the Water Activity Law. The city council may also authorize the issuance of such bonds, notes or other obligations in accordance with applicable state laws and the city's Home Rule Charter, and in so doing, shall be deemed to be acting as the governing body. 
(Code 2000, § 13-1-10; Ord. No. 992, §§ 1-4, 1998; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Secs. 28-121-28-138. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FRANCHISES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-139. - Renewal of franchises. 
    All members of the city staff are hereby directed and authorized to become informed and knowledgeable regarding the terms, conditions and pertinent facts in relation to the public utility franchises granted by the city, and to do and perform all things necessary to cause renewal or replacement franchises in respect of said public utilities, to be accomplished so as to avoid any cessation of the services provided by such public utilities. 
(Code 2000, § 5-1-10; Ord. No. 946, § 1, 1995) 
Sec. 28-140. - Continuation of franchise. 
    In the event that any such public utility franchise expires without previous and timely renewal or replacement thereof being accomplished, such public utility provider whose franchise has thus expired and which shall continue to function and provide public utility service to the inhabitants of the city, shall be, and hereby is, deemed to be providing such services and continuing to function and conduct its business pursuant to a revocable business permit, as described in section 12-10 of the Home Rule Charter. 
(Code 2000, § 5-1-20; Ord. No. 946, § 2, 1995) 
Sec. 28-141. - Conditions for continuation. 
    All conditions, agreements, limitations, rights, privileges and duties of any such continuing public utility service provider, except the term and duration of such arrangement, shall continue on the identical basis and arrangement for which the original franchise of such public utility provided, and particularly being the fee or compensation originally agreed upon in the franchise of such public utility service provider, as mandated to be paid to the city pursuant to section 12-6 of the Home Rule Charter. 
(Code 2000, § 5-1-30; Ord. No. 946, § 3, 1995) 
Sec. 28-142. - Duration of continuation. 
    The term and duration of the continuing business permit afforded to such public utility service provider herein shall be for such time as is reasonably necessary in order to negotiate for a renewal of such franchise and obtain voter approval thereof, to allow such public utility service provider to close out its business, or to allow such public utility service provider to dispose of or remove its property from the city. During any such continuation of public utilities pursuant to the business permit arrangements hereinabove set forth, neither the city nor the public utility service provider shall have the right to terminate such permit sooner than 180 days after giving written notice to the opposite party of its intentions so to terminate. 
(Code 2000, § 5-1-40; Ord. No. 946, § 4, 1995; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-143. - Access to city property. 
(a)  The continuation of any public utility service by a provider pursuant to the business permit arrangement hereinabove set forth shall not be deemed to be a trespass by the public utility service provider upon city property. 
(b)  No such continuation of public utility service pursuant to the business permit arrangement shall be deemed to be a renewal of any such franchise, nor shall the same be deemed to be a grant of such franchise, the same being, instead, an implied consent to use of municipal property, upon previously agreed upon conditions, for an indefinite but limited period of time, in the best interest of all citizens of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 5-1-50; Ord. No. 946, §§ 5, 6, 1995) 
Sec. 28-144. - Approval of voters. 
    Nothing herein contained shall obviate the need for voter approval of public utility franchises, as required by section 12-5 of the Home Rule Charter. 
(Code 2000, § 5-1-60; Ord. No. 946, § 7, 1995) 
Secs. 28-145-28-171. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NATURAL GAS 

Sec. 28-172. - Grant. 
    Greeley Gas Company, a division of Atmos Energy Corporation, hereinafter called the company, is hereby granted the right, privilege and franchise to construct, install, maintain and operate in, through and along the present and future streets and alleys of the city its mains, pipes, boxes, reducing and regulating stations, laterals, conduits and service extensions, together with all of the necessary appurtenances, for the purpose of supplying natural gas for light, heat, power and other purposes to the city and the inhabitants thereof and users therein (including domestic, commercial, public authority and industrial consumers) for the term of this franchise, subject, however, to the limitations herein set forth and provided. Provisions applicable to the furnishing of natural gas to the city light plant by the company shall be set forth in a separate contract. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-10; Ord. No. 950, § 1, 1995; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-173. - Term. 
(a)  The rights, privileges and franchise herein granted to and conferred upon the company shall extend for a term of ten years from November 8, 1995, until the Tuesday after the first Monday in November 2005, and for an extended period of ten years, which may thereafter be granted as hereinafter set forth. 
(b)  After January 1, 2005, and before March 1, 2005, the company shall file with the city a report that documents the efforts and progress that the company has made in meeting the city's objectives of ensuring safe, reliable and best-cost natural gas service for and to natural gas consumers within the city. Upon receipt of the report, the city shall conduct an inquiry into the facts presented and will determine, through the city council, whether the company should be granted the hereinabove referenced ten-year extension of the franchise, which grant shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-20; Ord. No. 950, § 2, 1995) 
Sec. 28-174. - Effective date. 
    The effective date for the grant of franchise shall be November 8, 1995. Pursuant to section 12-5 of the city Home Rule Charter, the company shall be liable for its proportionate cost and expense of said election. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-30; Ord. No. 950, § 3, 1995; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-175. - Compensation. 
(a)  For this grant, and as consideration for use and occupancy of the streets, alleys and public grounds, the company shall pay monthly on the volumes consumed, commencing November 8, 1995, five percent of the gross revenue realized from the sales of gas for domestic, commercial and industrial use in the city, provided that the franchise fee provided for in this article shall not be charged or collected for gas used by any governmental unit or tax-exempt organization which has provided the company with written notification of its status. 
(b)  For the purpose of ascertaining or auditing the correct amount to be paid under the provisions of this article, the city shall have reasonable access to the appropriate books of the company for the purpose of checking the gross income received from operations within the city. The company shall not be required to generate books and records which it does not maintain in its regular course of business. 
(c)  It is understood that payment of such franchise charge does not excuse the company from payment of either sales and use taxes or property taxes, as such taxes are levied from time to time. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-40; Ord. No. 950, § 4, 1995; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-176. - Laying pipe. 
(a)  The company shall use its best efforts to lay all new construction pipeline at least 24 inches below the surface of the streets, alleys and avenues, at least such depth below the bottom of all drain ditches, and in a manner which does not interfere with any present public or private drains, sewers, water mains, sidewalks, paving or other public improvements. The city reserves the right to construct, change or repair any public improvements and to change the grades of any street, avenue or alley. Should the same be changed, constructed or repaired, the company is required, at its own expense, to lower, change or alter the pipelines to harmonize the regulations herein and not to interfere with the conduits, water lines, sewers, sidewalks, paving, drains or other public improvements of the city or the public utilities of the city. The company agrees to perform routine maintenance and surveillance in accordance with industry standards to ensure that pipeline depth complies with applicable state codes and regulations. 
(b)  If practicable, no pipeline shall be laid closer than two feet from any water main or other pipe or conduit of other utilities. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-50; Ord. No. 950, § 5, 1995; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-177. - Repairs and replacements. 
    All earth, materials, sidewalks, pavings, crossings or improvements of any kind required or removed by the company shall be fully repaired and replaced promptly by the company, and the company shall protect and save the city and the citizens thereof harmless from any loss or damage and from any and all claims or suits to persons or property on account of the construction, installation, operation and maintenance of said distribution system, unless such loss or damage occurs as a result of the negligence of the city or its citizens. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-60; Ord. No. 950, § 6, 1995) 
Sec. 28-178. - Excavations supervised. 
    An excavation by the company in any of the streets, alleys, avenues, roads or public grounds within the limits of the city shall be done in accordance with such reasonable rules, resolutions and ordinances now enacted or to be enacted by the city council relating to the excavations in streets, alleys and public grounds of the city. City officials who, from time to time, may be charged with enforcing ordinances relating to excavation may be present to ensure compliance with such ordinances. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-70; Ord. No. 950, § 7, 1995; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-179. - Extensions; service devices. 
(a)  The company shall, at all times during the term of this franchise, install and maintain, at its own expense, service devices and street services, and all measuring, regulating or limiting devices which are necessary for the supplying of service to the consumer (including services to the curbline along the line of the main where the main is in the street, and to the abutting property line where the main is in the alley) and shall make all extensions for the supplying of its services to the consumers and inhabitants of the city. The same shall be made, supplied and furnished under rules and regulations of the company as may be, from time to time, filed by the company with, and approved by, the public utilities commission of the state (PUC), or as may be prescribed by such commission or any other regulatory body with duly established jurisdiction over such matters. 
(b)  Each consumer of gas shall install and maintain, at his or her own expense, within his or her property line, suitable service lines, appliances and fixtures, except meters as may be necessary for the use of such gas supply, such service lines, appliances and fixtures to be subject to the inspection of the authorized representative of the city and the company at all reasonable times. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-80; Ord. No. 950, § 8, 1995) 
Sec. 28-180. - Meters. 
    All natural gas sold and distributed by the company hereunder shall be measured by company-owned and installed meters located on the premises of the consumer served, or upon easements of rights-of-way adjacent thereto. Company employees or agents shall have the right to enter upon such consumer's premises and read or inspect its meters at reasonable times during daylight hours. The company shall furnish reliable gas meters, as described in section 28-181. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-90; Ord. No. 950, § 9, 1995) 
Sec. 28-181. - Standards for natural gas supply. 
    The company shall maintain and operate its plants and system and render efficient service in accordance with the rules and regulations of the PUC, and the terms and conditions of this article, including specifically, but without limitation, the following requirements: 
(1)  Heating value. Natural gas sold, supplied and delivered under this franchise shall be maintained at a monthly average of not less than 950 British Thermal Units of heat value per cubic foot. A cubic foot of gas means that amount of gas which, when saturated with water vapor at a temperature of 60 degrees Fahrenheit and subject to an absolute pressure equal to 30 inches of mercury, at 32 degrees Fahrenheit (14.73 pounds per square inch) occupies a volume of one cubic foot. Gas sold under this franchise shall be accurately measured utilizing equipment of a type approved or allowed by the PUC. Upon the city's request, the company will provide the city with copies of any calorimeter and pressure reports that it maintains. 
(2)  Natural gas. Natural gas may be furnished to the city from wells, pipelines or gas processing plants, and the company shall remove any objectionable constituents or noxious gases therefrom and add such odorizing agent as may be required by law or regulations of any applicable regulatory authority. 
(3)  Pressure of service. Until and unless lawfully changed, the standard of pressure of service shall be the same as now or hereafter approved by or acceptable to the PUC. 
(4)  Maintenance of system. The company shall maintain its gas plant equipment and distribution system in good condition and repair at all times. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-100; Ord. No. 950, § 10, 1995; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-182. - Rates and conditions of service. 
    The rates to be charged and exacted from the city and its inhabitants, and the rules and regulations with reference to the character, quality and standards of service to be furnished by the company, shall be under the jurisdiction and control of the PUC or such regulatory body as may, from time to time during this grant, be vested by law with authority and jurisdiction of the rates, regulations and quality and standards of service to be supplied by the company; provided, however, that nothing contained within this section shall be construed or interpreted as obviating the necessity for the company to receive, and the city's voters to grant, the franchise as a requirement of the company doing business within the city. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-110; Ord. No. 950, § 11, 1995) 
Sec. 28-183. - Maps. 
    The company shall prepare and submit to the city a map showing the location of its distribution system, showing the approximate locations and sizes of lines, locations of shutoff valves and gates, and all appurtenances incident to the distribution system, so far as such facilities can reasonably be projected. The map shall be kept reasonably current by addition of the information hereby required as the system is extended or revised. Prior to the performance of any excavation work, the city shall notify the company and provide the company with an opportunity to mark the location of its lines and facilities in accordance with applicable state statutes. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-120; Ord. No. 950, § 12, 1995) 
Sec. 28-184. - Rules and regulations. 
    The company shall have the right to make such reasonable rules and regulations for the protection of its property for the prevention of loss and waste in the conduct or management of its business and for the sale and distribution or curtailment of gas under the terms hereof as may, from time to time, be deemed necessary and approved by the PUC. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-130; Ord. No. 950, § 13, 1995; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-185. - Indemnification. 
    The company shall indemnify, defend and hold the city harmless from and against all claims, demands, liens and liability for damage of whatever kind on account of or arising from the grant of the franchise, the exercise by the company of the related rights or the operations of the company within the city, and shall pay the costs of defense plus reasonable attorney and expert witness fees. However, the company shall not indemnify, defend and hold the city harmless from claims, demands, liens, liability and damage to the extent that they arise from the negligence of the city. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-140; Ord. No. 950, § 14, 1995) 
Sec. 28-186. - Insurance. 
(a)  The company shall be insured or shall maintain adequate self-insurance to cover and protect itself from and against all claims, demands, actions, judgments, costs, expenses and liabilities which may arise or result, directly or indirectly, from or by reason of loss, injury or damage to the city, its property or employees, or to other persons or their property. The company shall maintain insurance against such liabilities in the minimum amount of $5,000,000.00. 
(b)  The company shall file all certificates of insurance with the city, showing the specific limits of insurance, coverage required and deductibles required. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-150; Ord. No. 950, § 15, 1995) 
Sec. 28-187. - Discrimination or preference prohibited. 
(a)  The company shall not, as to rates or service, make or grant any unreasonable preference or advantage to any consumer or subject any consumer to any unreasonable prejudice or disadvantage, provided that nothing in this franchise shall be taken to prohibit the establishment from time to time of graduated scales of charges and classified rate schedules to which any consumer coming within an established classification would be entitled. 
(b)  The rates to be charged by the company for industrial gas used in the city may be lower and different from those charged for gas used for other purposes, provided that contracts or tariffs for industrial gas contain a curtailment clause which recognizes the preferred right of the other users over industrial users. 
(c)  The company is encouraged to promulgate and utilize rate structures which would be most advantageous to low income and low income elderly consumers, whenever permitted by applicable regulatory provisions. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-160; Ord. No. 950, § 16, 1995) 
Sec. 28-188. - Right of inspection. 
    Upon five days' notice, the city may, at its sole expense, at any reasonable time during normal business hours, inspect the company's books and records pertaining to and directly affecting the rights of the city arising under or by virtue of this franchise. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-170; Ord. No. 950, § 17, 1995; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-189. - Financial information. 
(a)  The company shall provide the city with the following information on a monthly basis: 
(1)  The city's monthly sales revenue derived from sales of natural gas within the city limits; 
(2)  Franchise fee exemptions, if any, by type; 
(3)  Net revenues for the city subject to franchise fees; and 
(4)  Total amount of franchise fees billed to customers. 
(b)  Upon request by the city, but not more frequently than annually, the company shall provide the city with two complete copies of: 
(1)  All annual natural gas operating and financial reports filed by the company or its parent, Atmos Energy Corporation, related to the operations of the company, with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and state regulatory bodies; and 
(2)  Copies of all documents which are distributed to the stockholders and bondholders of the company or its parent, Atmos Energy Corporation. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-180; Ord. No. 950, § 18, 1995; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-190. - Gas supply cost; information. 
    The company shall implement and maintain gas purchasing practices and policies designated to provide the lowest reasonable cost of purchased gas to the city's residents consistent with the company's standards of quality and reliability. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-190; Ord. No. 950, § 19, 1995) 
Sec. 28-191. - Transfer of ownership or control. 
(a)  This franchise and the rights granted to the company under this franchise shall not be sold, leased, assigned, disposed of or transferred, either in whole or in part, through the sale, merger, consolidation, reorganization or transfer to any other person, entity or corporation without the consent and approval of the city. The city's consent and approval shall be withheld, if at all, only upon the grounds that: 
(1)  The proposed purchaser, transferee or assignee refuses to be bound by and comply with all provisions of this franchise; or 
(2)  The proposed purchaser, transferee or assignee does not have the financial or physical capability to perform the company's duties and obligations under this franchise. 
In any event, the city shall not have the right to withhold such consent and approval if such transfer of ownership or control is approved by the PUC, or such other state agency as shall then have jurisdiction over such transfer of ownership or control. 
(b)  Should the company sell, lease, assign, dispose of or transfer rights gained under this franchise without first requesting the city's consent and approval, this franchise shall be deemed to have no value in any subsequent city condemnation proceeding, as set forth in C.R.S. § 31-15-707. 
(c)  At such time as the company shall make formal application with the PUC, or with any other state regulatory body having jurisdiction over such a proposed sale, transfer or assignment, the company shall notify the city of such proposed transfer of rights granted under this franchise, and shall also provide the city with copies of all nonconfidential documents related to the sale or transfer as are filed with such state regulatory body having jurisdiction of the sale. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-200; Ord. No. 950, § 20, 1995; Ord. No. 1022, § 1, 2000) 
Sec. 28-192. - Forfeiture. 
    The city reserves the right to declare a forfeiture and termination of this franchise for the breach of a substantial and material provision thereof. No forfeiture or termination shall be declared until the company shall have had a reasonable opportunity to be heard and to correct the alleged breach. Upon failure of the company to exercise reasonable diligence to correct such condition, the city may declare this franchise forfeited and terminated, in which event, the company shall, as provided in division 1 of this article, continue to render service as theretofore for a period of 180 days to enable the city to determine its course of action. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-210; Ord. No. 950, § 21, 1995) 
Sec. 28-193. - Acquisition of system. 
(a)  In express recognition of the fact that the company, or its predecessors in interest, have heretofore been grantee of a franchise from the city for the furnishing of natural gas for a period in excess of 20 years, and in further express recognition of the provisions of C.R.S. § 31-15-707(1)(a)(II), and the Home Rule Charter, the franchise renewal is granted upon the express condition that the city has the right and power to purchase or condemn the company's works or system at their fair market value at the time of purchasing or condemning such works or systems, excluding all value of the franchise or right-of-way through the streets and also excluding any value by virtue of any contract for hydrants or private rental or otherwise entered into with the city in excess of the fair market value of said works or systems. 
(b)  Any such acquisition shall be in accordance with all applicable laws at the time of such purchase or condemnation. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-220; Ord. No. 950, § 22, 1995) 
Sec. 28-194. - Continuation of performance after expiration of franchise. 
    In the event that the company continues to provide gas service to consumers within the city after the expiration of the franchise, the company shall be bound by all provisions of division 1 of this article, providing for continuation of services by public utilities upon expiration of franchises granted. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-230; Ord. No. 950, § 23, 1995) 
Sec. 28-195. - Failure of gas supply. 
    During the term of the franchise, should there occur a failure or partial failure of the supply of natural gas available to the company because of depletion of such supply, the company shall take all reasonable steps to obtain an additional natural gas supply from other sources to be delivered to the company and, if unable to procure the same, it is hereby authorized to supply artificial or mixed gas for the unexpired term of this franchise. If the company, within a reasonable period after failure of the supply of natural gas, shall fail to supply to its customers artificial and/or mixed gas, the franchise rights granted herein shall terminate. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-240; Ord. No. 950, § 24, 1995) 
Sec. 28-196. - Changing conditions. 
    The city and the company recognize that the gas industry is currently the subject of discussion, examination and inquiry by different segments of the industry and by state and federal regulators, and that these activities may ultimately result in fundamental changes in the way the company conducts its business and meets its service obligations. Therefore, at the request of either party, the city and the company agree to meet with each other and discuss in good faith amendments to the franchise to reflect a proper accommodation of such developments. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-250; Ord. No. 950, § 25, 1995) 
Sec. 28-197. - Local office maintained. 
    The company shall, during the life of the franchise, maintain an adequately staffed service and management office within the city. 
(Code 2000, § 5-2-260; Ord. No. 950, § 26, 1995) 
Chapter 30 - ZONING 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accessory building means a subordinate building or portion of the main building, the use of which customarily is incidental to that of the main building or to the main use of the premises. For the purposes of this chapter, the term "accessory building" shall include dish antennas and similar structures. 
    Accessory use means a subordinate purpose for which the land or structures thereon are designed or intended. 
    Alley means a public thoroughfare which provides only a secondary means of access to abutting property, the right-of-way of which is 20 feet or less in width. 
    Alter means any structural change in the supporting or load-bearing members of a building, such as bearing walls, columns, beams, girders or floor joists. 
    Animal hospital or clinic means an establishment where animals are admitted principally for examination, treatment, board or care by a doctor of veterinary medicine. This does not include open kennels or runs. 
    Apartment. See Dwelling, multiple family. 
    Aquaculture means the science and endeavor of producing and raising, on a commercial basis, fish or shellfish in confined tanks or beds of water. 
    Basement means a story having part, but not less than one-half, of its height below grade. 
    Board of adjustment and appeals means the legally-appointed municipal board empowered to hear and decide appeals from, and to provide interpretations of the terms of, the zoning regulations and official zoning map, as defined within this article, and in accordance with state laws. 
    Boardinghouse means a building other than a hotel where, for compensation and by prearrangement for definite periods, meals, or lodging and meals, are provided for three or more persons, but not exceeding 20 persons. 
    Building means any structure designed or intended for the enclosure, shelter or protection of persons, animals or property. When a structure is divided into separate parts by unpierced walls from the ground up, each part is deemed a separate building. 
    Building height means the vertical dimension measured from the average elevation of the finished lot grade at the front of the building to the highest point of a flat roof to the deck line of a mansard roof and to the average height between the plate and ridge of a gable, hip or gambrel roof. 
    Building official means the person designated by the city council to administer these zoning regulations, whether such person is entitled building official, building inspector, administrative official, public works director, enforcing officer or zoning official. 
    Car wash means an establishment having facilities designed or used exclusively for washing or cleaning motor vehicles. 
    Cellar means a story having more than one-half of its height below grade. 
    Child care. See Day nursery. 
    Clinic. See Medical, dental or health clinic. 
    Club or lodge means a nonprofit association or organization formed for fraternal, social, educational, philanthropic or other similar purposes, including unions and professional organizations. 
    Comprehensive plan means the duly adopted comprehensive plan for the development of the community which includes maps, charts, illustrations and texts for the following: 
(1)  Land use studies; 
(2)  Goals and objectives; 
(3)  Population study and forecasts; 
(4)  Economic study; 
(5)  Housing survey; 
(6)  Transportation plan; 
(7)  Central business district plan; 
(8)  Community facilities and public utilities plan; and 
(9)  General development plan. 
    Condominium means an individually-owned, single-family dwelling unit located in a multifamily structure where the surrounding lot area is held in common and maintained through a special ownership agreement. 
    Day care center. See Day nursery. 
    Day care home. See Day nursery. 
    Day nursery includes the following: 
(1)  Child care. See Day care home, Large day care home and Day care center. 
(2)  Day care center means a facility which is not the caregiver's residence, and which provides day care for 13 or more unrelated children. 
(3)  Day care home means a facility in which the primary caregiver provides day care out of his or her home for two to six unrelated children. 
(4)  Large day care home means a facility in which the primary caregiver provides day care out of his or her home for seven to 12 unrelated children. 
(5)  Preschool means an establishment which provides educational services for unrelated children aged five years and under and/or below the age required for entrance into the public school system. 
    Dwelling, multiple family or multifamily means a residential building designed for or occupied by three or more families with the number of families in residence not exceeding the number of dwelling units provided. 
    Dwelling, single-family means a detached residential dwelling unit, other than a mobile home, designed for and occupied by one family only. 
    Dwelling, two-family means a detached residential building containing two dwelling units, designed for occupancy by not more than two families. 
    Dwelling unit means one room, or rooms connected together, constituting a separate, independent housekeeping establishment for owner occupancy, rental or lease on a weekly, monthly or longer basis, and physically separated from any other rooms or dwelling units which may be in the same structure and containing independent cooking and sleeping facilities. 
    Family means one or more persons occupying the premises and living as a single housekeeping unit, as distinguished from a group occupying a boardinghouse, fraternity or sorority house, lodginghouse, hotel or motel. 
    Floodplain means land area subject to inundation from surplus stormwater, as defined by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) flood insurance study, and as depicted on the flood insurance rate map for the community. 
    Frontage means all the property on one side of a street between two intersecting streets (crossing or terminating), measured along the line of the street. Where a street is dead-ended, the frontage shall be considered as all that property abutting on one side between an intersecting street and the dead end of the street. 
    Garage, private means an accessory building designed or used for the storage of not more than four motor-driven vehicles owned and used by the occupants of the building to which it is accessory. 
    Garage, public means a building or portion thereof, other than a private or storage garage, designed or used for equipping, repairing, hiring, servicing, selling or storing motor-driven vehicles. 
    Home occupation. 
(1)  The term "home occupation" means an occupation or activity carried out on the premises which meets all of the following conditions: 
a.  Only one person other than residents of the premises shall be engaged in such occupation; 
b.  The occupation is customarily incidental to the use of the premises as a dwelling place; 
c.  Not more than one non-illuminated nameplate is used; 
d.  The nameplate shall be attached to the building and shall not exceed one square foot in area; 
e.  The occupation does not occupy more than 25 percent of the floor area of one floor of the principal building, when such use is carried on in the principal building; 
f.  No display will indicate from the exterior of the building that the premises are being used in part for any purpose other than a dwelling; 
g.  There is no commodity displayed or stored on the premises except that which is prepared on the premises; 
h.  No equipment or process shall be used in such home occupation which creates noise, vibration, glare, fumes, odors or electrical interference detectable to the normal senses of a person off the lot if the occupation is conducted in a single-family residence, or outside the individual dwelling unit if conducted in other than a single-family residence. In the case of electrical interference, no equipment or process shall be used which creates visual or audible interference in any radio or television receivers off the premises or causes fluctuations in line voltage off the premises; and 
i.  No traffic shall be generated by such home occupation in greater volumes than would normally be expected in a residential neighborhood. 
(2)  The term "home occupation" does not include the growth or cultivation of marijuana for medical purposes, and a medical marijuana center may not be operated as a home occupation. 
    Hospital means an establishment used primarily for inpatient care and provision of health, medical, mental and surgical care of the sick or injured. 
    Junkyard or salvage yard means a lot, parcel or tract of land, including buildings, used primarily for the collection, storage and sale of waste paper, rags, scrap metal or other discarded material or for the collection, dismantling, storage and salvaging of machinery or vehicles not in running condition, or for the sale of parts thereof. 
    Kennel means any house, building, structure, premises or land where more than three dogs over the age of four months are kept. 
    Large day care center. See Day nursery. 
    Loading space, off-street means space logically and conveniently located for bulk pickups and deliveries, scaled to delivery vehicles expected to be used and accessible to such vehicles when required off-street parking spaces are filled. Required off-street loading space is not to be included as off-street parking space in computation of required off-street parking space. 
    Lot. 
(1)  The term "lot" means a parcel of land of at least sufficient size to meet minimum zoning requirements for use, coverage and area, and to provide such yards and other open spaces as are herein required. Such lot shall have frontage on any improved public street or on an approved private street and may consist of: 
a.  A single lot of record; 
b.  A portion of a lot of record; 
c.  A combination of complete lots of record, of complete lots of record and portions of lots of record or of portions of lots of record; or 
d.  A parcel of land described by metes and bounds. 
Provided that, in no case of divisions or combination shall any residual lot or parcel be created which does not meet the requirements of this chapter. 
(2)  The term "lot" includes the term "plot" or "parcel." 
    Lot frontage means the portion nearest the street. For the purposes of determining yard requirements on corner lots and through lots, all sides of a lot adjacent to streets shall be considered frontage, and yards shall be provided as indicated under the definition of the term "yard" in this section. 
    Lot measurements are defined as follows: 
(1)  Depth of a lot is considered to be the distance between the midpoints of straight lines connecting the foremost points of the side lot lines in the front and the rearmost points of the side lot lines in the rear. 
(2)  Width of a lot is considered to be the distance between straight lines connecting front and rear lot lines at each side of the lot, measured across the rear of the required front yard; provided, however, that width between side lot lines at their foremost points (where they intersect with the street line) shall not be less than 80 percent of the required lot width except in the case of lots on the turning circle of cul-de-sacs, where the 80-percent requirement shall not apply. 
    Lot of record means a lot which is part of a subdivision recorded in the office of the county clerk, or a lot or parcel described by metes and bounds, the description of which has been so recorded. 
    Lot type. See the diagram below which illustrates terminology with reference to types of lots. 
    Manufacture means any method of processing, developing, fabricating or assembling raw materials, semi-finished materials or parts into a semi-finished or finished product. 
    Manufactured home means a single-family dwelling which meets all of the following standards: 
(1)  Is partially or entirely manufactured in a factory; 
(2)  Is not less than 24 feet in width and 36 feet in length; 
(3)  Is installed on an engineered permanent foundation; 
(4)  Has brick, wood or a cosmetically equivalent exterior siding and a pitched roof; all homes with bow, or arch, trusses being expressly prohibited; 
(5)  Is susceptible of, and intended for, permanent connection to public utilities; and 
(6)  Which meets or exceeds, on an equivalent performance engineering basis, standards which include, but are not limited to, standards established by the city building code, the housing and urban development standards or the uniform building code standards. The term "equivalent performance engineering basis" means that by using engineering calculations or testing, following commonly accepted engineering practices, all components and subsystems will perform to meet health, safety and functional requirements to the same extent as required for other single-family housing units. 
Any manufactured home sited within any zoning district of the city, where allowed, shall be placed in its permanent location in such manner that any open space, or gap, between the bottom of said manufactured home and the ground shall be enclosed by poured concrete wall, concrete block wall or other solid masonry construction wall, said wall being plumb to the exterior walls of said manufactured home, and without regard to whether or not the exterior walls of said manufactured home are bearing walls or not. It is the intent of this requirement that no manufactured home shall be sited within any zoning district where allowed with skirting made of wood, metal, plastic, vinyl, fiberglass or any other perimeter enclosure of a temporary nature. 
    Medical clinic, dental clinic or health clinic means any building designed for use by one or more persons lawfully engaged in the diagnosis, care and treatment of physical or mental diseases or ailments of human beings, including, but not limited to, doctors of medicine, dentists, chiropractors, osteopaths, optometrists, psychiatrists and podiatrists; and in which no patients are lodged overnight. The definition of the term "medical clinic," "dental clinic" or "health clinic" shall not include a medical marijuana center. 
    Medical marijuana center means the use of property for profit or otherwise which is operated by any person, including, but not limited to, a patient or caregiver, and which is used to cultivate, distribute, transmit, give, dispense or otherwise provide marijuana in any manner to any other person, other patient or other caregivers in accordance with section 14 of article IV of the state constitution and the implementing state statutes and administrative policies. As used in this section, the terms "patient" and "caregiver" shall have the meanings provided in section 14 of article IV of the state constitution and the implementing state statutes and administrative policies. 
    Medical marijuana dispensary means the use of property for profit or otherwise which is operated by any person, including, but not limited to, a patient or caregiver, and which is used to cultivate, distribute, transmit, give, dispense or otherwise provide marijuana in any manner to any other person, other patient or other caregivers in accordance with section 14 of article IV of the state constitution and the implementing state statutes and administrative policies.
